comment: As advertised. Easy to install and keep in mind it was my first time ever that I had to change or touch a light switch more than turning on/off the light. My main concern was that in my garage I have a 2 gang switch (one switch for the garage lights and the other for the outside lights) and was worried if one of these smart switches will fit next to the regular switch and under the same main original cover....Let me tell you, everything was on point.

I have had this for about a month and really like it.  It works consistently both with the app and Alexa.  Installation was easy too.The best feature is that it is more energy efficient than competitive switches.  I bought a Leviton switch initially (DW15S-1BZ) and found it disconcerting how warm it was.  I bought this TP-Link switch and installed it in another room to compare.  This switch is cool to the touch.  It uses a little bit of power even when the light is off, but not a noticeable amount.  The TP-Link Switch is about 8 degrees warmer than the ambient room temperature.  In comparison, the Leviton switch was 20 degrees warmer which is warm enough to notice.

I've spent a lot of money on Smart Home tech lately, buying myriad brands and devices, to include Wink, Hue, Smart+/Lightify, August, Schlage and GE).  I've found that, by a huge margin, the Kasa brand has been the most reliable, and caused the least amount of heartburn out of the bunch!  They typically respond immediately (nearly imperceptible delay, seriously!) to Echo commands with only the occasional exaggerated delay, none of my other devices respond as fast, nor do they work at their fastest as often as my Kasa devices have.  Once installed they are easy to connect, the schedules are easy to program (I've never had one glitch yet, which I can't say about the others), and the app is the absolute quickest to connect and respond when "away" (it might even be faster than when using the Echo).That is why I'm actually sad to only give it 4 stars.  What could Kasa possibly do to make themselves worthy of that 5th star, you ask?  Simply offer a toggle design instead of only decora/rocker style switches.  These simply don't fit the aesthetic of my home and my wife will only let me put them in out-of-sight places (under the cupboards and in the garage so far).  I would happily pack up and sell off every other of my myriad devices to replace them with a Kasa offering of equal ability and a "rustic" design, but that's not an option, and since I'm sure that's not going to ever happen, I'll have to stick with the GE toggles until I can convince my wife "Rustic Futuristic" is a thing.

My gosh, there are a bunch of techically inept people throwing shade. This thing is awesome. Works perfectly. Step 1: Install the switch per instructions-easy  Step 2: download KASA app Step 3: Set up your account at the KASA site-easy Step 4: From your account at the Kasa site tap the device name; a screen for that device appears, with selections for Schedule, Away, Timer, an off/on button and at the top right corner an icon that looks like three little sliders. Tap that icon to open the Device Settings screen and then slide the Remote Control slider icon to the right so that it lights green.  (Remote Control ON is required for use away from your network AND/OR by Alexa.).  (Alternative step 4: configure the switch as  "local" or "remote" connected in the Kasa app in the Device Settings menu.) Step 5: go to ALEXA app to link accounts and enable skill. If you screw up: In KASA app delete switch and on the switch press reset for 10 seconds then start over.11/29/19 Update; after 2 years and 9 months, Zero issues.

Things to check before you buy:□1. Your existing light switch "box" (inside the wall) has the "neutral" wire available, not just the (switched) "live" wire.  Old houses, and some other installations, may only have the single "live" wire going thru the wall box.  This switch, because it has active electronics, needs both to work.

Installation when smoothly until the new firmware update was pushed to switches.  Then only one of the two switches would work.  Called the support number 877-458-0562.  Support person asked to looked at network/switches remotely so they could trouble shoot and fix issue.  After looking at system, which already has 2 other TP-Link smart plugs, the "technican" then kept showing me all the broken links on my network, but would not fix the broken firmware update.  Finally it became clear, the "technical" was just a sales consultant who wanted $199.00 to fix the network and the switches, and then would turn me over too a real technical support person.  The "technician" would not correct the firmware update that was corrupted. WHAT A CON JOB!!And now since the switch goes into a coastal cabin, I can not return the product as it is 3 days past the 30 deadline.  So not a good experience.

Before purchasing this switch I already had some familiarity with TP-Link products because I had been using several of their WiFi smart plugs for over a year and was very happy with them.  I also had some experience with light switches like these, having installed about ten of them in my house.  Those switches work fine, but they are all made by another company and they require a hub.  What I love about this TP-Link switch is that it installs and integrates easily like other TP-Link products and it does NOT require a hub.(In case you're wondering what I mean by "hub," many smart devices such as Lutron light switches and Samsung Smartthings devices don't connect with your home network directly via WiFi, but rather through their own proprietary hub, a small device which you plug into your router or connect to your home's WiFi network.  There's nothing inherently wrong with a hub,, but it's an extra piece of equipment and therefore another layer of complexity.)

After I had bought three good working wifi plugs I first ordered one and then another switch, before trying to properly install the first switch. Turned out, both did not switch the light on. They connected to the wifi just fine and I was able to operate the switch manually and via the app alas the lights would not go on. I put the old manual switch back in and the lights worked - so it was not the light that was defective. Tried their online help - takes ages for someone to respond by chat. After some back and forth they sent me a link with installation instructions, which I had followed anyway. Then they admitted they cannot help and I should return the switches to Amazon.I also tried their phone service line - what a horrible experience. Took 10 attempts to just get the auto response system. Then waiting, waiting and waiting. Got disconnected three times after considerable wait time and once while speaking to an agent. But I did not give up, hoping I will be able to make the switches work. The last agent I was able to speak to suggested I should contact a professional electrician. Thank you for that. I am an electrician by trade and have a masters degree in electrical engineering.

Easy install and paired with Alexa with zero problems. I bought this to operate my fireplace by voice. Worked out great. Also, the switch does work with a standard decora cover plate so you don't have to install the gigantic cover plate that comes with it. Fireplace controls are low voltage and the Kasa switch only passes its 120v line voltage through so I used a 120v Honeywell pam relay to close the fireplace contacts. The pam relays are low cost, extremely reliable and have a high temp rating because they are listed fire alarm equipment, perfect for a fireplace.

I had seemingly a much more complex install than what the instructions demonstrated, but ultimately was able to get it done. I had to connect 4 neutral wires from the same breaker circuit to get this switch to control the two light fixtures that the old switch controlled. Took me forever to ultimately figure it out and dig to find all the correct neutral wires and none of the ones belonging to the other two switches in my 4 gang setup.Took almost an act of God to get the bulk of this new switch to fit into the wall box. Be prepared to feel some pain trying cram it in.

I liked this for about 4 days.  Then it was obvious it was a weak, poorly designed piece of junk. It strangely makes a very faint buzzing/clicking sort of noise all the time. At first it worked fine and connected to the wi-fi, and I was even able to set up an on/off schedule for our foyer chandelier light. However, after a few days the light started not turning on, and we wondered what was wrong. We noticed the switch was blinking orange and white. Apparently, it keeps randomly dropping connection to the wi-fi or something. No idea why. It's literally only 15 ft. from the router!!! We have other brand (w*mo) switches that are farther away and work fine.  This TP-Link switch just doesn't work properly. I'm tired of having to reset it every other day just so it can connect to the wi-fi and turn on the light again.  The other problem is, it shouldn't even need to be connected to wi-fi in order to manually turn the light on/off... that's ridiculous! The other brand switches we have don't do that, because even if they are disconnected from wi-fi they still work manually.  I would not recommend this product at all!!

UPDATE 3: It's now been long enough for me to believe that TP-Link has successfully corrected the problem I referenced in UPDATE 1 below.  My units have continued to work successfully for well over a month now, including self recovering once power was restored from a power outage. All have continued to work flawlessly with all of my my Echo (Alexa) devices and I've been able to verify I can use the Kasa app to turn lights on and off from anywhere I have internet access on my cell phone.While I'm at it I should note that one limitation for these is that they are strictly single pole (SPST) switches, which means they can't be installed in place of a 3-way (SPDT) switch . It would be nice if TP-Link offered a 3-way version of the product for those of us who might want to use one with a multi-switch installation.

Update 4-28-20: a software update last month for the switch finally allowed me to schedule on/off times to automatically be set to sunset/sunrise times, without the need of using a TP-Link hub. This was the reason I had deducted 2 stars from my rating. Now the switches do this automatically and I don’t have to keep adjusting the schedule manually as sunset/sunrise times change through the year. Raised my rating to 5 stars. Highly recommended. Below is my original review from 2018.Original review: The previous owner of our new townhouse had Nest thermostat and Nest Protect smoke detectors installed. I added a Nest Hello doorbell and was happy with it. I decided to take a tentative step into further home automation by adding these TP-Link HS200 light switches for the front and back porch lights.

I absolutely love these switches. I have small 2 kids and they constantly leave the lights on in our entire downstairs family room area ( office, playroom, and garage). I often wouldn't know that they left a light on for hours or, for the garage, the whole night sometimes.So I had to find something that would stop the headache.

TP-Link requires the switch to be setup with an app installed on a mobile phone. There is no way to use a desktop to setup the switch even though the switch is perfectly capable of being setup with a simple browser + wifi just like an Amazon echo. TP-Link is using the mobile app to do a personal data grab.The TP-Link app on the mobile phone uses the mobile's wifi transmitter to setup the initial communication with the switch, just like setting up an echo with a desktop computer's browser + wifi. TP-Link's app won't allow the setup to continue until the app is given access to the mobile device's location, and the setup won't proceed until you also enable enhanced location gathering on android (this includes GPS and other info). The app complains it "needs" the location in order to "find" the switch. LOL what total BS. I can't believe TP-Link thought they could sell that line. TP-Link should just admit to ransomware. TP-Link ransomed your wall switch (that you already bought with your hard-earned $$) in return for personal data stored on your mobile device. The potential data loss includes your high-fidelity home location (easily mapped to an address), your wifi-name, other locations you travel to, other wifi signals you come into contact with, device identification, and possibly more.

Turning your home into a smart home with smart switches and outlets can be a daunting task.  We needed to replace a light switch that controlled some outdoor lines and this became our place to start.  Overall it was a good experience, but here are a few things that you shoudl considerThe comes complete with a face plate and wiring screws to hold the wires together.  Instructions are NOT in the package, you get them by downloading their app (the KASA App) and following the instructions. The instructions are not particularly helpful, basically telling you to match the wire colors from the old switch with the new one.  So limited value add there.

I've owned 3 of these for about 1 year now and they sometimes will not communicate with my router and I cannot find out why . Our router works just fine with other devices just not this brand . For example today one unit decided to stop working then all 3 stopped and now they show just "local" connection only which makes them worthless . I've attempted resetting them well over 30 times over the last 4 hours or so and I also reset the router back to factory settings at least 20 times and it will work with everything else just not these units . I guess they have a lifespan of " X" amount of time which is god knows what . I would NOT ever buy these again  and I suggest you find another brand if you're looking for something reliable . These were a waste of time for me , these things ALWAYS seem to stop working when you can no longer return them - interesting fact .

I purchased 2 of these smart switches months ago and wasn't impressed.  I never posted a review.They only seemed to work via Alexa maybe 5-10% of the time, but worked flawlessly with the Kasa app. I reached out to Kasa and they said it was likely an issue on Amazon's end, since the switches were responding via the app, whether on wifi or 4G.

Turned out not as bad as I expected to install. One reviewer said it wouldn't fit in standard size face plate. As you can see in picture I have a 3 switch plate and it fit fine. I can push puttons under smart switch if needed. I did have to locate white ground to hook up but was prepared for this. Getting to work with alexa messed me up with one step . First have to download Kasa app and set it up on there. Then I tried to get Alexa to recognize it where it wouldn't but then I remembered that you have to give the alexa app permission to link to Kasa app in smart home, once I did this Alexa found the switch and it works great. Now since switch is behind door which I used to have to reach behind to get to switch all I have to do is say "Alexa turn on the Den Light" and presto the light goes on.

I do not do many reviews, as a mater of fact I think I have only done 2 or 3. I feel the HS200 switch deserves a review. The switch worked perfectly fine for about 2 months and suddenly stopped working. For some reason, it looked like it was stuck in setup mode. I contacted support on Monday and got a case number 445172 on Tuesday. The first response was to try everything that I stated I did again and let them know the results. Their next response was to send them screen shots of the errors I was getting. I did that and the next day I got a response that the product was defective and to register the switch on their website, so they could give me an RMA to return the switch. I tried to register the switch, and the website could not find the serial number and to contact the support team. The next response I got was they needed a copy of the Amazon invoice. It is now Friday, and I got an email form the person working on my problem that he or she is going on holiday and will not return for a week. If I need the switched replaced I need for them to return or resubmit my request. I guess is if I resubmit the request nothing will get done until next week. Plus, I sure the new switch would be ship standard shipping which will take another week to get here. This is not my idea of good customer support. I will not be buying TP link products again. I do have two of their lightbulbs and a timer that work just fine.

I would love to love this product. But I can't. It DOES NOT recover from a network outage. If you have to reboot your wifi (which we all are suppose to do at least 1 time per month)  it will not work anymore. You have to factory reset it and then go through the programming all again, then it is fine. Not that it is hard, just super annoying. Sucks I have 5 of these before I realized this major flaw. None of my other brands have this flaw. Live and learn.

I installed some ceiling fans and put this switch in to control it.  I had to get an electrician out because the existing switch did not have a neutral wire.  This is a requirement for this switch which, to their credit, is clearly stated in the Amazon listing.  One other thing to note is that my electrician asked if it was motor rated, I had to do some digging on Kasa's site but did find that it was designed with ceiling fans in mind so, while not explicitly stating that it is motor rated, it is designed for ceiling fans.  I specifically purchased a simple switch (on/off with no dimming) because you should get a controller specifically designed for ceiling fans if you want to be able to adjust the fan speed.  But if all you want to do is turn a ceiling fan off and on, and control the speed on the fan itself, then this is a good choice.I have several of Kasa's smart plugs and the integration with Alexa, and Google Home is great.  Even if you don't use or have that currently the Kasa app is well done and makes it easy to set up and run devices.

I wanted a timer for my backyard lights, I had the led with the light detection but some times they went on when still sun. I was thinking on a normal timer but its around 16 us the cheaper and these smart lights are 19. So..PRO

I purchased this same item on December 3, 2017. It quit working early January 2020. I ordered another of the same. I installed it and went to their site after looking at new enclosed paperwork. It hinted the first might be covered by warranty. It stated “ 2-3 years “ which is a bit indecisive for a warranty. I just wanted another of same HS 200 and would be willing to ship it back to the manufacturer for replacement to add to a different room. BTW original would not reset. I began chat with rep. and rep was very not savvy about dealing with this item and warranty issues. Over the next frustrating episode she went for advice several times to an associate. I texted “2-3 years” is confusing & am I covered if I am be willing to ship back faulty unit at my expense. She texted “what country are you in? I responded USA and she texted 3 years is only for a United Kingdom. I bought Kasa camera, 2 light switches and wall plug. December 3-January 20= 2 years and 17 days == terrible customer service considering my additional purchases they could verify on Amazon. 17 days out of warranty and the item went beyond a reset. My problem is why did I purchase the same item before I chatted the “tough luck bozo” company rep. text person Maybe I ordering in U.K. would have resolved my situation. TP rules !

The physical install of the switch was quick and simple. Took me about 30 minutes.  Could have probably changed it out quicker. However, the switch went into a double gang box that is being shared with an outlet. They share the same power source coming into the box and then there is a additional line going out to supply power to other outlets. Plus the line that leads to lights in the ceiling from the switch. So  I spent some extra time inspecting the wires so I knew what went were in the box. After that, I had it changed out in about 10-15 minutes.Software setup was quick and simple. I used the Kasa app on my phone. With in a 3-4 minutes the switch was on my network , updated and functioning. I just gotta create a new room and in my Google home app and I'll be set.

Bought this, and was super excited, my house is from the 50's in NH and doesn't have grounded wire in the entire house. All we have is the Hot (Black) and Neutral/Cold (White). Went to set this puppy up and just kept getting a clicking noise / light would turn on and off / and the wifi button would glow yellow. I capped off the grounded green wire, as I thought this wasn't an issue. Tried this on 4 different outlets because I thought maybe I was doing something wrong (really didn't think so this isn't rocket science). Nothing. I tried searching TP's support center and nothing regarding this, nothing on the details page... except for "NEED NEUTRAL WIRE" ... which it seems that's what they mean by GROUND. I'm sure this thing works great on grounded units. Call me salty, but I'm giving a 1 star for everything I had to go through for this, with 0 help or explanation from TP. Unless anything changes, or they change the descriptions.. I'll keep it at that.

Everything worked flawlessly until I tightened the bottom screw into the electrical light switch box.  Once sufficiently tightened, the switch turns off!  I can reproduce similar behavior by applying pressure to the switch's bottom tab with my hand.  There is something clearly wrong with my switch as it can't sufficiently handle pressure from the bottom mounting screw.  My best guess, this pressure is somehow triggering the reset/restart buttons which are located on the button of the switch.Phone support wasn't available on a Monday at 2pm EST so I spent more than 90 minutes on chat with customer support.  It was a truly horrendous experience.  Customer support blamed me for everything, took minutes to respond to simple questions and didn't spellcheck a damn thing.  I've been in IT for over a decade and have installed dozens of electrical switches throughout my life but yeah....I'm the problem.

For the money, this switch is a fantastic option to get a smart switch with Alexa integration. I have give it only 4 stars because of a few installation setbacks that were a slight annoyance. I wanted to test it out before putting it in my clients homes.During installation, I was putting this in a 4 gang box on a single pole switch circuit. the other switches in the box were 3 way switches, so there were more than a few wires in the box.

STOP!  Before you buy this switch make absolutely sure the place you want to install it has a NEUTRAL wire.  This does not mean a "white" wire.  You will often find in older homes, your switch can have just 3 wires, load, live and ground. This will often be black, white, and green.When you take the HS200 out of the box you will see it has FOUR wires: 2 black, 1 white, 1 green.  The 2 black wires act as live and load, and while interchangeable on the switch, you CANNOT connect both blacks from the switch to the single black wire in your box.  No matter what anyone tells you, please DO NOT try to override this configuration by wiring your TP-Link neutral (white) to a green ground wire.

Installed this switch at the far corner of my house to control some exterior lighting.  Worked okay initially, but over the past year, it has fallen off the home network time and time again -- sometimes after a power failure, but sometimes with no apparent cause.  In all these cases, the switch never finds its way back onto the network, and that means I have to do a manual reset on the switch, which is not in a convenient location.  In my view, the ability to recover from network disconnection is more important than any feature for a wifi device -- and the Kasa disappoints.  It's worth noting that I have another wifi switch (Meross) right below this Kasa switch, and the Meross manages to stay online when the Kasa fails.  Caveat emptor.

Installing this took some doing, and some patience in the process! TP-Link's tech support, though, was excellent, and helped me through it, and now we LOVE being able to tell Alexa to turn off our lights when we go to bed. Even better, our living room light switch (this switch) is not by the front door, so if we wanted to turn on the living room light when arriving home at night, we previously had to walk most of the way through to the other side before we could turn on the light, sometimes tracking with us whatever happened to have come out of the cat that day. (Our cat has some issues.) Now, we open the door, tell Alexa to turn on the light, and we SEE where we're stepping (and what we're stepping ON or IN)!And my wife thought it wouldn't be great to be married to a nerd! This is great stuff!!! :-)

I have now more 3 of these switches installed, in addition to a TPLINK light bulb and TPLINK Wall Plug. They are stylish and it's even cooler with the halo sign when they were off.Installation is bit of hassle since it requires the neutral line which might not be immediately available in some older units (and please don't try to connect the neutral to ground, it's wrong.). If you don't know what I am talking about, I will suggest you to hire a certified electrician.

TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Light Switch, No Hub Required, Single Pole, Requires Neutral Wire, Works with Alexa and Google Assistant (HS200)I bought 5 of these items after a lot of research but found that they were not compatible with the 3 way switches that I wanted Alexa to work with.

Love these switches, along with the TPLink Plug we have, however where is the IFTTT support? Easy to setup via the app, limited on how to wire it up, but I think thats mainly my houses wiring, but will most likely be buying more if and when they get on the IFTTT train (I don't understand how this isn't a standard option for any home automation IOT device.) My ideal scenario will be, when my cell phone is near, turn on the lights via geofencing, or when I set my nest thermostat, turn off my lights, or when I turn on my alexa party music, turn down the lights (with bulbs). Will be waiting for the integration and then hopefully start buying their light bulbs too.

I am slowly working through creating a smart lighting system, and settled on the Kasa smart switches because they work just like regular light switches so an older person in the house does not have to relearn how to turn on new light switches.  I use the Kasa App on my phone, connect the switches to Google Home, and my spouse has full access to the smart switches and outlets in Google Home. So easy!Installation for two of the switches took a total of 15 minutes, and that included finding the right breakers to turn off the power. Installation was so easy, and the Kasa app was easy to use. I now have an outside smart outlet and switches inside the house. I plan on adding additional smart switches. It makes more sense to buy switches instead of bulbs. Bulbs will wear out, can be broken, etc, but a switch is stable in the wall for much longer.

Super wish I would have discovered that TP doesn't have a way to turn off the "dark mode" circle light before I installed it. Nothing like feeling good about nailing installation instantly turning into regrets when you shut off all the lights and this switch is glowing back at you. Absolutely do NOT recommend in a bedroom if you want darkness. Why can't I turn it off?? I even tried to just cover the circle, but the light leaks from the slits in the sides! This is a feature on the Leviton brand, but despite YEARS of requests for it, TP has yet to address this feature. That said installation was easy (even watched their video) and this was my first time installing a switch of any kind. Maybe 15 minutes since I had to watch the video. Flipped on the power and it was up and ready to pair. App setup worked and I was up and running. Alexa knew about it within a few minutes and I was set. Again, the only reason I'm not happy at this point is not being able to turn off the dark mode light which lots of others have requested for years and TP has yet to address. I'll keep this brand in rooms where people won't be sleeping. And side-note - my box was clearly opened despite buying "new" but that was on the seller so I'm not dinging the product.

I was concerned about whether this switch would fit in the 3-gang box where we needed it. As you can see from the photo, the other two positions were filled with dimmer switches. There is a lot of wire coming into the box, I didn't count, but at least 3-4 wires for each switch. Our house is new enough not to have conduit, so they ran pre-bundled cables of wire. The hardest part was bending the wires correctly to get everything back into position in the box. Since the wires for the house are solid core, they do not bend the easiest unless you get it "started" in the right direction.In the end, everything went into the box correctly and the standard switch plate fit perfectly. It was a breeze to install on the network and works great! Be sure to download the KASA app. There are instructions on it to walk you through  the physical and network installation.

If you have any knowledge of basic home electrical wiring, you definitely won't have a problem with installing this light switch. As the title of the product reads, it does need a neutral wire in order to be fully connected with the internet and always on.It comes with a snap-on faceplate (which seems to be a little larger than a normal faceplate), and 4 wire nuts to connect existing wires to the switch. The switch works with most existing gang plates as well, and I didn't need to use the faceplate included in the box. Once installed, the switch is very simple to connect to WiFi using the TP-Link Kasa app, and if you've already connected the Kasa app with Alexa, it'll get automatically detected.

16 months ago I bought a different brand smart switch for my outside lamp post. I programmed it to turn on around sunset and turn off at 10:20 p.m.  It worked fine at first but a few months after getting it, it started turning on at varying times 30-45 minutes earlier than it was set for but it always turned the light off at the correct time. I thought it was an app problem but was never able to resolve the issue.  So I finally decided to get the Kasa switch and I love it. So far, it turns on when it is supposed to and off when it is supposed to with no glitches.  The other feature I REALLY like is that it has an option (via the Kasa app) for "sunset" and "sunrise" and you can adjust the number of minutes in relation to, say, sunset.  I have it set to turn on at sunset + 20 minutes and it dependably does just that on a daily basis.  The app is very user friendly for setting schedules and I had no problem getting the switch to connect with my home wifi - your wireless router needs to be broadcasting a 2.4 ghz signal.  If you are looking for a dependable smart switch at a reasonable price, I highly recommend the Kasa HS200.

I was in the market for some "smart" light switches to automatically turn on lights near my front door and garage at a certain time every night.  This would help with safety in my neighborhood since there's a lot of crime, and criminals tend to lurk in the dark shadows.  After looking through Amazon, I decided to go with the Kasa Smart Wi-Fi Light Switch by TP-Link since it was the #1 bestseller, and I've never bought any other smart light switches before.  Each one came out to $30.99 (down from a $51.07 listing price).When they arrived, I saw they had 4 wires per switch that needed to connect properly.  I am not an electrican, and I would consider myself a complete noob when it comes to this type of handyman work.  If you're scared of installing it yourself, just know; if I could do it, you could definitely do it!  These switches also come with a face plate, but it only is good for one switch.  I couldn't use it since I wanted to install this particular light switch alongside a few others.  I had to use the old face plates.
the 89% of us who aren't in the iPhone cargo-cult will be incensed.This is the worse of all the smart systems to install and make work.

I've been using this switch to control a flood light at my mom's home. She comes home from church on Sunday and Wednesday nights in the dark, and this gives her a way of turning on a light from her car (via the Kasa app). I plan on setting up a couple more outside light on this type of switch such a second flood light and the deck lights. This way she can turn everything on at once if she needs to. I also have some lamps on the TP-Link outlet. This is convenient for her, not having to come into a dark house or try to turn lamps on/off with her hands full.I chose switches/outlets over smart bulbs for a couple of reasons. First, smart bulbs can be an expensive outlay the first time, and therefore to replace when they go out. Second, the outlets can be moved around as needed meaning they can be used for things other than lamps.

Smart wall switch installs require good handyman skills. They are large compared to most switches and this means careful rearrangement of existing wiring in your switch box may be needed. This can be difficult since house wiring is stiff and it's tricky ( at first) to get the wiring in the exact right place to accommodate the large size of the switch. As stated you MUST have a neutral wire ( white) for this switch to operate.Since many "handy people" ignore the electric code I cannot emphasize enough that the safest way to deal with installation is to shut off your main breaker. My husband nearly learned this the hard way when he found a live wire served by a SECOND breaker box in a common box that actually was serving three branch circuits, two with reversed color codes! A contact voltage tester is a must if for some reason you cannot shut down the main breaker. If you plan carefully the power should be back on within 15 minutes max.

I installed this to control the lights on the front porch, so when we come home at night, we can turn on the lights from our phones, before leaving the car.Once installed, setup was easy, as I already had the Kasa app for wall plugs, and the Kasa app was already linked to Alexa and Google Home. After a refresh of connections, I could control the switch from my Echo Dot, Google Home, and Android phone.

When this works, it works really well - lights turn on/off instantaneously via app or Alexa.  Problem is, 50% of the time Alexa won't be able to turn it on, and will say "TP Link is not responding."  Often as well, when I access it via the Kasa app the Remote Access toggle is set to Disable to some reason - when I restart the app it becomes available.  Looks like from reviews that I'm not the only one experiencing this.  I'm going to try the Leviton and Wemo switches next, this is going back to Amazon.

Great switch and probably one of the cheapest options for integrating with Samsung Smartthings. I have searched for a long time for anything that would be good quality and would integrate with Smartthings hub, not through a third party like IFTTT, but direct integration. Although this one still requires internet connection to be controlled by the hub, it's still a much better option than having another middleman company in between to make them work with each other.I think this switch is my answer to the long searching. It took me less than 20 minutes to install it and get everything running even though it was my first time doing one of these. Kasa app provided very simple to understand and detailed instructions for the installation. Wifi connected quick and ran through firmware update, after that it was up and running. So far it has been couple of weeks and it's a solid device. I've added some rules in the hub to flip the lights on and off during certain times of day and when certain things happen in the house, so far no glitches at all. I've also seen that some other smart switches have a hard time reconnecting to WiFi after loss of power or loss of wifi signal. Throughout last couple of weeks for completely unrelated reasons I've had to shut off breakers that supply power to this switch to do some electrical work, and I've had to reboot the router several times as well. This switch reconnected within seconds and was up and running. As far as the app goes, although I don't use it much and do everything through the hub, I thought it was fairly comprehensive and allowed to set up some scenes, timers, schedules and lots more. About the only thing that I would add to the app is under settings, device info - would be nice to have the IP address as well, not just a mac address of the switch.
I. Pros1.  Works natively with SmartThings, IFFTT, Google, Amazon

I bought this to replace a failing timer switch for our porch lights, which was programmed to go on at dusk and off at midnight each day. What it didn't solve was the problem of coming home to a darkened porch if we came home after midnight. I ordered the Kasa Switch to solve that problem.Installation took less than 5 minutes, with the only minor issue being that no electrical hookup instructions were included in the packaging. There was a handy graphic on the side of the switch naming the wires and, fortunately, all 4 of the wires were the same colors as my existing wiring, so it was pretty simple. Despite it being an easy task (for me), the lack of any instructions might be intimidating to those with no experience in these type of things.

I really do like the TP-Link products. Easy to install, configure and manage.I wanted to stay with the same manufacturer, throughout the smart home plug and switch offerings, to be able to manage them all from one app rather than multiple apps for multiple devices (locally or remotely).

I have about 25 zwave devices around the house and use SmartThings as the main hub. Lately a few of my GoControl/Linear switches have hone bad. I would recommend you stay away from them but they don’t seem to be available any more.  I also have GE zwave but they’re pricey and the type I want isn’t currently available either. I’m not a Zigbee fan and if you read up on either technology some sources are indicating they may be on their way out. Not sure I agree but one thing I haven’t done yet is to buy a WiFi device. So when I saw this Kasa WiFi switch for about half the cost of a zwave I had to give it a try.Now I already have about 100 IP addresses used up in my local network, and I don’t really want to use up 100 more, but this switch has so far been great for this price point.

So, I have been installing several different Kasa devices. The latest was the hs200 Smart Switch and I was displeased when trying to set up Wi-Fi it said this device had been previously configured. It look new but I did notice the seal on the box was not sealed. The wires did that look like they were used so I'm not sure what happened here I feel like it's a refurb without being notified it was a refurb. However since I had already gone through the trouble of getting it installed I reset it and it seems to be working. This hasn't happened before but I did want to call it out so if you get something that looks like it may have been open to you might want to inspect it more carefully before you go through the trouble of installing it. Also when I look up instructions for installing the switch it said to use labels to label the wiring in the wall however there were no labels in the package it was literally just the switch a faceplate and some wire nuts. So if these things were missing then definitely this was a used product and I am even more unhappy. But again this hasn't happened before so maybe this is an outlier event.

In the past 2 years I've installed about a dozen of these plus some dimmers, 3-way switches and another dozen of smart plugs of the same brand to control my lights, fans, bathroom heaters and media devices. They all integrate nicely with both Alexa and Google Assistant, and are IMHO the best choice if one doesn't have any Apple/Homekit dependencies. The requirement of an existing neutral wire is normal and similar to other products in this price range (and most higher priced products). I have tried others for different reasons, but unless I need something special (like 2 or 3 switches in one box) these became my go-to.Additionally to my regular lights, which are mainly recessed sealing lights and regular fixtures, all equipped with LED bulbs, I use (for now at least) only 2 Kasa Wi-Fi bulbs and 2 Ikea TradFi accent lights. So I mainly use the Kasa app if I need to set timers or schedules, for instance for an outside light or seasonal decoration lights etc.
This is a great high quality smart switch. Almost all of my single pole switches at home are these Kasa Smart Light Switches.Pros:

Purchased 3 of these at the same time.  I’d previously been using the Leviton smart switches, but these are significantly cheaper. Long story short, I should have spent the extra money and bought Leviton. Only one of the three hS200s stay connected to WiFi for more than a day or so.  Then I have to get the kasa app and reprogram them from scratch again. One of two failure modes: solid red WiFi light (where it’s dead until you hit the reset button), secondly, they occasionally blink green/orange (which is also what happens when you hit the reset button), and require being re set up with the Kasa app.A few things about my network before anyone tries to blame that.  I have 3 SSIDs overlaid on 3 UniFi AC Pro APs in different locations around the house. The worst RSSI any of these devices sees is -58dBm (as measured by the WLC).  It’s not a wireless issue. I suspect it could be related to the device having crappy firmware that gets confused when it sees multiple APs broadcasting the same SSID. In their AP it shows three of the same SSID...  Yet somehow Leviton and my other 60 or so IoT devices work just fine.

Kasa is a good product. I've installed over 20 switches in my home and they are very easy to install and integrate into WIFI. I have a couple of these switches that control ceiling fans and they work quite well. The problem with the overall product line is that you are limited to only 3 smart actions. Therefore, you have all these smart devices but are extremely limited in how you can use them. That causes you to constantly be reaching for your mobile to turn on or off lighting scenes or other devices. It's truly puzzling and frustrating.

A few months ago I upgraded my pool light to a color-changing LED bulb. You have to power-cycle the bulb in order to change the color schemes - that part is a pain because I have walk over to the pool panel and flip the switch up to 10 times. Now I have replaced the simple AC switch in the panel with this TP-Link switch and the process is now effortless. I can either switch the light on/off via the Kasa app on my phone or tell Alexa to turn the bulb on or off. The install was super easy: attached the white wire to the neutral wires in the panel, the two black go to the LED bulb (source & load), and green to ground. Then find the TP-Link network on my phone to setup the switch, let the Alexa app know about the device, and you are done. NOTE: This switch requires the 2.4GHz network signal from your router. I had disabled mine to prevent interference with Bluetooth. I had to re-enable it for this switch. Not the end of the world but something to keep in mind.Update: I discovered that the TP-Link switch only works reliably when the panel door is open. Th metal panel is apparently working as a Faraday cage and the TP-Link wireless signal is not not getting through with he door closed. I will have to mount the switch in a plastic enclosure outside of the panel.

This review is for the TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Light Switch.  I installed it in an existing light switch after trial & error, and I finally figured it out.  The setup/connection was immediate with both Kasa & Alexa - it was recognized immediately.  It has only been 1 day, and so far so good; I will update if that changes.  HOWEVER, know that this will ONLY work in a switch with a "neutral line", which in my outlet was 2 white lines shoved way in the back that you don't use with a normal switch installed AND neutral lines are NOT in every switch in your house.  I believe, or at least in my case, it was ONLY in switches that are installed in the perimeter/outside walls of the house (built in 1950).  In other words, the main light switches in your bedrooms are normally placed in interior walls, and you won't find a neutral line in there, so it will NOT work. I also read that one way to determine if your existing light switch has a neutral line is to look and see if there is an outlet for plugging in on the same wall below it.  I took off/apart a few switches only to find they didn't have a common line available, only to read up later on how to best determine if there is a neutral line without taking your existing light switch off/out.  I ordered 3 of these, and so far, I've found two switches in places I needed them that I was able to replace with this TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Light Switch.  Also, I have wifi bulbs throughout most of the house and they are the easy answer BUT not all fixtures use bulbs that are on the market yet.  In summary, available light switches that have a neutral line (in older homes) are on the perimeter walls of your house and in most cases have a plug/outlet beneath it or close by  in the wall.  I read, but cannot confirm, that newer homes (built after 1970) mostly have a common line in ALL switch boxes.

Wasted hour trying to install EXACTLY following the wiring instructions - I bought 2 but gave up on the first one.  I was able to join to my home wireless ok.  The Kasa app found it ok, gave it a name ok. I tried to turn the lights on but they just flickered once and would not stay on.  The switch didn't work in manual either which should have been the only warning I needed.  Repeated from factory reset 3 times before calling it quits.  I processed a refund and would not recommend.  I live in a new house with excellent wiring so that was not the issue.  Just defective I guess.  Thought about calling help desk but (1) didn't want to invest any more time, and (2) wasn't in the mood to fiddle with it until they agreed it was defective

I bought two of these light switches from Amazon. I also bought two WeMo light switches from Lowes. There's basically no difference in setup, besides the fact that the tp-link light switches do not have videos with installation. You can watch the WeMo videos for help with installation. I did not receive anything free or discounted. I bought both switches with my hard-earned money. There is no difference in functionality. They both work well with Alexa. Cosmetically speaking, the WeMo light switch has a black circle that illuminates green when the light is off, and the tp-link switch simply in luminates white when the light is off and it does not illuminate when the light is on. If I had a slight preference, I prefer the tp-link switch because the illumination serves to show the switch when the room is dark. It is less expensive also. I would make a suggestion to anyone who has no Alexa compatible light switches. Buy all of them from the same brand, as WeMo and tp-link use different applications. So, if I want to use my phone or tablet to use the devices, I have to go into two separate applications. Both applications  offer the same  set up  and allow you  to change the name  of your devices.  They also allow  you to take pictures of the room to easily identify where the switches are located. My only regret  is that I wish they were all the same.  It should be noted that I used to coupon at Lowe's for the WeMo switches and the coupon May the price the same ask the tp-link switches. I should have gotten them all the same. I also bought Alexa compatible plugs that operate lamps. I use the tuya smart application to operate my lamps. Therefore, this is yet another application, and I have to operate three different applications to control lighting in my home. Alexa can eliminate having to use multiple applications. If you are away from home and want to turn lights on and off, this is when different applications become a pain. Everything is working well and I love it. Another thing to know is that if you name your devices similar names, Alexa will keep giving you error messages. Do not use names like my lamp or my light, unless you have only one lamp or light. If you name the more specifically, you will not have the error messages that will call Alexa to state, " I found multiple devices in your account with that name." And it took me forever to figure out what the problem.  I had names like my bedroom light, guest bedroom light, my lamp, and guest bedroom lamp. I simply removed the word "my." I changed it  "master bedroom." It works perfectly but there alot more syllables for Alexa to understand. I found this very frustrating but this was not a problem with any of the devices. It was an Alexa problem.

I bought  pool and spa LED lights for our pool,each did not draw over 40 watts.The double ,single gang box double switch was to be replaced with this smart switch so we could set this up on Google assistant.This switch did not work. It did not turn on the lights as asked by Kasa help,and was obvious this was a troubleshooting step. It is simple to install and any body who has installed a ceiling fan with a light would have no problem installing this.I finally reinstalled the 30 year old mechanical switch and it worked just fine.I did see a review that this did not work on LED lights.I dismissed it as sour grapes....Not the case,it does not work on LED s. Kasa tech will leave you hanging for an hour and dismiss that hour with a one word negative answer.They do not work with you and are 10 minutes between answering a question in the Que.Returned item,but wouldnt mind an answer from Kasa.I would still like to go forward and tell Google Home to turn on the pool lights!!!!!

I was enthusiastic about getting some of these switches into my house. I now have 7 installed. Setup is easy using the Kasa app and then discovering the devices with Alexa. But operation of these devices has been less than stellar and I'm not sure the convenience of being able to turn a light on or off in another part of the house is worth the inconvenience of having to constantly reset one or more of these devices. The usual problem I see is "local only" in the Kasa app. Usually setting up the device again solves the problem but it usually interrupts what I am doing. The worst event was this past Saturday when 6 of the 7 switches stopped working with Alexa and the Kasa app indicated "local only". On this occasion resetting the switch didn't fix the problem. The switches would immediately go back to "local only". In desperation I was ready to restore to factory settings and start over. I did find a FAQ on the TP-Link website that more thoroughly explained operation, function of the buttons and what you should expect when pushing one of the buttons. Short story is that I pushed the "restart" button on the switch and the switches were back in operation, all but one that is. The remaining switch required one more reset after going through the restart procedure. My concern is how could this number of devices go out of service at the same time. Did TP-Link try to do an update and it failed? That particular incident took 90 minutes to sort out. The documentation that accompanies this device is lacking and there is really no information at all if your device starts acting up.

Why I bought it:I bought this product as part of my kitchen remodel.  It's currently connected to my sink light.  This switch is one of the most affordable ones on the market.  I wish I would have paid the extra $4 to make it dimmable, but I was already over budget on my project and didn't think I'd care for a dimmable sink light.

These smart switches look well designed so I purchased three for my different rooms. Installation was easy and well though-out. Just follow the instructions on your phone and that's it. Out of my three switches one seems to have a mechanical defect. When clicking it makes a noisy click rather than the soft click so instead of returning the switch to Amazon as I'm still within 30 days I contacted Tp-link's tech support to see if they could replace it as part of my discovery of their customer service. Email response time was reasonable with one-day delay but it was exhausting. They asked me to try one thing after another to the point I decided to cut the loss, cancelled my RMA request, and returned the faulty switch to Amazon. This is one negative aspect in buying from a Chinese vendor like Foscam or Tp-Link. Their employees work very hard to make sure the anything replaced under warranty has exhausted ALL other options. Even though I like Tp-link's smart switches they cost 25-50% more than their competitors so I expect much better service than the cheaper vendors when paying this much. On the surface their two-year warranty seems generous but it's no better than another vendor with six-month warranty if I have to pull my hair out trying to get the broken product replaced. I'll be looking at switches from other vendors instead.

Sadly, I now have a number of smart plugs and switches from a number of different companies and all work well EXCEPT the TP-Link ones.  My Echo Plus is constantly telling me that "TP-Link is not responding" when plugs and switches from other companies seem to be doing fine.  Sometimes the Echo will say that the "TP-Link is not responding" but then the light or switch does respond about 10 seconds later.  I don't know why TP-Link's devices have to be closer to the router than the other devices to work and even then don't always respond.  It's like they need a first non-responsive signal to start listening and then on the next request maybe they'll respond.

Nice product. Good packaging. Comes with (difficult to remove) face-plate and gaskets. Instructions are very minimal, but refer you to the Kasa application for installation and setup. This works ok, but they could have given a brief print instruction, in my opinion. Installed in place of old timer switch which failed.  My switch box has a neutral so power was not any issue for me. Wire up the two blacks to the power and the light feed, wire the ground to the box ground, wire the neutral to the neutral. It powers up in already in setup mode and is ready to talk with the Kasa ap, which finds it even before it is logged to the local network. (Bluetooth? not sure how, and it does not say). Provide it the password to selected local WiFi and it is ready to go. Kasa allows you to name it  and set time schedules, including on at sunset, as well as control it directly. It also has a local button to act like a switch without Kasa. Linking with Alexa app also very intuitive. Alexa asks for your Kasa password, then allows you to find the device on the local network. Voice control very smooth with Alexa also. "Alexa turn on Driveway" .. So far I have three of these hubless TpLink devices. All work well, so far. durability, yet to be determined.

I was hesitant to buy this because these sort of products, when they're new in a category, tend to have buggy software or just don't work well but it had really great reviews on both Amazon and Costco ... so I bought two to test.First - installation.  I'm no electrician, but it was pretty easy.  It comes with a very nice face plate that hides all screws so it actually looks better than my old programmable switches - it's a nice simply and clean look.  The wires didn't match the colors in my wall so I had to Google that and find the alternative colors that are used and once I figured that out, everything went well.  (It would be helpful if they had included a wire color guide insert, but it's simple enough to find on Google.)

In the past I have purchased and installed several Leviton Decora Smart switches. So my opinion here is based largely on comparison to that brand.Pros: MUCH better price. Install of the switch is exactly as expected. Configuring the app is similar to what I have come to expect for other Alexa enabled devices.

The first one I bought worked/works fine. The last two failed right out of the box. One went into  reset mode permanently flashing and clicking and the second one leaked power. I.E. the LED it was connected to glowed dimly when off and never went to full brightness when turned on so it never turned completely off and never turned completely on.I may have to replace the one that is working with a different brand so I don't have different switches from different people with different skills to use. Not a reliable product.

I gave the versatility 5 stars because there is a lighted wifi symbol on the switch that tells me if the wifi in my house is connected. The switch was easy to install, I used it on a double switch outlet, it fit well into the box housing with the regular switch and the face plate fit like a glove. Kasa App is very easy to  open, It works with my alexa, and I can also control it on my alexa app.Update: It worked amazingly until that firmware update, now the light switch itself still works but the kasa app will no longer connect to my switch. Chatroomed with tech support twice,  no resolution. Although I will buy again if they fix this firmware issue

I have two complaints about this product.  One it is large. My switch box was stuffed with wires and it wasn't easy to get this packed into the switch box. The size may be state of the art, as this is the only smart switch I have ever put in. They all might be this size and I simply do not know if there are smaller ones.My second complaint is the screwless  plastic cover plate is cheap, difficult to snap on and likely to break. Well the switch is inexpensive and all these shortcomings are minor given the price of the switch.  I would recommend the product  and just say if it will not fit in the switch box you intended for it, you can probably find another in your house where you can use it.  You will need a neutral and a ground is recommended.  It was quick and easy to hook up to  my network and integrate with my iPhone and Echo network. The only reason I am taking away a star is because of that cover plate. I just think they could have done a better job on that. Still a great product for the price.

We started with the Philips Hue bulbs but quickly discovered that using conventional/led bulbs with Smart light switches is definitely the way to go. Here's why: if you have a conventional light switch and turn it off, your fancy smart bulb is useless.  Most homeowners are probably used to walking into a room and flipping a switch. That is a very hard habit to break. Additionally, smart bulbs require you to either use your phone or voice to turn them on and off... We'd find ourselves standing there for 5-10 seconds working through phone apps or talking to Alexa to get the lights on or off.  No thanks!With the switch, you can talk to Alexa when it's convenient, you can 'flip the switch' when you walk in or out, or schedule lights on/off at will... and the wife is MUCH happier!

I like the scheduling capability, and I like the sleek look of the switch. I also like that it's completely contained in a plastic housing, with the wires coming out of it. Another similar switch I looked at had exposed screws on the bottom of the switch you had to screw the home wiring to. Not cool. This one uses wire nuts and is very shielded.There are a few things I don't like about it. Like why does the little light on the switch come on when the device is switched off? It would make more sense to me to have the light come on when the device is on, but it's not a big deal.

Installation took a bit longer than it could have because this unit is thick and deep, so I needed to grind down some screws in the wall because this needed every available bit of space. It still sticks out a few millimetres from the wall. As it says, check for neutral wires (in our house, they were installed but toward the back of the gang, not in use).This switch looks like a standard rocker, but the bottom is all you press for on/off. There is a small illuminated circle on the switch when the lights are off to help find the switch in the dark and to show the status.

I started installing a few switches and my wife and daughter thought “dad is just being techie about this”. They almost wanted nothing to do with the switches. Then i showed them how easy it is to control the lights and ceiling fan. Now when my wife walks into the kitchen, even if her hands are not full she will speak to have the lights turn on or off without her having to touch the switch. Both wife and daughter think i need to install lots more of these switches. I love how easy the are to install and setup. I have several routines programed for automation (since they integrate seamlessly with the Amazon and Google products) so we never come home after dark to a dark house, porch and coach lights on, etc. Even if someone comes to the door after we go to bed, the porch light will automatically turn on for 20 minutes. I can’t say enough about the products. Any chance i get i show off my geekyness explaining to others my setup and how great the products are. Thanks for a great product

I didn't want to have another smart home app on my phone but the Kasa app is required.  It took me a while to find the remote control switch that makes this switch visible to Amazon devices.  Once that is set, Alexa app can see it (Google Home can not) and you can issue voice commands but I have yet to be able to figure out how to include it in an Alexa routine.  Since this switch is to control my outdoor house lights I wanted to add it to my Alexa sunset and sunrise routines.  Alexa allows plus/minus sunset/sunrise times.  The Kasa app allows only sunset/sunrise/tod in it's scheduler.  Since I have to use the Kasa app to schedule, I can only assume that if my phone battery runs out, the routines won't fire.  I gave it 3 stars because it minimally does what I need but in these days of home automation I expected better integration with the leading vendors but this switch apparently has no comparability with Google or Samsung Smart Home and only minimally integrating with Amazon.

The reason I give the KASA Switch a 3 is:When I had trouble for the first time on one of my switches that lit my bathroom, I called KASA technical support. The switch had been working for seven months with no problems and all of a sudden stopped working. I called KASA support and the technician there told me that I had to get an electrician to come out and determine if the switch was wired correctly. I told him it would cost $200 to get electrician to come out and check a switch that was already working correctly. Originally I paid only $39 for the cost of switch and why would I want to pay $200 to electrician to take two screws out and see that the switch was a sealed unit and there was nothing he could test anyway. I really did not like the technical support that I got from KASA. It seems kind of dumb to spend $200 to check a $39 switch.

I made the jump to a "Smart Home" a little over a month ago after Alexa joined our family. After talking to some friends, doing some research and assesing my needs I settled on TP-Link because of the variety of Smart products they offered, no requirements for a Hub, the lower cost and the ability to control everything from one simple app on my Smart phone and Amazon"s Alexa.I have not been disappointed. After a very short learning curve, I surprisingly found the installation and set-up of all the TP-Link Smart devices extremely easy and intuitive. I have installed several different Smart devices including three different bulbs (LB-100, 120 & 130) depending on the area, as well as, Smart Switches (HB-200) and Smart Plugs. All of it has installed, programed and worked with few problems.

I bought this switch after finding out I could not use the Kasa switch 3 way kit which (comes with two) as a single pole switch. The switch works good, slight delay when turned on/off but to be expected. Very easy to install and app walks you through each step. When used in routines I found that you need to be careful not to turn off/on too quickly in the routine as it executes too quickly and light remains on/off, fixing my routine fixed this. So far good switch for fair price. Remember to get a switch plate to match what your setup is going to be if it's installed in a 2 gang or more. I like this switch as it toggles on/off not an actual rocker switch so pushing the switch toggles on/off. The switch is actually never in the wrong position which makes for no confusion, it's more of a "push button" which is great. The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is I just installed it recently

I was so shocked at how cheap this is compared to the WeMo switch I bought for $50 at Lowe's. Now I'm considering returning the Lowe's one and replacing it with another of this Kasa HS200 Tp-Link switch! (Full nomenclature inserted in that sentence on purpose so this shows up should someone be looking into this model on Google).Connecting to WiFi was even simpler than the WeMo model I have. Linking to my Google home for commands was easy too. The most difficult part was figuring out the menus within the "Google Home" app.

I bought my house new a couple years ago and I like to have a few lights turns on by itself at a certain time or certain weather. Because when me and my gf goes to work, then we don't want our dog to be in the darkness by himself.Most of my lights are 3 ways switch and having to install all of them with the 3 ways switch kit would be expansive.  So I learned how to kill one of the switch and just use the Kasa Smart light Switch on the other one.  Having just access to one switch does bother me and I love how I got the KASA to hook up with the weather thru IFTTT.

I have several Kasa Smart Switches and a couple of Smart Plugs in my home.  Performance- wise I have been generally satisfied with all of them.  But there are some caveats.1.  Power outages will sometimes lead to the unit unable to get back onto the network.  When this occurs - you need to set it up again as if new.  This is a pain that can be magnified if you have it tied into Alexa routines as they would be treated as new devices.

The sales information isn't clear. This item requires two distinct power/load circuits to operate, something most pre-WWI homes (and many post WWI homes) do not have. Many wall switches have simply a green (ground), neutral (white) and black (hot) wire - some don't even have the green, using the box and the shield (BX conduit) to provide the ground. The TP-Link requires two hot wires to operate. TP-Link tech support says that one is to power the switch, and one is to power the light. This information was not available until the instructions were downloaded (not in the package). Simply running both black wires from the single wire in the wall doesn't work, which is confusing, but that was the only explanation tech support would give me. Since not one single-gang switch in my house has two hot wires associated with it, I had to return what promised to be a good, workable product.

Over the past year or two, I've been slowly converting my 'dumb' home into a 'smart' one, and these switches are one of the changes I've been adding.  (Specifically, I'm using one of these in my hallway, one in my guest bedroom, one in my guest bathroom, a 3-way version in my kitchen, and a 3-way version in my entryway.)First off: once set up and running, these work and work well.  The ones in my guest bedroom, hallway, and kitchen have been installed for about six months now and work perfectly.  (I can't speak to longevity on the ones in the guest bathroom and entryway yet as I just installed those this past weekend.)

Going up to my attic which am converting to an extra room, the light switch is downstairs. I thought about the possibility of purchasing smart WiFi lights, but this was the cheaper option.My router is 2 floors down and i am still able to get signal to the switch with no issues what so ever!!!

My home is one year old.  I wanted these switches for the front eave lights, front porch lights and the outside lights around the garage.  I also did one for our front room.  I wanted them for simulated occupancy when we are gone and also for reduction in cost due to kids/spouse leaving them on all day and night.  I installed two of the switches in a three gang box, one in a three gang box and one in a single gang box.  Install went great.  They are a robust beautiful little switch.  They were so simple to get set up once installed.  The Kasa Smart app is elegant and full of features.  Overall I’m very pleased.  I’d love to see Kasa add a voltage indication feature to the app but it’s totally unnecessary.  I’m a geek for info like that.  The only problem I had was that amazon sent me a previously used switch that had been both installed and configured.  I was able to get everything to work fine but I don’t like getting used stuff when I pay for a new unused item.  You feel like someone is trying pulling a fast one on you. I would suggest that if you are considering a purchase, that you move forward with no hesitation.  If anything changes, I will update this review.

I installed the switch in our theater room and it works perfectly.  Generally, I don't like playing with electricity but installation was a breeze and incorporating the switch with Alexa was no problem.  With the room having no windows it is completely dark when you turn the lights out so it is great to have you and your guests get seated and situated then tell Alexa to turn out the lights and at the end of the movie have her turn on the lights so one doesn't trip.  Since it is a theater room, the walls are a dark plum and the ceiling is black and the carpet is dark gray.  I am seriously considering ordering some more for other rooms in the house, especially since my wife has a bad habit of leaving lights on when she leaves a room.  I have had a few months now and no issues so far.  I highly recommend .

I bought these smart switches to control lights in my home.  Most of the smart switches went to outdoor lights as it was the best option for me to have the best control of lights I needed to operated remotely.  The install is super easy and they connect to my wifi with no issues.  Every one that I have installed needed a firmware update immediately after installing but they were operational in minutes.  Pairing with Alexa app was also easy and I was turing on and off my lights using my echo dot in minutes after install.  They are a little bulky compared to normal switches so make sure you push the wires and wire nuts to the far back of the box you are installing them in or you won't fit them in on the first shot evenly.  They do need to be grounded and I had to ground them to a metal electrical box in one installation as I have some older wiring in my home along with some newer but the switches work great and wifi signal is not an issue in plastic or metal boxes.I also love that when the lights are off you see a light ring in the body of the switch.  You can instantly tell if the lights are on or off and if it is dark in the room you can easily find the switches.  They also make a satisfying click when depressed and I haven't had a single issue with all 4 of my Kasa Smart Light Switches.

I read in other 1-star reviews that it worked for a few days, then failed. Mine failed from the start.I wired it as instructed, and used Kasa app on iPhone to connect it. WiFi light actually turned green for 1-2 minutes.

I usually don't give five stars to a product, but in this case, I must.  I am so impressed about how easy it was to install and configure these switches (I bought two, installed side by side in the same wall box) and how well they work.  I installed these to control some outdoor flood lights attached to my barn/work shop that is over 100 feet away from my house.  The access point is located on the second floor of my house on the side facing the barn.  With my cell phone, I can usually pick up about 2 bars of WiFi out there.  So I wasn't sure that these switches would work with the weak signal.  But they had absolutely no problem connecting and staying connected to the access point.Being able to create programs for these switches (like on at dusk and off at dawn) as well as being able to turn them off and on with my cell from anywhere is great.  No hub needed.  No subscription required.  They just work.

Controlling three exterior lights on a photoelectric eye, but it was hard to aim it correctly.  The light from the bulb kept confusing the "eye."  So, time for a TP-Link wall switch.  Got rid of the electric eye.  I have other TP Link switches in the house which have held up for about a year with no problem.Installation struggle:

I love them with Alexa and trying to curb my wasteful habits, but the only pisser is these use a few watts themselves.  I have 8 HS110s and 5 of these and no other parasitic loads on the circuits these live on.  With the fridge,  garage freezer, and pool not cycling my house sits about 85w static, if I open the circuits where these live it goes down to about 45w, leading me to believe the 13 devices are pulling about 40w.  Just to chase my tail a little I energized the circuits where these live, saw the 85 watts again, then unplugged the 8 HS110s, and it dropped by about 25w leading me to believe the HS110s are about 3w each, and these switches are in the same neighborhood.The Kasa app is a little sluggish but it's nice seeing the power of the HS110s and setting the away mode when I'm on the road.  It works great with Alexa and I love "echo everything off" and hearing things turning off all over the house before I go to sleep.

I ordered this switch to control a light and thought it would be a fairly quick install.  When I pulled the old switch out, I noticed there were 3 black wires and no white wire connected to the switch.  My switch situation is that it is on the same run as several outlets which always have power to them.  The two black wires at the bottom of the switch were a continuation of that line while the black wire at the top was to the light.  There were 3 neutral wires (white) in the back of the box, however they were not connected to the switch.So here is what I did:

I couldn't be happier with my choice to go with TP-Link Switches.  I looked at several other options, including the Lutron which my Sister and Bro-in-law use.  Also a great option but requires a separate hub and costs significantly more.  The Kasa switch connects directly to Wi-Fi and has a great App (at least Android that I use) to walk you through set-up and use.  I have 6 of the HS200, one HS220, and one HS210 currently in my home and they have all worked as advertised.  I use them with Amazon Alexa and the integration and function has been seemless.  I started installing these about a year ago and will continue to slowly replace all my switches.  I have sunrise and sunset set-up for my outside lights, away mode integrated with my Ecobee thermostat to alternate lights during the evening when out, and my kids are delighted to tell Alexa to turn off "Billy" (my sons choice of name for his lights) and "My Light" (daughters, choice) when going to bed.A couple of notes for future buyers:

We have 12 recessed lights in our basement and replacing the switch with this wifi switch was much cheaper than replacing all of the bulbs with smart bulbs, then grouping them, and then making a routine in Alexa.  The switch is fatter in the back than a normal switch so I had to replace the metal switch box with a plastic one because the side screws were almost touching the metal and I was worried that they might arc to the box.  The switch looks like a modern flat toggle but does not toggle up and down - you just press the bottom to turn it on and the bottom to turn it off again.  There is a small circle that is lighted when the switch is off to tell you where the switch is.  The other switch in the box is a 3 way and will eventually be replaced with a TP Link 3 way.

Was really tough to install, the unit is VERY bulky and the wires are hard wired to the unit extend from the lower back of the unit. This causes issues with fitting it into the wall box because 1) This was 3-4mm deeper than my lutron dimmer 2) 3 wired hard wired to base (not sides like most switches) means more cable to stuff at the back 3) Required neutral wire (some competitor units do not need this because of the above I spent hours trimming wires, tucking them into the wall, pushing and stuffing trying to get this damn thing to fit!! Not it’s in, it’s not flush or straight it looks horrible! I don’t have the energy to remove it and return it.

I have purchased multiple switches and they all have worked exactly as advertised. All of my rear patio lights are now on a schedule, as well as being able to be turned on/off with voice via Alexa or using my app, as well as my dining room chandelier. It’s rad af and impresses everyone when they are over.Easy to install, assuming your house wasn’t built in the 20s and you have a neutral wire, which you should definitely check for before purchasing these (turn off the relevant breaker and remove the plate to see inside the junction.) Neutral wires are (usually) white and this product will NOT work without one. That said, installation is easy peasy; black live/leads to each other, neutral to neutral, ground to ground or just cap the ground if you don’t have a ground in junction.

I have installed several smart plugs to control table lamps in my home and vacation home and I wanted a solution for the front porch light in the vacation home.  Note: all the smart plugs I have tried can survive a power outage without having to be reset to function properly.  I installed this switch in a basement junction box to replace a failed electromechanical timer because the first floor switch box did not have access to the common wire in the circuit and this switch needs common, hot and ground to power itself. It installed easily and integrated perfectly with Alexa and I was able to set up a routine for it to go on and off according to sunset and sunrise times. That is an Alexa feature I really like, so you don’t have to reset the timer/switch every time there is a season change. Alexa also allows you to set a routine so it is offset by your choice of minutes before or after sunrise or sunset, so all of your switches lamps won’t turn on exactly at Sunset. If someone is staking out your house for a robbery they will notice several lights going on simultaneously.  Back to the Kasa switch:  the only issue I have with this switch is that it needs to be physically reset after a power failure. Since I installed this switch in the house I spend the least amount of time in, that means the light will not be switched until I get there, notice it is on when it should not be, and go down to the basement to reset it. It does seem to fail in the ON condition, so the light stays on all the time. Now I am considering redoing the wiring to add an outlet and plug so I can use one of the Alexa enabled smart plugs instead of this switch so that it will survive a power outage.
