If the smart plugs can all do this why can’t the smart switch do it?  Also, if your home was wired 10 or more years ago as mine were, you may not have the common wire available in any of your light switch boxes, making it impossible to wire and use this or any other type of smart switch. I recommend you check your wiring before buying one of these.

Sure there are cheaper WiFi switches out there.  I have tried them.  They are bad.  My last cheap switch was too big to even go into the electrical box.  The WiFi signal disconnects.  Total aggravation.  Don’t waste your time on them.So I decided to spend a couple bucks more for the Kasa by TP-Link.  My home is filled with TP-Link routers, modems and extenders.  So I trust their products.

After experimenting with a number of different smart switches, settled on the Kasa / TP Link and installed them throughout my home.  Physical installation is straightforward.  Note, like all of these WiFi switches, they are pretty deep and thus it's a challenge to install doubles or triples into those particular switch-boxes.  The software is adequate, and does have room for improvement (the scheduling is not intuitive in my opinion)  but unlike some competitors, it actually works and setting up the switches is relatively painless.  At this price point, I would highly recommend this product and it work great with Alexa.

I've installed 14 Kasa smart switches in my new construction home and am planning on installing another 6-10.  These are "rocker" style switches which means the switch depresses and springs back rather than toggling, I actually like that because it keeps multi gang switches looking clean (I have having some switches toggled up and others down).  There is a small illuminated circle that appears when the switch is off to make it easy to find the switch in the dark.  I use my switches with Alexa and with the Kasa app (which is excellent).  The switches are somewhat large which can make multi-gang installation a little bit of an adventure but still do-able.

I replaced all nine of my Wemo switches with these.  They are so much more easier to reconnect when the net goes down.  I had to stand in front of the Wemo switches for approx 10 minutes to get each one back up.  After 2 or 3 years of this frustration I replaced a few with this switch and after a trial period I replaced the rest of my Wemo switches with the TP-Link.  An added plus they were less than half the price I paid for Wemo.  I am giving the Wemo switches away. Would not use those again.  I don't like to give a poor review to a product, but I purchased both brands from Amazon and the application for the TP-Link is so user friendly.

I put in two of these switches in outdoor boxes to control my pool lights.  They were easy to set up on WiFi and with the Kasa app, I can set up automatic times on and off as well as control with voice via Alexa.  I really love that I can time them off the sunset rather than just time of day.  I only wish the app allowed for more time than just "sunset plus 59 minutes" . They are much deeper than the standard switches that they replaced and I had to add a box extension on both electrical boxes to allow them to fit.  So they were alot more trouble to install than i thought they would be, but since they work so great, still giving them 5 stars.
I currently have one of these switches on all four of my outdoor lights.Front Porch, Back Porch,  Side Garage,  Front Garage.

I now have several of these, some of which have been in operation for many months. These interface well with a smartphone or tablet and give complete, user-friendly programming control. I do not interface with an Alexa, just my smartphone and tablet, so I can only speak to that part. But the software allows you to group units together so that they can all be controlled with a single operation, it allows you to choose specific times and days with the timer or you can choose "sunrise" or "sunset" and it will adjust the time each day as needed.I found setup to be simple, as is programming and simple on-off operation. Finally, as I have had several for many months, I can report that I have had no malfunctions to date. I will be adding more.

I have several TP-link single-pole switches aorund my house to replace regular "decora" switches. These don't stand out, and regular people can use them without having to talk to Echo or use the app, which is good for visitors who might otherwise shut off power to smart bulbs.This one took a little longer to install because the junction box I was putting it in had two circuits running through it, and it was a tight fit.  Plus, it was a double box.  So, I went back to Amazon and bought some snap-on double gang decora plates, which fit in with the rest of my tp-link switches and look nice.  Set up is easy, and I have my switches set on a schedule, as well as using IFTTT to have certain lights turn on or off at sunset or sunrise.  I never come home to a dark house.  When it's cloudy, I just say, "Alexa, lights on in the kitchen" or something like that.  I use these switches for fixtures and my lamps all have a hue system running through them along with dimmers on the wall.  This is a good system if you live in a house where people are likely to want to turn switches on and off.

Good little switch. Learned a lot while installing it. I ended up purchasing a book to help me with wiring because I got confused by the neutrals. Here are a few tips:• Get some wire cutters and strippers because I needed to cut away about an inch of wire from each connection to get these to fit into my wall. They are about twice the depth of a normal switch.

I've installed both smart bulbs and smart switches, and the switches make more sense to me for several reasons: 1) the smart bulbs seem to disconnect from the network fairly regularly and have to be reprogrammed, which only takes a few minutes, but is annoying; 2) when using a smart switch and the bulb goes out, you don't have to buy another expensive smart bulb, you can replace it with any (read: cheap) bulb; 3) I have them hooked up to control my outdoor lights so they automatically go on and off and don't have to worry about putting an expensive smart bulb outside, or having it disconnect from the network. I would definitely recommend these smart switches for the easy install, solid app, and utility.
Good product. Easy to install - just realize you need the extra power wire (4th wire) for it to work.Pro:

I have now installed 5 Kasa smart switches and will shortly install a pair of Kasa 3 way switches. The app flawlessly leads you through the process for each type of Kasa smart device. I have seen the app evolve over the years from being very good documentation to excellent documentation. Before you purchase a switch make sure that you have access to a neutral wire (it is white) in your wall box. Not all purveyors of smart devices support strong wifi passwords (i.e., passwords with symbols) ... Kasa does. My biggest installation problem has been scant space for wiring and the switch in the wall box. Smart switches tend to be somewhat wider and deeper than the switches they replace.As a care giver I am deeply appreciative of the the additional functionality offered by smart devices. They have made my life and my wife's life much easier. The excellent devices, instructions and app from Kasa have made it possible.

I bought this to hook up with my Alexa Echo and had a little bit of trouble hooking it up. Once I called the US support line, they walked me through the troubleshooting and I got it to work pretty easily. There are a couple of steps to get it to work:1) You have to install it correctly (For me: black and red are live, white is neutral, green or exposed copper is ground)
I like the TP-Link Kasa switches, since they are easy to install and work with Google Home without needing a hub.*** See UPDATE below ***

I have been using this for several years now and I can't imagine my bedroom without one now. Being able to say "Alexa lights off" instead of having to get up and manually turn off your light is great. The iPhone app also works well so if you don't want to speak out-loud to turn off the lights in the middle of the night and wake other people up  you can use that. I also really like the idea of it being a button that your press instead of a switch, it makes turning on the light a lot easier if you have something in your hands, you can just easily bump the switch with your elbow or something. I haven't had any connection or light issues with the switch. It may be an expensive light switch compared to a "dumb" one, but I think it truly is one of the best smart home upgrades you can make.

You can't go wrong with these wifi switches. They are pretty easy to install if you're comfortable doing electrical work and they integrate very well with alexa and Google assistant. My biggest concerns are that they dont always fit the wall plate so well but buying a slightly larger one did the trick for me. And the other con is the light it emits may be a tad too bright if you sleep near one but a white cover up sticker can dim it and not take away the look of it. But all in all these are great and the app is easy to navigate and I have made many alexa routines using these switches to turn things on automatically. Had no trouble switching fans, vents and lights on and off.
Summary:This is my second TP-Link switch; the first was the HS210 Kit reviewed here https://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-reviews/RVT4GGWVCFGE5/ref=cm_cr_othr_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B07724HNTX.

This switch works to turn on and off a light via the Alexa home assistant - it does not dim the lights. With that said, it is very easy to wire, but does require a ground or it will not work - check to make sure you have one as not all switches do depending on how old the electrical installation is. WiFi set up is very easy as well.The switch does not actually flip, but clicks. Thus you have to press the bottom which will go in and come back out upon release. Once set up you can use the switch as normal by pressing or asking Alexa to turn if on/off. It's speed is only limited by the home assistant, but it does respond well. Refer to picture to see how bright the light is when off.

I'm definitely a tech geek so the idea of a smart switch really appealed to me. "Hey, I can switch on a light with my voice or on my phone from my office or in the car . . ." So it's clearly cool that way, but the advertising wasn't crazy clear about this particular switch and how it only works with a light that is controlled by a single switch.  So I'm techie but not exactly a licensed electrician consequently, I didn't know the difference or what those other kind of switches were called.  As a result, the install was a little frustrating because the light I really wanted it attached to was a three way setup and this didn't work for that.  Long story short, I ended up putting the switch in a room that wasn't my first choice or in a place where a smart switch made a ton of sense, but its still pretty cool as a novelty device.  The face plate needs to have some options especially if you are putting it beside another switch for something like a ceiling fan and two plates can't fit side by side etc.

I used this switch for my front porch light and it works great. You can set up on/off based on sunrise, sunset, by time, or any combination through the app on your phone. It's nice coming home and having the lights on.When the light is off the switch is softly illuminated with a circle that is visible through the face of the switch. This is a nice feature when the room is dark and you're looking for the light switch.

Find your neutral wire and connect along with the two live wires from current light switch and the ground wire. My main complaint is the switch itself is very bulky in the back of the switch (what goes in the wall) so if you have a small area in the wall for your light switch, this is going to be a tight fit ... if you can even get it in there at all. Just depends on how your home was constructed. Integrating with phone and WiFi is fairly easy if you are somewhat knowledgeable in connecting to WiFi. Their online support takes forever and isn’t helpful, they will tell you to call an electrician. Once connected, it’s easy to program and turn on/off from your phone. I’ve had a few times where I had to reset the switch (tiny button below main toggle on switch). Overall, pleased.

This is one of many smart switches that I bought some expensive and some very expensive this one is the most reasonably priced and let me say it was one of easiest to install Had it up and running in less than 30 minutes. Some of the expensive ones I bought had me pulling my hair out because they were so sensitive with the way it had to be hooked up and what they were compatible with. Some of them would stop talking to the app and say not able to connect.I am a TP-Link customer from this day forward planning to install more in my home and they will all be TP-Link Thank you TP-Link.

Our family is not comfortable with Alexa/Google Home/ Etc, but we still want to have controllable switches. We are slowly changing all of our switches over to KASA switches not only because how well they work, but also for they don't need. They do NOT need a smartthings homebridge, Alexa, or any other extra equipment aside from a smartphone or tablet to run the KASA app.Setup is easy, especially if you have some experience changing light switches and fixtures in your home. It really is just another light switch and goes in like expected.  Once the traditional wiring is done load up the app and add the switch to the list - follow the prompts - and you are done.

Need an auto cutoff timer function? Seems reasonable for a automated and temporary lighting. WeMo offers that but I didn't find it reliable so I ordered this. Although this switch says no hub required, read the description, there is a hub in their smart router and it's only found there. Why would I need it? I could name one of 2 total features I needed a smart light switch for; an auto cutoff timer when manually turned on and motion triggered lighting from a security camera.But no auto cutoff timer without the hub. No hub without an expensive dated router I don't need.

Okay. . I am in the process of installing this. . .and I had to stop what I am doing to go online to see how to separate the plate from the unit. . Why doesn't the instructions say so. Does it just pop out. It is held by plastic. . I don't want to break anything.  (It does pop out -- start from area that has the metal) In addition, it would be nice if they included labels to put on the wires . other manufactures did this. It is not that I don't know that white goes to white, black to black and green to copper -- but the instructions make a big deal about labeling. Also I had one black wire that was looped. . . making it look like it was two black wires going to one screw so I did label it, before I realized it just one wire. . . Also it would be nice if they stated that it doesn't matter which black wire you use -- either one is fine.  That being said, I was able to install both switches in a dual box and they did fit and since I already had a TP plug set up was a breeze.  I put one on my bedroom ceiling fan, and one on my garage light (which I always seem to leave on -- so I am hoping with this I will at least remember to turn it off)

First of all, the installation was hard for me since I realized only after getting this in the mail that the switch I was replacing was a 3-way switch (2 switches that control one light).  Made the install super sketchy and difficult, but I eventually figured it out with the help of an uncle who is an electrician.If you're gonna use this with an Alexa, beware that when enabling the skill, the switch can sometimes say "unavailable" or "not connected", but it IS connected and will still work flawlessly...(((THIS DOES NOT HINDER THE SWITCH FROM WORKING PROPERLY AND MAY ACTUALLY BE A POWER SAVING FEATURE, BUT FIGURED ID MENTION IT ANYWAYS))) Its strange... If I go into my Alexa app, and view the "bedroom" group (which is the group I added the switch to) most of the time it wont show the switch.... Like, Alexa cant see that the switch is connected... but if I tell Alexa to turn it on it works fine... Also, If you want it to appear again in the group for a while, you can go to devices (in the Alexa app) and hit the "on" button, which will then register it and put it in the group temporarily.

Update October 4, 2020:Installed second switch in my home, this one for four hanging counter lights. This one was a bearcat, not because of the switch, but because of the way the electrician in his wisdom - or perhaps lack of it - hd decided that the switch should be a junction box. Three commons wrapped together, three grounds wrapped together all smashed up at the back of the box, as well as the hot side for the switch pigtailed off a hot junction. First attempt the switch common came out of contact with the other commons, so second try I needed to use some creativity to insure a secure connection in that mess  Also for the huge ground bundle. In the end, after solving the major wire junction and space fiasco, the switch performed perfectly, and hooked up to wifi fine and integrated with Google Home easily as before.

I have several TP-Link smart plugs and this switch isn't much different. The main concerns are going to be related to installation. First, the original switch didn't have a neutral white wire ran to it, so I had to dig further into the electrical gang box to find it to attach. I found some helpful Youtube videos specific to wiring of this switch. Second, this switch is deep. I had to slightly rearrange the wires in the box to accommodate the switch size. Third, the mount arms / bezels are thick, and might prevent the switch faceplate from fitting flush to the wall or at least it did for me. What I ended up doing was temporarily fitting the switch in place and tracing it on the wall with a pencil. I then took a high speed cutting bit with a dremel tool and carved out the drywall and plastic gang box so the switch fit flush with the surface of the wall. With a good dremel this only took seconds to do vs. trying to do it with hand tools.Other helpful advice. Take your time and you'll have better results. I first tried to install it without recessing the switch and I overtightened and cracked a faceplate. Having an extra faceplate on hand is probably a good idea so that you can finish and clean up your project in one go of it. You can always keep the extra for your next project or return it to the store on your next needed trip vs. making a special trip. Also, I was working in a double gang box – be sure to use a probe for detecting electricity before working on the switches and shut off the circuit breaker or breakers. I had two active circuits in the box and had to flip two breakers.
2 black wires to 1 black wireThere will be 2 black wires on the back of any smart switch you buy. If you live in an older house, there is only 1 black wire in the wall.
Background:  Built and new house two years ago and wanted to start a smart home with a goal to minimize brand variationSize:4500+ Sqft 3 levels

I have been using the TP-Link switches for at least 6-8 months.  I have installed roughly half a dozen of them; either single pole, 3-way or the dimmer variety. They all continue to work great.  The app and Google Assistant integration are excellent.The reason that I bought TP-Link switches is because they are UL-listed just like other "dumb" light switches and components that you might buy at your local hardware store.  Most "smart" products are not UL-listed.

I bought a couple of these after a mostly positive experience with the Kasa smart plugs, and I'm pretty pleased so far.All Kasa devices I've bought have worked with both Alexa and HomeAssistant (smart home hub software). They set up easily, and work with almost zero delay.

I have nothing terrible against TP product. In all honesty I love this product that they have. I'm sad to say that my house who is not designed with second black wire. Unfortunately I could not get it to function because of that second black wire that is required in order for it to work. I was able to get the device to turn on and Link with my phone but unfortunately the wall unit would not allow it to turn on the power to the lights even though it was getting power. It would be nice if the manufacturer wood design a wall switch that could use the wires that were in my house but there is nothing more that could be done. I hope the manufacturer does reach out to me to offer me a switch that does have a red wire black wire and a ground wire that can still do the same job because this would have been a perfect switch.

Update: I have been using this switch for a month or so. I bought a second switch for backyard lights. The idea is to have the lights turn on during the night. I have noticed that the app is not responsive several times. The button to switch on or off does not work (from the app). After I close the app and open it several times, then it becomes responsive. This is why downgrading to 3 stars.However, scheduling the light works fine so far. The switch runs on and off on time. Moreover, it works well with Alexa by calling the name of the switch.

I bought two sets of TP-Link HS200 for $32.99 each on June 27, 2018. I already had several TP-Link HS200 switches throughout my house, and I bought two more to replace the last two remaining switches. These are excellent switches and I am very happy with them.First a background: I have roughly fifty smart devices throughout my house. These include smart assistants, bulbs, light panels, switches, motion sensors, etc. TP-Link smart devices I have are HS100 plugs, HS105 plugs, HS110 plugs, and HS200 switches. They are all connected to SmartThings, which unfortunately takes some time to configure as there is no native solution from SmartThings to connect TP-Link devices.

First I would like to say the physical product works as I expected once installed. No Neutral wire? Don't bother, search elsewhere! It was easy to set up in the app and out of the combined 15 TP Link Kasa smart bulbs, smart plugs, smart switch and cameras they have solid connections and never dropped once I replaced the Verizon FIOS Gateway G1100 router with the TPLink Archer 2300. The physical install was kind of hard for me to install due to my wall box was so tiny, inside the metal switchbox my neutral wire wasn't cut and in a wire nut, it entered the box and ran straight up and exited the box. My load wire wasn't cut either, just stripped and wrapped around the screw in the switch.For the wires I had coming out of the wall switch box, I had to cut the neutral wire into 2, along with the load wire and install as normal as per the directions, white to white, all blacks to one of the blacks, and the red wire to the second black wire. My place have old wiring so there was no ground wire and I didn't want to ground the wire to the metal switch box because I didn't know if it was grounded so I capped it off. Im my apartment out of 5 toggle switches only 2 had a neutral wire.

Our electrician was installing some outdoor lights and he put the switch in the basement of the house.  To simplify matters, I wanted a light switch that I could trigger remotely and after ample research I settled on this one and have not been disappointed.  Here is a quick summary:Pros:

Bought this switch in July 2018 for my work shop.  Instead of putting in double switches for the front and back doors, I elected to use this smart switch located at the front of my shop, then use Alexa to control the lights from anywhere in the room.  When I first put it in, it worked pretty well.  Over the months though it seems to be having more and more difficulty.  As of now (January 2019) it will not respond to KASA or Alexa.I found a number on the back page of the operator manual to call support.  They told me to hold down the left button at the bottom of the switch for 10 seconds to do a factory reset then add it back to KASA.  Will try this tonight when I get home.

I use this with Google home, and it works flawlessly.  I like that this calibrates the dimming level during setup, which I don't recall the others like Wemo and Lutron doing.  Setup is pretty easy, and keep in mind that you need a neutral wire.A tip with installation I can give you is to not stress too much about knowing the difference between the live and lead wires. The way my wiring is, it's difficult to tell which is which. I had to do trial and error, and reversing the wires will not cause damage. You'll know it's wrong if the lights won't come on...then, just turn the breaker back off and reverse the two wires.

Physical installation is not bad, but you will need some room in your panel as this thing is much bigger than your standard switch.  Then, the rest of installation is via the apps which is very easy.  My biggest problem is that it keeps dropping off from the network constantly, which renders it useless. I have to reset the thing every other day, and I can't do that if I am away from home.  My access point is about 6 feet away, btw. This is a switch, no house design will have an access point next to every single switches.  Network connection needs to be reliable and strong.  I don't know why they don't provide network access via the electrical wire instead of wireless, since it is already hooked up.  There is no need for high speed, but reliable is an important feature, IMO.

I've been meaning to install a smart switch for some time now to control my outdoor lights and I've always liked TP Link products, I have the smart plug that I use for my living room lamp. It was easy to install, and luckily my house wiring has the neutral wire required for the installation. I also replaced the other toggle switches in the gang box with rockers to match the TP Link. Connection to wifi was easy and the configuration was a breeze as I already had the Kasa app installed. Alexa integration was even easier as it picked it up right away. Currently it's in a timed setup so I don't have to go to my front door to turn the outside lights on and off every night. I'm hoping it holds up well over time. Great product TP Link!! I'll definitely be getting some more to complete my whole house smart integration.
Love being able to integrate light fixtures into Echo’s new guard system.Two things to consider, however:

I had installed 2 Belkin Wemo dimmers to control a replace a few existing dimmer switches that were in my home.  While they were virtually no different to install, the setup was a nightmare.  I ended up having to change Wi-Fi settings on my 2.4Ghz network just to be able to use it.I was a little hesitant to stick with the Wemo switches for regular single pole operation.  I saw these had a very good rating, and went for it.  I've installed 2 of these, and one 3-way switch so far, and the setup each time has been so incredibly easy.  Once I installed it and restored power, it's taken me only about 5 minutes to get this setup, connected to my network, and added into Alexa.

Works great so far, but beware of the LED indicator on the switch.  My SO and I need to sleep in a dark room due to night shifts, and the indicator is very bright when trying to black out a room.  Some people this probably won't bother, but it really can get bothersome for those of you that want a darker setting.  I hope TP Link comes out with a way to optionally turn the indicator off.

I researched a lot of wifi light switches, and debated for a bit on which one's to purchase.  I knew I did not want to spend too much even though I debated on the ecobee for a while ( I have their thermostat) but I dd not need the Alexa feature as I have Alexa throughout my house already.  These seemed reasonably priced and had decent reviews.  So I dove in with one switch and one plug.The installation was straight forward, I have Honeywell automated GFI sized timers for my outdoor lights and these were similiar to install.  Though it ended up tight since I have a 4 switch spot, with now 3 of these in it, it gets difficult to tuck the wire nuts in but is doable.

I bought three of these to convert the switches in my basement from standard to smart switches. The installation was easy: Black to Black, White to White, Ground to Ground. Only one of my switches had this type of wiring.  One switch turned out to be a Three-Way (Two switches in different places controlling the same light, we still don't know where the second switch is).  The wiring for same is Black, Black, White, Pink, and Ground. The other wiring for the third switch has no Neutral (White) wire at all. Once wired in, the setup is easy, and it works great. Just make sure when you decide to convert over, you take the existing switch out of the box (please turn off the circuit breaker first, and there's no need to unwire it yet) and see what kind of wiring configuration you have.

I bought the TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Light Switches to control the outside house lights. They are easy to install, about the same as installing a dimmer switch, about 10 minutes. Easy to set-up with the Kasa app. I was hoping for a 'dusk to dawn' option but it seems to need a TP-link hub for that capability. I have a bunch of hubs (Hue, Meross, Schlage) already and  I hesitate to buy another one, so I settled for creating an on/off schedule.My one gripe is that the light switch cover for a double Decora style switch instance does not fit properly over the TP-link Wi-Fi light switch because of the thickness of the plastic tabs which attach the switch to the electric box. It looks like a 'deep' switch cover will work but they are pricey. It would be good if Amazon offer these deep switch covers on the same page as the TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Switch. Several covers show up but I don't think any of these is the correct cover.

Just finished installation with no surprises. I had a deep box with the 4 wires needed so installation was snap and connecting to router and Alexa was just as easy. Now to see if it stays connected.5-3-20.  Just installed my second one. At $40 apiece I didn't find that many places I wanted one. At $20 that changed. Today was a seldom used ceiling fan. Because this one went into a duplex box I had to reuse the original cover plate and ran into the same problem I had with a Wemo switch. The cover plate fits so tight that it interferes with the reset switch and affects normal operation. By enlarging the top and bottom edges the problem disappears.

I'll start off by saying that overall I'm happy with the switch once I got it installed, and it seems to be working great. It integrated easily with my Google home and I'm able to control it with voice commands.However, the installation process leaves a bit to be desired. The biggest issue is that the switch doesn't come with any actual installation instructions; you download the app, pick your device and the app guides you though it from there. That wouldn't be a problem except that you need to be connected to WiFi even before the device is installed, and since this switch was on the same circuit as my modem and router, it wouldn't allow me to select my device and get installation instructions. Luckily, I found a good YouTube video and had it up and running in about 15 minutes.

I just installed this wi-fi light switch today and am pleased with the unit.  I have this controlling two exterior wall sconces that flank two garage doors at a property I own.  I have the lights now scheduled to turn on in evening when it is dark so that tenants have more visibility.  I use many of the tp-link wi-fi mini plugs and standard plugs and have been happy and wanted to try this device.  I used push in connectors in the 2-gang box in the garage to make the install go a bit smoother and the switch fit nicely with the existing 2-gang wall plate.I run a unifi network at the property with 3 access points covering the entire property with wi-fi.  I run one SSID on three different channels (2.4ghz) which gives me redundancy in case one AP happens to fail, hopefully preventing any connectivity drop offs to the switch.

the switch housing is large and may not fit in some small electrical outlet boxes, especially if the interior has a bunch of wires. The manufacture also made the switch plate cover difficult to unsnap. I bet a bunch of people break them, at least I almost did, so some care is needed popping it off. The Switch also requires a white neutral wire to operate and in many homes the electricians only run the Black hot wires to Light Switch outlet boxes to save time and money and since most older dumb switches only need the Black Hot Wire to operate. I was lucky and had a three prong electrical outlet in the same 2x4 cavity a couple feet below my light switch box and was able to pull up it's White neutral wire so had a couple hours added work but got the new Smart Switch to work.TP-Link has a app to use the remote on & off feature with my android smart phone and the install and setup went fine. I did buy this to also use with a Amazon Dot, but I can't get the Dot installed because it's Alexa app doesn't work with my phone so sorry I couldn't review how the TP Link Switch works with the Amazon products.

This in-wall switch just works!  FINALLY a product that does what it says.  AND it actually fits in ALL standard USA electrical boxes.  AND it is UL certified--seriously, check out all the cheap competition... none are UL listed... So even if they say they support 15A, how do you know they won't melt down first in a ball of flame?  Do you really want that type of risk hard-wired that into your home?Two other companies have UL listing, so these are really the only competition to this one: GE and Leviton.  But both of these guys require you to buy a special "gateway"... so their switches may be RF, but are not Wifi.  TP-Link is Wifi.

UPDATE 07/20:So after having used this for a bit, it's good for simple control which is probably reflective of the price.  They finally added smart actions which gives you the ability to auto turn off the light after a certain amount of time when you turn it on.  However, there's a limit of 3 smart actions enabled at any given time which isn't great.  The Belkin switch is much better for that and allows me to have tons of rules applied.  I use these for regular lights and also for bathroom fans so that they will auto turn off after venting the room, but limiting to only 3 auto-offs makes it less useful if you have multiple switches you need to apply rules to.

Installed in just a few minutes, but took a few tries to get the app to connect to it for setup.  It was likely my phone, but the inability to setup using a laptop could be a drawback for some who don't want to or can't use the app.  Once setup, it has worked well and I haven't had any connectivity issues.  The ability to turn it on at sunset and off at sunrise is really nice, but I wish it could have an offset -- for example, sunset - 1 hour (on 1 hour before sunset).  The other thing that I would add is the ability to setup the switch to connect to multiple networks if the first network becomes unavailable similar to how a phone or laptop will change networks automatically.  I have 2 networks in my house and as it stands right now, if the network the switch is connected to becomes unavailable it will not automatically fallback to my second network.  Instead, I have to manually change it to the other network.  Other than those few things, the switch has worked really well and I have installed a couple more.  It is very nice to not need an additional hub and it is priced reasonably.  One thing to note though, TP-LINK has released hardware version 3 of the switch which changes the chipset for better performance but Amazon is still shipping version 2 as of this writing.

I installed 14 of these TP-Link HS200 wall switches in one day. Everyone of my rooms and garage are now controlled via Kasa and/or Echo depending on which interface I want to use. I love the "Kasa" app and the things it allows you to do, but obviously Echo has the Voice Control feature so they are a good pair together. The switch wiring is straight forward if you have ever done any electrical work. Older house wiring may not be compatible with these switches if the common does not drop into the gang box. Also beware these switches take up a lot of space in the gang (wall) box and if there are a lot of wires in the box (plus wire nuts) it is possible the HS200 will not fit without some creative wire maneuvering. If you have never done any electrical work at all in your life - BE SMART - hire someone to install these for you. Don't try it yourself. Electricity and wiring are not for the novice. Don't risk your life or your house.Now a note for TP-LINK if you are listening - I will not ding my rating of these switches - but one thing that annoyed the heck out of me while installing these switches. Annoyance # 1 - how much would it have added to the manufacturing cost and selling cost to actually put retaining flats on the back of the mounting screws so the dang things don't keep falling out. I know you tried to mold the chassis to hold the screws, but trust me it isn't the same and doesn't work. All other switch and outlet manufactures put retaining flats on the back of their screws. Step it up one notch (please). TP-Link please consider the retaining flats on the screws. Love these switches.

I've posted before about the TP-Link wifi lighting controls, and I'm still enamored with them. Fantastic devices with rock solid signal and connectivity.  I've got 8 of these installed around my house, (and a dozen hs100 plugs) and I would buy more if we needed them.This requires knowledge of electrical wiring, and should not be installed by the uniformed.  The app does a good job walking you through it, but if you don't know how to install outlets or switches in the wall, then get some help.

RevisionOK I went to reset and I noticed a gap with a slot in middle between toggle bottom and wall plate.  That is reset switch.  Can access with screw driver blade without taking off wall plate.  That is not mentioned any where. Reset unit to factory per instructions and redid set up.  Switch works again properly.  No will see if it stays connected or I have to regularly reset it.  If it stays locked in will add a star.

I had an electrician install three of these about a year and a half ago. It took less than 30 minutes for him to install them, including the time it took me to set them up and connect them to the Kasa app and then Alexa.They worked perfectly until about a month or so ago. Now, at least once a week, they disconnect from wifi, and I have to turn off the switch in the breaker box to get them to work again.

This is just one of 14 TP-Link products I have in my home.  I have been using them for a couple of years now and have had NO problems with any of them.  I have the hardwired switches (2), light bulbs (5), and 2 types of these plugs (7 total).  All of them have been easy to install (even re-wiring my switches) and connect and have worked seamlessly with all of my Alexa devices (3 echos, 1 show and 2 Fire tablets) as well as my iPhone through both the Alexa app and the Kasa (TP-Link's app).  You can't beat the price on all of these products and the quality is top notch!  I like that they are "Hub-less" as that is one less link in a chain that can be problematic.  I have 2 of the lightbulbs in porch lights (outside) and I live in an area that gets highs in the summer of 100º and snow in the winter with lows in the teens and have had no problems with them.  All in all these are the BEST smart home products I have found (I was given some WeMo plugs as a Christmas gift and one didn't work at all and the other kept loosing its connection, so out the door those went!).  I'm staying with TP-Link for sure!
I bought this as my second step into home automation, and I am not disappointed.First, the things I wish I had paid attention to.

This light switch was easy to install and setup. I am a long-time fan of WeMo, having several outlets and  light switches ... Kasa has raised the bar for initial setup and cost!I love the lighted circle that shows where the switch is in the dark (when it is not turned on). I wish the circle stayed lit when the switch is in the 'on' position, since my switch is in the stairwell which isn't lit.

Kudos to TP-Link Smart Wi-F- Light switch. I ordered it yesterday morning with same day delivery. Received it last night. I installed it this morning. It took about 30 minutes to complete entire process. I works like a charm. I programed it to turn on and off at sunrise and sunset. It connected to all my devices with no issues. I even have it connected to my Echo (Alexa). It can be programed to activate on or off at times you wish, at different times and the length it is activated, to confuse would-be burglars. Can be turned on or off manually or by the downloaded app (Kasa).Great product. The reason for only the 4 star rating is because I only just installed it. I had a horrible experience with another named product (Leviton Decora Wi-Fi wall switch) Installation the Leviton was easy. But when it came to the pairing the switch to my router, it failed to connect. However it did see my neighbors networks but not mine. Leviton support team tried to help but failed as they could not figure out the issue. This support assistance took 2 days as I had to wait for the supervisor to call from the west coast. I live on the east coast.  I guess the support techs work on banker's hours.TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Light Switch -Thumbs UP........Leviton Decora Wi-Fi wall switch- A big Thumbs DOWN

Now that it is installed, the switch works as advertised  But I was not impressed with the installation experience.1. Before you buy this, I would open your switch and have a look.  If you only have one coax cable with the two wires coming into the box (i.e. the power is coming into the light box, not the switch box), THIS SWITCH WILL NOT WORK.  It only works in a box where there is power in the switch box.  Since the switch itself requires power, I guess this makes sense, but the instructions don't spell that out as such.

Since this requires opening up/replacing your light switch cover and potentially exposing bare powered leads, I would suggest having this installed by a professional or a high capability handy person.  Obviously make sure power is turned off before attempting to do anything.I have 2 of these switches now (and a few Kasa Smart Plugs) and they've worked great for me.  It is a typical TP Link high quality product so I expected this to be the same.  The installation was straight forward and much easier if you have the Kasa app already installed on your iPhone/iPad.  There is also quite a bit of programming capability so you have quite a bit of control with this switch.

Giving this five stars as I haven't found a valid reason to deduct.Installation was fairly easy and straight forward, everything you'd typically need (except tools) was in the box. The wiring and "hole" in my place was a bit tight and that made hooking up take a bit longer than it should, it was no fault of the product though. It works as expected and though it only supports 2.4 GHz wifi, that's not really a drawback. I have my 2.4GHz access point on a different network than my phone and Google Home but both were able to find as well as communicate with the switch.

This is my second review of this thing since I have been buying these and installing all over the house.Relatively easy to install the hardware ( getting the app to connect was not easy at all). After 3 days they started going off line, needed to be reset and added to the app again, which by the way stopped working, now I have 3 connected switches and 2 that are grayed out in the app and it says not online.

At first I didn’t think I was going to be able to use this switch because I have an older home ( no ground or neutral) but I was able to make it work. I only had a white and black wire and they weren’t wired as hot and neutral. So First, I replaced the metal switch box out for a plastic one. Since WiFi etc could be blocked by the metal box, plus the metal was too small. I just broke the old one so it would fall out. No cutting in wall. Second, I had to re-do the wiring inside the light and switch since I didn’t have a ground or neutral wire. I ended up running the ground wire to the switch and attaching it to the neutral/grounds on the switch, white to Live and Black to Load. The process to quite a while but it works very well. If you have a older home and you aren’t handy with electric work I would suggest sticking with the smart bulbs. However, if you like a challenge it looks great when your done. Newer homes shouldn’t have an issue.

This is my third Kasa product. I have 2 of the smart plugs which work amazing.I was concerned with this due to the complaints of installation because of its bulky size. This is true but I have a 6 year old home and really didn’t have much trouble. Getting to the neutral wire was the hardest part because it was tucked and bent way in the back of the box.

Just installed three of these. Not sure why some other brands cost twice as much.  Besides that from some of the reviews, stae that the firmware update causes issues.  So I wont be doing a firmware update.  Besides that, It was so simple to install.  The instructions are so clear. Great wifi reception.  I can now automate all the exterior lights to turn on at sunset and off at sunrise.  No more running around the house or leaving lights on all day because I forget to turn them off. Now the exterior of the house will be brightly lit whenever I arrive home late. Thank goodness for modern innovations. 🙏👌👍

I have a number of different TP-Link switches and outlets and they are incredibly easy to install & setup without the usual frustration you get with many other products and apps. I do not use mine with Alexa but just program them with the Kasa app on my phone. The Kasa app is fantastic and walks you through the install/setup process. I have tried other so-called smart products and most all are horrible to setup and to get them to stay connected.One unique feature for is the "Away" setting in which you can have a lamp (for instance) turn on and off randomly during a set period of time making it appear more like someone is at home.

I used this switch with Alexa in a 500 sqft studio apartment with no dividing walls for over a year.Over the course of that time it constantly lost signal with both my Echo device and with my wifi, at least once or twice every month.  3 times i had to reset it and run it through the setup process over the course of that year as well.

I’m an almost 60 year old widow. I try to do small DIY projects around the house. I have four Alexa devices and just love them...mostly for the music aspect. I’ve connected a smart bulb and smart plug to my Alexa system, but this was more of a challenge because the plug needed to be installed. After watching a couple youtube videos on it, I was ready to give it a shot. Took about 15 minutes from beginning to end and I was done. I connected it to the ceiling fan in my bedroom, which I run every night. Now it’s so nice to tell Alexa to turn the fan on or turn the fan off. Don’t shy away from this if you’re not “handy”. Give it a try, you won’t be sorry.

Extremely responsive and works great with Alexa. Unfortunately, I have two complaints.1. The Android app was TERRIBLE. It was extremely buggy and difficult to set up. Now that I have it set up, it works fine, but I was worried I wasn't going to be able to set it up and I'd have to return it for a time. But, if you're willing to fight with it for a while, it works great now! I can't speak for the iOS app. (For those of you more technically inclined reading this thinking I'm probably just not good with technology, I'm an app developer.)

I bought two of these.  The first gave me fits on installation, and had me questioning my own sanity.  The variety of different ways it was failing were amazing.  First level tech support was worse than useless, basically reading a script and being unable to recognize that the script didn't apply.  Basically they kept saying "must be a wiring problem."  It wasn't a wiring problem.I gave up on that one, and installed the second one in the same location.  Easy as pie and 24 hours later is still working as expected without any of the errors.  I tried the first one in a different location, and had similar horrific experience (but now understood  that the first one was a bad unit).  Amazon has come through with a replacement for the bad unit and the replacement was also an easy install.

They work great. I was able to set up a routine to automatically turn on the lights in the morning and and when I'm only my way home from work. The only issue I have with them is how much space they take up inside the gang box. If they wired up like a normal switch and didn't add  6 inches of wire inside the gang it would be okay. The size of switch and the extra wire make it hard to fit everything in, especially a double gang box with multiple sets of wires running in/out already

Tried to install 4 times, but always failed to connect in final step.  I suspect this is because of the 2.4GHz limitation, for which most mesh routers dont offer a workaround because you cant turn off the 5GHz network.Really bummed, not just because of the time wasted trying to set this up, or the impossibility of getting support from TP-Link (automated Chat - what use is that?), but because I had had luck with a smart plug made by the same manufacturer, so I assumed these Kasa products worked with mesh networks.  How wrong I was.

Just finished installing 2 switches. Easy to set up. Kaza app on my android smartphone quickly found the switches and allowed me to control the lights from my phone. Enabling this skill on the Alexa app was also easy and the switches respond quite well. I have 3 dots.Only issue so far is that I could not activate remote control on either switch: I get an error message saying the devices had been previously linked to another account (which is weird since I bought them directly from Amazon). Suggested solution is to factory reset, which I have not tried yet. This, however, was not an obstacle to pair Kaza with Alexa.

I have a 4 gang wall plate at my front entry that has all the switches for for the front lights. I installed 4 of these in that box. I AM NOT and electrician but I am pretty familiar with switch wiring (enough to be dangerous). After opening the box and examining all the wires I looked up somethings on YOUTUBE. I was able to get them installed and working. I already had the app because I have a few wall outlets that are TP-Link and they connected with no problems. I really like the TP-Link products. It is so nice to be able to put the lights on a timer, tell Alexa to turn them on or off or control them with the phone app. My wife says I'm getting lazy in my old age and I just say I'm getting smarter.  Great products and easy install.

I was having trouble getting a working smart switch installed in my master bedroom.  This was the 3rd switch I had tried and by far the worst one.  The install was easy, it was working fine for 3 hours then it started strobe continuously, I reset the breaker and it kept going.  There was nothing I could do to get it to stop the strobe.  I was just lucky I am not prone to strokes, someone who is vulnerable to a strobe light could have easily had an episode.  I had to uninstall it at the dead of night and swap in a temporary switch until i finally got a switch that worked (Skylink).

I use this with a Smartthings hub. Originally Kasa was not supported and I often glanced over their products....until now.Setup was intuitive and painless. Wiring was also equally drama free. I use one of these for my front porch lights and let my hub command it as I can set it up to come on x-min before sunset....this is big for me as usually it is too dark before it comes on.

Piece of cake to install and set up. So far no problems with the wifi connection for all but one of my switches. Great to be able to flip outside lights on from my phone when I get home and it's pitch black outside of the house. Also, if I hear something outside, can just push a button on my phone and lights on just like that. Functional product and nice looking as well.Dropping two stars due to persistent WiFi connectivity issues with one unit. In the garage, well within range of the WiFi signal and it pops on and offline randomly. I have full Wifi strength at this location so it isn't an issue on my end. I have heard customer support is non-existent, so I will test in another location to determine whether my unit is defective.

Worked right out of the box. Followed the instructions and was able to get the switch installed and working.  I intended to use this with Amazon's Echo and the only stumbling block I ran into was that I jumped the gun and tried to discover devices before adding the TP-Link Kasa skill to the Echo.  In the Echo app: From the menu, go to Smart Home, then Get More Smart Home Skills.  Search for Kasa or TP-Link and enable the TP Link Kasa skill.  Enter the credentials you will have created from TP-Link.  Then discover new devices and it should find the switch.  FWIW, the TP-Link app has these instructions.Keep in mind that whatever you name the device in the TP-Link app will be what you can ask Alexa to turn on/off.  If I named it Bob's Room, I can ask Alexa to turn on/off Bob's Room Light, Bob, Room, or Light (assuming no other devices share those words).

The Kasa series of smart switches and smart plugs are great connected products. Easy setup, very fast response to commands from either the app or Alexa, and the app has a lot of features for schedules, groups and scenes.This smart switch is no exception. Once installed, it connected to my Wi-Fi network without issue, and works flawlessly. A great way to have the best of both worlds - a physical switch when you need it, or voice control when your hands are full. Admittedly, being a switch, its commands are limited - on and off. But you can combine it with other Kasa devices (in the Kasa app), or with other Alexa devices (in the Alexa app) to automate those simple commands in many useful ways.

What can I say it's a light switch... that I can turn on from anywhere in the world as long as there's an internet connection.  So far my favorite thing is to shut off the outdoor lights from the car or turn them on when I get home.Set up is easy though the switch does take up more room than a traditional switch and it requires a neutral wire. Not a problem so long as you dont have old wiring.  To install download the app, select your switch and the app walks you through the hookup and provides safety in the step by step process.  I honestly feel almost any DIY person can handle this so long as you know how to safely cut power to the box and have the right tools.
Installation is easy. Clear instructions in the Kasa app. Connection to WiFi is quick.Tested today at home. Didn’t test from away yet.

Couldn't be happier.  I installed them 2 months ago.  I have six total including two with the dimmer function.  Other reviewers have said that they stop working after a month.  Every one of mine is still working perfectly fine.  The hardware is easy to install.  The app is easy and intuitive, and as long as your wifi signal is strong, the switch is extremely responsive.  They are super easy to pair with Amazon Echo.  You just register a user name with the TP-link Kasa app, then sign into that user name via Alexa, and then Alexa automatically finds every TP-link device that you have installed.  Super easy.  I've had some issues with Alexa not understanding voice commands sometimes, but this is an issue with Alexa, not the switches.  If I go into the TP-link Kasa app directly to control the lights with my phone, they work flawlessly every time.  I suspect those who are saying that the switches are inconsistently working or not working at all may have spotty wifi issues, or the voice command they've programmed into Alexa may be difficult for Alexa to understand.  You really have to have strong wifi everywhere you intend to install these.  I have a dual wifi router setup for my home, with one router downstairs and another upstairs.  So between these two access points, the 6 switches I have distributed throughout the house work like a charm.

I have many TP-Link home products, various plugs, switches and cameras.  The products work great and easy to integrate with Alexa, but the warranty  registration process is the worse process I have ever experienced.  I don't know if they just don't want you to register their products or they just are just incompetent with the process / programming.  I have complained about this before and it has not gotten any better, despite now having to go to a whole new registration web page (which previous registered products will not carry over too, they will just "age out " of from the original site) .First - apparently they don't put the serial numbers in their database, so you can't even start the actual process on the page.

I don't write many reviews and I've tried a number of smart switches and I think these are my favorite1. Alexa Google home integration: there's something cool about telling AI to turn your lights on and off.

This is an add to my previous review of the HS200 Smart Switch. This morning I noticed all of my outside lights were still on. Then I noticed my neighbors lights were on as well. He liked mine so much he bought them too. I opened the app on my phone and there was no “off time” shown next to each switch and each switch had a green circle next to them,indicating the lights were on.It seems the server must have had a glitch and didn’t allow the off command to be executed. I found the fix to this.

Background:I first experimented with Lutron Caseta for Smart Light integration with Alexa. It works fine, and it was really the only solution that made sense for my 3 way implementation. More recently I have been looking for a cheaper solution. $50 per switch was really excessive all things considered. I stumbled upon this TP-Link Smart Light switch. I was intrigued because it was able to operate entirely without having yet another hub. I purchased one and gave it a try. I have been very very happy with it. I thought it was going to be a one-of oddity, then TP link released the HS210 version of this switch. That will work with 3 way switches!  That means I can now replace all my remaining switches with TP link products. Arrmed with this knowledge I purchased a second one (HS200, not the HS210 kit). Being an eletrical complete noob, I thought I would review my experience.

I have purchased 2 of the HS200 smart light switches. Both are now broken. One stopped working 7 after purchase, but TP-Link said (finally via email) they would replace it. The other stopped working 25 months after purchase, which was 1 month outside the warranty and they have refused to replace the switch. That TP-Link would not stand by their product when it was only 1 month outside of the warranty is awful customer service, prioritizing policies over customers. I asked to talk to a manager, but was not ever allowed to talk with anyone who could actually make a decision. On top of that, wait times to talk to anyone in customer service were really long (30 minutes or more) and they tried to get me off the phone as quick as they could so that they could send me their decision via email—again totally impersonal and an example of policy over people. I will never buy another TP-Link product again because of how both of the switches broke and TP-Link’s customer service was cold and uncaring.

I am not an electrician or a DIYer, but I managed to install these switches by myself.  Did I make mistakes?  Yes!  My biggest mistake could have been prevented if I had watched a few YouTube tutorials before I installed the first switch.  How was I supposed to know that when the instructions say wire it to a neutral wire that it meant wire it with ALL the neutral wires?  Once the two switches were installed, I was able to easily connect them o Alexa.  Installation (after I figured out my mistakes) was so simple) I Have ordered 4 more smart switches.

The wiring was dead easy and took possibly 3 minutes top once I knew what they wanted me to do. Follow the instructions in the Kasa app, as it makes it easy for anyone to do this - not just those with experience.  I had to dig through the questions asked in this listing to find the links for the Kasa support for Alexa or rather vice versa.  In short, make sure you've created a Kasa account in the app. Then with Alexa app, go to the 'add a device' and there is likely a short cut right for Kasa.  Only down side is that the timer doesn't seem to work with Alexa -- I'd love to be able to turn the fireplace on but ONLY for 20 minutes.  The app lets me, but Alexa does not.  Or if there's a way for Alexa to turn switches on/off but with a delay.... I have not yet found it.

I have installed multiple electrical switches in my house. I have also installed several smart devices in the past. For some reason, after following all instructions, connecting to wifi, getting power to the HS200 switch and the appearance of everything working, THE LIGHTS WON'T COME ON. I have uninstalled, re-installed, tried a different wall switch and no luck.  In every case I have gone back and re-installed the good old reliable switch and it works every time. Since I'm giving up on this product, I'm sharing my experience as new buyers are aware that installation won't always be a breeze as some have described. Good luck!

HS200 wall switch has 100% connection reliability.  Unlike the Dimmer switch (HS220), the HS200 switch always remained connected.  I have just one HS200.  The HS220 Dimmer is constantly going offline (I have seven of them).  Don't know why one version has low reliability and the other has 100% reliability .  Don't think it's a WiFi problem as computer and cellphone have zero connectivity problems.  Also have same problem with TP-Link bulbs, very low connection reliability.The TP-Link HS105 mini-plug (2 of them) has low reliability while the HS110 plug (2 of them) has 100% reliability.

This is my first smart switch. It was very easy to install. I downloaded the App and followed the directions. I replaced a standard light switch in a 3 gang box. I was concerned about space as one of the other switches was a programmable light switch for my outdoor light that took up a lot of space in the box. The 3rd switch wasn’t connected to anything, so I removed it and just put in a blank cover. Not sure if I would have had enough room if all three switches were active. However, for whatever reason this box seems to have a ton of wires running thru it, so not sure if this would be applicable in every 3 gang box. Note- you must have a neutral white wire available to connect to the switch. Older homes may not have this wiring.The App is very easy to use and I was able to connect it to both Alexa and Google Home. Definitely considering buying more switches for my home now.

I installed three of these, and those worked perfectly. The Kasa scheduling system is not as intuitive as Weymouth, but. Otherwise I was extremely satisfied. Then I tried to install the fourth. I tried everything, but, when I turned the breaker back on, all the light did was flicker incessantly. Then I tried online customer support. That was a very frustrating experience. First, Kasa subs it out to somewhere in Asia, so the language barrier is not insubstantial. After a great deal of email back and forth, they finally begged off by saying that they aren’t electricians. So I am on my own.  The installation is identical to two of the previous installations, both of which went off without a glitch. I will reinstall the old switch and maybe try this one on another device, but my caution to you is that their customer support for problem installations is subpar.
The switch is smart looking, easy to install and easy to set up.The fact that it is Alexa compatible is another plus.

I own 5 of these now. These are so easy to install, IF you also get some 4-port push-in or spring clamping electrical connectors. Make sure you get connectors that are 22-12 gauge and 4 ports. Most of the time you will need 2- or 3-ports, but in my house I needed 4-ports for some of the wires. Tp-link includes some orange twist connectors, but they cannot handle easily handle 4 wires, and the wires on this switch are twisted strands. My advice is get your own electrical connectors that can handle solid and twisted strands. You'll be done in 10-15 minutes of wiring, and these switches use the app on your phone to configure the Internet connection. That part couldn't be easier. Linking this to Alexa is just a matter of giving Alexa your Tp-link account information. Once you have one, you'll want your whole house connected. I wanted my 3 year old to be able to turn on bathroom lights on her own. It's also helpful for me to be able to turn off her bedroom light when she forgets - every single morning. I love these switches. Get your own electrical connectors though.

Installed easily and connected to my WiFi easily. It connected to Alexa without any problems so we can turn the kitchen lights on and off using the Echo dot. It doesn't require a smart hub, which is good and bad. Since there isn't a hub there are no schedules that can be used to control the lights. It isn't compatible with IFTT either so automation choices are *very* limited. It also doesn't do any dimming. You can buy a TP Link "smart" router with a hub in an apparent attempt to lock you into the TP Link walled garden and provide scheduling functions but I'm not doing that. So if you only need a switch that can be controlled on and off with Alexa, this is your ticket. If you want any kind of smart automation I'd keep looking for something that is compatible with more automation apps. I wish Philips Hue had a smart switch.

Having purchased several of these now and paying the extra shipping and duty to bring them to the UK, I can confirm they work perfectly on 220/240v. I had to do quite a bit of due diligence and actually found the original testing certification online and it showed they were tested for our voltage. The only difference is the size of the switch differs from the standard UK. A bit of cutting out of the wall to accommodate these switches, easy with plasterboard, a bit harder with brick or block, but they sit nicely when done. Also they must have neutral to work and most UK lights do run the neutral to the standard source and feed for the switched live. If you can fit these TP-Link switches you will not be disappointed they are fantastic, all fitted and working without WiFi being dropped or disconnected. The Kasa app is brilliant a good easy user interface and it’s nice to have a broad family of products to utilise the app and not have several different apps and products to confuse things. We are using the HS200 light switches and HS220 dimmer switches, the dimmer switches do not have the same shielding for the wiring and you could get a shock if working on them live, highly recommend to put insulation tape over the terminals to avoid for future issues. The UK HS100 WiFi plug sockets are great and we have recently started adding the KC200 TP-Link Kasa Cam outdoor series and again the app interface easy and straight forward. Again the KC200 are not available in the UK at the moment but we were able to add these without subscription easy enough. We have used Sonoff and WIFIPLUG products and they both often dropped WiFi connection and the app is not as good.

Very easy to install and setup. I was a little hesitant about the light on them but it’s so faint that you just barely notice it. Enough to notice in the dark to know there’s a switch there, nothing more. Also like the fact that it has dawn and dusk settings as I use these for outdoor lights since their cheaper than basic programmable switches. Only downside, of paired with toggle switches, they are a little thicker and stick out more than toggle switches so I had to loosen the toggle switches a bit so they extended far enough out as not to appear too recessed behind the cover plate.

I had been looking at a means by which ceiling fans/lights in my home could be integrated with an Echo Dot for voice controlled operation. I finally concluded that smart switches are the simplest, most cost-effective solution. This particular product was as easy to install as any traditional light switch, and the subsequent setup to work with the Echo was incredibly quick and easy. I installed two of these, one for the fan, and another for the attached light, and it works great.I did have to purchase a two-gang plate cover separately though, since I bought two single switches for this application.

This switch works perfectly and now allows me to turn on my front house lights at sunset and turn them off at sunrise.  The only slight issue I have, which you can see in the picture, is the switch does create a minor gap between the wall and the plate.  Not a major issue but something to keep in mind if you are particular about those types of things.  Wi-Fi communication with the switch is excellent and local control is easy as well:  tap on, tap off.  The wire leads coming out of the unit are roughly 2.5" and are stranded cable.  They also appear to be slight "tinned" with solder.

Wow, this was easier to install than a standard light switch! It's been repeated a billion times here, but you do need a neutral wire. This came with all the wire nuts you would need, all you need extra is a screw driver and some electrical tape (as extra security between wire nut and wires). App is easy to use, and I love that lights can be on a schedule. I kept forgetting to turn off the front lights in the morning so they'd stay on for days at a time, now I don't have to worry about it :) Perfect! I will probably get a few more for inside so we can control them while on vacation.

The installation of Kasa products from TP-Link are pretty straight forward bordering on simple!  But, with these in wall switches, there are some issues.  First, the gang box needs to be pretty deep to hold the switch and the packing in of the Romex cables attached.  Second, the size of the switch itself is slightly larger than the rectangle for the standard "Leviton" switch (see picture).  Third, in recent updates to the Kasa app, the ability to see the Wi-Fi SSID and signal strength have been removed.  This information was extremely helpful in troubleshooting network connection issues.  Lastly, would be great if the Kasa app added the ability to trigger events from the cameras to turn on lights!!!

No major complaints, but a few minor ones: Wiring instructions leave a lot to be desired. Thankfully I'm familiar with wiring switches from past experience, but if I wasn't then I would be in trouble because the instructions that come with this thing are poor regarding wiring. Additionally, the switch mechanism itself takes a little getting used to (it only pushes in on the bottom, so it doesn't work like a traditional rocker switch) and if you push too hard then the switch can get stuck "in" and then you have to jimmy with it to get it to pop out. Those are my only two gripes. The internet connectivity and app are rock solid. The speed is impressive but that might be relative to internet speed so I can't say everyone will experience that but it's been impressive for me. Overall, I'm satisfied and I really like being able to turn on my front outside lights when I'm not at home. One thing I wish it had built into the app was the ability to program on / off times.

pros: works very quickly and easily with setup through the app (you will need the app for installation instructions, it doesnt come with any). a little weird getting used to as the button is always in the "on" position, you click the bottom of the switch and toggle it on/off.cons: biggest con so far is that the switch backend (along with all the wires needed to install it) is LARGE. if you have a small electrical switch box or if its a double or triple and already filled with wires, this thing will not fit in it.

I didn't want to get into a whole "system" as I primarily wanted this for 1 light so this is perfect. I will echo what some others have said - due to the fact that it has pigtails instead of screw terminals, it can be a tight fit depending on your electrical box, but installing it was a very straight-forward affair (if you've ever done this kind of thing before that is).It works very well. It didnt get 5 stars from me for 2 reasons

When configured, this switch works very well and is almost immediately recognized by Alexa. Many network problems that people notice are most probably resulting from poor home network. I had to install a meshed network with 5 repeaters to get a good coverage of indoor switches and outdoor cameras.Samsung Galaxy S8 Active running Android 8.0.0, Android security patch level August 1, 2018 and Samsung Galaxy J7 (2016) running Android 7.0, Android security patch level June 1, 2018 will not allow the connection of the KASA app to the HS200 during setup. This may be due to an issue with security.

I bought this to replace an old timer switch for controlling my outside house lights.  I needed something that I wouldn't have to change as the days got longer/shorter and twice a year for daylight savings.  This has perfectly fit the bill.  Installation was straight forward and took all of 5 minutes.  If you have even a basic understanding of light switch wiring, you should have no problem installing this yourself.  Once installed, I fired up the android app, kasa and started the search for the switch.  The first time I tried, the app said found the device, but couldn't add it to the app.  After the 2nd try, the switch was added to the app and added to my wifi.  I was immediately able to turn off/on the switch from my android phone!  Pretty cool. Then from the app, I created a schedule to turn on at dusk and off at sunrise.  The app also shows daily run time, average run time for the week and month.  After the app was setup, I turned to my Echo to get it setup.  It was easy as searching for the skill to enable, and then going into the alexa app on my phone to find the switch.  Probably took 2 minutes total to get it running and responding to voice commands on my Echo.  Overall I am very pleased with this switch and will probably be buying several more for my house.Update March 14, 2018

I used this to replace a timer switch for my porch light and it works perfectly in that application.  With it, I can turn the light on and off based on a schedule set through the Kasa app, or manually with the app or by just hitting the switch.Installation is relatively simple and TP-Link provides everything you need to install the switch including the screws and wire nuts, but if you are not familiar with home wiring and installing light switches, hire a professional.

Works well and simple to install if your familiar with electricity or basic handy man work. Many of the 3 star and lower reviews are from individuals who have no idea on what they are doing or didn't read the requirement for a neutral wire so their way of dealing with their ignorance is to bash the product.The unit has FOUR WIRES.

I am currently running 10 TP-Link Switches, 2 TP-Link bulbs and 2 TP-Link smart plugs in my home. I control the devices with the Kasa app and with multiple Echo Dots (voice command) located throughout my home. The switches work perfectly and I have never had issues with them losing connection. I also like how there is an illuminated circle when the switch is off which is great when you need to locate a switch in the dark. They're pretty easy to install, but are much deeper than a regular rocker switch, so you may need to trim down some of your wires. However, I have fit these in duplex boxes with multiple TP-Link switches without issue. I also use these with my standard rocker switch panels. Overall, I am extremely impressed with these TP-Link switches, especially considering they do not require a hub like Phillips Hue and a few other brands. I am literally living like Ironman thanks to these switches.

Received two switches and setup was fairly easy as long as you know what you are doing and if you don't get someone who does!As you see in the picture, I have two switches side by side and set them up to work with Alexa in just a few minutes and they are working perfectly.

Ugh.... what a headache to install in my multi-switch box. The thing isn't the size of other switches. I had to shim the other switches and cut some of the cover plate to get it to fit. A single switch box install would be no problem but adding it to an existing switch box like mine sucked. I'll not do it again. I had a soft plastic plate I could cut. A metal or hard plastic cover plate is going to look really bad. Other than the install it works just as expected and no issues there.

Absolute garbage product. Honestly had high hopes as it was recommended by Amazon, but there are deadline flaws with the switch. Installed according to mfg instructions (I'm an apprentice electrician so easy install) The switch operates perfectly fine BUT ONLY when i physically press and hold the manual reset switch. All power and wiring done correctly, my wifi is an Eero mesh system so no issues with wifi.. I really wish i hadn't waited so long to wire up the TP Link Switch so i could return  it... instead it looks like I'll have a $20 shooting target next time i go to the range. I have several Leviton smart switches installed around the house and i highly recommend them for smart home automation needs.. This TP Link switch is flimsy plastic all the way around, bulky and difficult to fit in a single gang box, and not to kick a dead horse but setting it up is difficult if not impossible.Stick with Leviton, they cost a bit more but... you get what you pay for.. but that's just my 2 cents tacked on to what i paid for this garbage TP Link

I have two of these switch installed at my home.  It's very easy to install it took only 15-20 minutes for me to install. There are many youtube videos explaining how to install it. Remember you need the white neutral wire to install this. I think nowadays most of the homes have it. I have both Alexa and Google Home, it works perfectly with both. When the switch is off then there is a small illumination in the switch (see the attached picture) this light on the switch is really helpful at night if you don't want to use Alexa or Google Home to turn on the light at night. I love it!!!

I have installed a few of these around the house and they work very well. I haven't had any problems with them at all. The only trouble was just fitting them inside the boxes is pretty tight. The first time I installed two in a 4 gang box and it was really difficult to get them to fit with all the other wiring but I got it done. Ideally if you were building a house you would want to oversize the boxes that would use these (e.g. use 2 gangs out of a three gang box). Anyway, they do fit it just takes some care to do it (excess neutral and ground wires tend to be the issue).
