Works perfectly, and falls back to a regular switch if the internet is out. Their app is very nice and easy to use and integrates well with a lot of other services.Important: This switch is not a typical light switch. A typical light switch mechanically connects and disconnects the "hot" wire (the one with power) from the light. For this reason, a typical switch only connects from hot to hot. Electrical installers take advantage of this, and not all electrical light boxes will have all the normal wires (hot, neutral, and ground). Those wires are still connected to the actual light, but not to the electrical box. However, this switch, being connected to wireless and the internet, needs to have the neutral wire. I suspect the people having issues are the ones who are using ground for neutral, which is a mistake in a lot of ways, and is asking for trouble and maybe a fire.

Installing this switch was a bit intimidating, I have to admit.  Wiring anything is a challenge, since so much is at stake.  As an example, burning down the house comes to mind.  However, I am happy to say that all my apprehension was unnecessary once I got comfortable with the process by watching a YouTube video entitled "Installing wemo and converting 3way to a single pole switch."  Though I was installing a TP-Link switch, the task was exactly the same.  I quickly got the steps I had to follow from the video.  Those 3-way switches came out quickly, the rewiring to a single-poll was no longer a mystery and the installation of the TP-Link switches was straight forward.  The guy that produced the video has received lots of appreciation from viewers for making the steps very clear and to the point.  So far, the switches are working perfectly, with Alexa as their new master.  Two new switches all done and buttoned up in a little over 30 minutes.

It looks great and functions very well once installed. It uses Kasa app so I decided to integrate my bedroom totally through Kasa and downstairs through Smart Life to keep them separate. The wiring in my house is weird and I ended up having to seek advice from an electrician. Installation can be a bit trickier than it looks if your wiring doesn’t look precisely like the illustrations. I was finally able to make all bedroom lights operate off that single switch, or through Alexa commands like I wanted. It just took more effort than I expected.

Well replaced meross switch that was a real pain when the power would flicker it would not work so I started looking for a new switch read only good reviews on this switch so I decided to buy it so far so good was easy to install works with alexa and on my Phone we will see if it needs to be reset after a power flicker. It works much faster than the other one linked very fast . One thing that made me crazy was it said that it wasn’t hooked to wyfy so kept resetting and it was linked found out when it came up on my phone pushed button and the light went on and off as I pushed than ask alexa to turn on light and low and behold she did turn it on and off works nicely thank you

I have been wanting to put my outside lights on a schedule for a while.  HomeKit wall switches are really expensive but these were a great price and fit the look of my existing switches.  I struggled at first understanding how to actually wire these up.  They need power all the time so you need to pay attention to how to connect it.  Once I figured that out, installing additional switches was a piece of cake.  Integration with Google Home is also really nice and is easier than HomeKit for me.

I like the switch, it looks like an ordinary switch, and was very easy to set up with Alexa.  The thing is huge on the back, and I had a hard time getting it all the way into the box. I ended up having to rearrange all the wiring in that box, and I still had to force it in, but it did fit.The almost deal killer:  it's not a switch at all. It's a button.  You can only push the part that sticks out, which is normal, but the switch position never changes.  Always the bottom protruding, and the top flush.  I guess I'd rather see the switch toggle, even if the position didn't mean anything, or maybe just have a single button rather than a pretend switch.

Usually I never write review until I'm completely satisfied or see if it's working or not. So I always wait a couple months for my reviews.I bored 11 Kasa Smart Wi-Fi Light Switch and 2 sets of 3 way switches for my house to replacing my regular switches. I'm planning to buy 12 more of them and replace all rest of my regular switches this is including fans and dimmers switches.

These TP-Link devices are just outstanding. I cannot believe how easily and quickly they connect to wifi. This is a replacement for one that stayed on all the time. I did a return and I received it a day early. This one was perfect. I used it to replace an back porch light that was controlled by a photocell. It worked fine but I wanted an LED and I wanted to keep the housing. I bypassed the ballast and got an adapter for a standard base bulb. I also needed it turn off during the time of visitors staying in the bedroom adjacent to the light. I had to stretch out, unscrew the clear bezel, find a towel to cover my hand and pull out a really hot bulb, then screw in the bezel again. Took me forever to get the threads aligned. What a time saver.Also, wanted to thank Amazon for making returns so easy and quick. I have never had a problem. Sometimes I forget just how good they are...not perfect, but oh so close.

Very happy with this smart wi-fi light switch. It was super quick and easy to install, included plate cover is very convenient. I am using to control a flush mount ceiling fixture with LED bulbs, voice control with Amazon Echo Alexa, and already had Kasa app installed for a smart plug. I wanted a no-hub control for a switch controlled ceiling fixture to use with Alexa and originally tried to install

Kasa smart switch works as advertised to control a set of lights on a 1-way connection. Remember that you do have to go through the Kasa app and also Alexa app to set it up. Installation a little tricky. I had a 3-gang switch box and the white common wires were hard to locate initially; turned out they were bundled and stuffed behind one of the other switches. Also the adjacent switch was too wide to allow the Kasa to fit, but its metal edges could easily be clipped off. So be patient and be sure you've turned off the power to the switch box before installing!

I bought the TP-Link smart switch to replace my wemo smart switch. Where the wemo would periodically lose connection with my wifi router the TP switch has had no such issues. I also like that this works with Alexa directly, no extra "skill" need. Installation was as simple as removing old wemo switch and wiring in the TP. I did think the directions in the box were a bit lacking but, still an easy install. They even included nice wire nuts, not the cheap ones that come with some light fixtures. One neat feature of the Kasa app is that you can take picture of the item you are controlling and use it as thumbnail for each switch.  All I all I really am happy with the TP-link smart switch and will more in the future.

I was a little discombobulated with the switch because it could be turned off upstairs or downstairs, however, once I figured it out. Easy-Peasy! If it is a simple one for one exchange, take the plunge. YES, you CAN do it. The extent of my electrical knowledge is single mom ceiling fans. It comes with great directions and if you’re looking at this, you have access to YouTube. All good! 😉Definitely worth it. Can turn off my kids lights without going upstairs. 😁

So, I have now filled my house with all TP link switches, outlets and lights... Their entire library works so very well for our single family 2-story home. Without a doubt, some of the best money I've spent on converting to a Smart Home. From the lovely night lighting in the switches, to the ease of install, fit & finish - the TP Link devices have exceeded all my expectations and made my home so much better.No foolin, just go ahead and buy it, but just be aware, you WILL buy more... and maybe a few more after that. ;)

This is a nice light switch and setup was a pretty simple.  It connected fine to my house internet. But if you want to use it to turn a light on automatically when it gets dark and turn the light off when it gets light, you're out of luck.  In the product description and even in the Amazon Q&A the sellers say it has Sunrise/Sunset mode.  But it doesn't.  I've spent time on the phone with their customer care and then their engineers. What it does have is a timer that turns the light on or off at a certain time.  However, week to week the sunrise and sunset changes so the light ends up switching at the right time, but when it's fully bright out, or hours after it's become dark. I tried connecting it to a sunset service via IFTTT app, but the IFTTT servers are inaccurate and don't deliver reliably, so some nights the light switch just doesnt switch on.  I ended up using the timer mode, which basically makes the whole connected via wifi part of this switch of no use to me.  I would have been better leaving the old GE sunsmart timer in that I replaced to solve this exact issue.  I didn't return it, hoping for some kind of software update.

Bought this as a brand new item . When I got the delivery the item seem to be refurbish since box was open and damage and looks like someone used before . I went ahead in installed . Everything was working fine till the light was flickering and two of my recessed light burned . I called amazon and they offered a return, which I was ok with it since I didn’t want it  . The part that got me upset was when they told me my refund will take 2 weeks . This is outrageous . Beyond upsetting .

I bought this to dip my hand in the whole home automation world. Installation was simple and I was able to pair it to my home connection and my Kasa account. The commands are pretty responsive (strobe light party!!!) and the options for scheduling are pretty handy!I have decided to return it, not because the product was bad or defective, but because after calculating the cost of going all the way on TP-Link, it would be cheaper for me to go with a Z-wave system and a hub. Each z-wave module is about $5~$10 cheaper than each of the TP-Link or other WiFi modules. The other con with WiFi is that range could become an issue when you have a module installed in a far away point of your house.  Z-wave works like a mesh, where each module repeats the signal for other modules to find and repeat again. This ensures that your whole house is covered by the hub.

Bought it, installed it (not as easy and wemo), and I returned it. First off, this and Wemo are practically identical in looks and build other than the indicator light design. Actual install was easy. I got this after I had some use with my wemo switch and setting up the TP-link to the internet was way more frustrating. The app though for TP-link seems to have a bit more features than Wemo. But not a deal breaker for me. I ended up returning it. Keep in mind that if your mounting in a multi switch location, the mounting plates are thicker so you will most likely need to buy a new wall plate to accommodate its thickness in order to get it to sit flush. Unless your lucky and you already have them. If not, the wall plate will stick out around the switch and it looks tacky. If it's a single switch location, the plate provided is pretty nice. But unfortunately my locations are multi switch.

Was planning on upgrade my house to modern home and smart switch is one of key elements.Overall install is not difficult but you need some knowledge on electricity: Hot line, Load line, Nature Line,.....

Worked well for my application which is controlling my 90 year old Moms Taco hot water circulator. My sister who also helps Mom needed access to the switch to turn on for Moms showers and we discovered their is no sharing option in the Kasa app. On the setup side it essential the installation has a white neutral wire to connect to the switch otherwise it just blinks ay you and won’t finish set up.I solved the control issue by adding the Kasa switch to Moms Alexa account so my sister can just say”Alexa turn on Moms hot water circulator”

I have several HS200 and HS210's installed in my house.  I had them installed by a professional electrician.  He said they installed easy enough.  First problem was the first power outage one of the HS200's stopped working completely.  Unable to reset it, no lights, no nothing.  The second problem is even more frustrating.  These lights will turn off and on randomly.  It happens more often when I have them on and more often on the HS210 but even when I have lights off, sometimes they're turn on and then back off.  Frequently throughout a night if I have lights on, they will turn off and then back on again.Now the even bigger issues is the customer service.  I called in and explained the issues.  For the first I was told to "check the wiring".  I said I didn't install them to begin with so I'm not sure what I'd be checking.  Then I was told to hook it up to another light and see if it worked.  There was also some very confusing talk about whether they would send me a replacement because it happened because of a power outage (which is crazy, they shouldn't stop working totally because of an outage).  The 2nd issue was even crazier.  The first answer was try and reset them up in the app (reasonable request), however I told him, I had already done that.  So then the next answer was to check the bulb.  To which I said, "it's 7 lights" and 2 of them don't even have bulbs they're LED lights on a circuit.  It was insisted this was the problem, at which point I told him this was a waste of my time and I'd figure it out myself.

Like the advent of the smart phone, these devices fill a number of needs with one cost effective device.  I've two circuits of decorative outside "Malibu" type lights and carriage lights on a detached garage/shop building.  Previously I had to put on my slippers and go outside to turn these lights on/off during unscheduled times.  I had them on conventional timeclocks that would get off when the power went out and didn't adjust for day length  changes throughout the year.  These devices give me:  Remote control - no more putting on slippers, astronomical clock, always accurate, remote monitoring and control from my cell phone or Alexa type devices.  Solves a lot of problems!  They do require a ground and are somewhat light duty, though I do expect them to last a long time.  Indoor use only.
Man oh man.  I love this thing.  Big time saver.  Peace of mind / security from having our lights come on.  It's nice to drive up to the house at night and have the lights already on.Pros:

So, we slowly moved over to all KASA smart home devices.  Hundreds of dollars.  We got a new, faster, internet/modem/router.  Everything moved over seamlessly EXCEPT for KASA/TP Lynk.  Tried customer service twice and it's useless.  We now have 25+ KASA devices that do not work.  One minute they disappear, the next minute they are only reachable with the app (as opposed to voice),the next minute they work. All of our other devices we still had laying around work fine.  (VeSync, Leviton).  Our Sonos system works fine.  Our elf cameras work fine.  The only issue is KASA, with non-existent customer service.  NEVER NEVER NEVER again!!!

I have a small warehouse which has overhead fluorescent lights.  This switch will work for about a day, maybe two then stop working.  I replaced the switch several times and still have the same problem.  I don't know if the lights are too much, or if it's the nature of fluorescent lights.  The warehouse is small (2,000 sq ft) and the lights are on a 20 amp breaker.  I'm now using a "Lutron MS-OPS6M2-DV-WH Maestro 6-Amp Multi-Location Dual Voltage Occupancy Sensing Switch" which is motion activated and seems to be fitting my needs.  I use this in conjunction with my "Beam System for Remote Communications Plus Dock" to automatically turn on the lights when I remotely visit the warehouse with the Beam device.

I've had plenty of smart-home stuff that was laggy and/or just didn't work very well, but the TP-Link Kasa stuff (at least with the newer versions of the app) is very good. Response to actions in the app is prompt, getting it set up is easy, and the app is pretty flexible for doing things like timing, grouping switches/plugs, etc. I threw out our non-TP Link swiches/plugs and replaced them with these.  Do watch for sales, though -- TP Link puts these on really good sales at least twice a year (Prime Day and Black Friday at minimum).

I have installed about 8 of the Kasa devices: Light switch, Dimmer switch, Wall outlet; Plug in switch. Once installed, the Kasa app finds them an sets them up quickly. While I like the app, I really got them to use  with my Google Assistant. No problem there. They all work with Google. Just note that any of the hard wired products (like the dimmer switch) requires a neutral (white) wire. This is because the wire wire allows the switch to get power even when the switch is off. That said...I am very pleased with all of the Kasa devices.

These smart switches from tp-link the hs200 standard Smart Switch and the hs-210 3-way Smart Switch are both very reliable and good for the few weeks I've had them installed. I like that they have some of their own wires already attached  coming out of nthe plastic encased casing- no exposed metal. Except for a couple terminals on the hs210 three ways ones. I really liked at the HS 200- two of those for my front driveway lights and front door - can be set on a schedule to turn on with the changing sunset and sunrise.  no more remembering to turn on the lights or turn off.

After 1 month the switch quit working.  I contacted TP Link for troubleshooting and replacement if needed.  What a nightmare.  After going through many troubleshooting steps to include removing the switch, and replacing the homes original switch, which worked fine, the technician agreed the switch needed to be replaced.  I went to request an RMA, and the serial number of the switch was not in the system, so I could not request and RMA.  Called to rely the issue and they had no clue all the troubleshooting steps had been completed, and all I needed was a replacement switch.  Now I have to wait for another email from them, then try to input the serial number again, and then if that works, I'll get and RMA in 4-5 days, then maybe a new switch 2 weeks later.  This is way too slow, too many emails, too many phone calls, and not worth the hassle.  As a result of my interaction with customer support, I would not recommend this company for any item.  They make it far too difficult to resolve a simple issue.  I have the receipt, I completed the troubleshooting steps, simply mail me a replacement, but no, they want to drag this out and waste my time.

I won’t give the product 5 stars. Installation was a beast. I have an older home and light boxes aren’t meant for huge wifi light switch receptors. I had to cut the metal side wall that was plastered in, remove the wire casings, shove everything way up the wall, and slowly insert the wires while jamming into the box. Sounds not fun. Then the wiring was off, so I called support cause it said need help. India answered and started to trouble shoot me. I said Dude, are you an electrician? No kidding?Well I played try this and that and it works great

Great switch.  Easy to install, as long as your electrical box has a sufficiently large volume.  The back of the TP switch takes up about as much space in the electrical box as a GFCI outlet.  You also need space for four wire nuts within the electrical box, since the TP switch relies on 4 wire-wire connections (as explained in Amazon's product description page).The one odd thing is that unlike conventional switches that look similar and toggle up/down like a see-saw, the TP-Link switch's lower part always sticks out and acts like a push button.  You push the lower end to click the switch on and you push the lower end to click the switch off.  Even if you were expecting conventional see-saw action, it would work fine: when you look at the switch and see the bottom part sticking out from the rest of the switch, that's what you'll naturally think to push.

Got these from the US amazon store to take overseas in a 220-240V country, they work flawlessly.  I was skeptical at first, but a FAQ  on the official TP-link website confirmed the smart switches were universal voltage UNLIKE the smart bulbs. Here's the excerpt below:" Q: Do our Smart Home products support multi voltage? Can I bring the smart product to other countries for using?

Got a couple of these to use with my Echo. Setup is pretty easy if you have a little electrical experience. If you can change a switch, you can install these. Most difficult part of the install was fitting everything into the box. The switch has a little circle that lights up when it is off so you can see it in the dark. It looks like a rocker style switch but is actually push button. Large rocker switch plates covers work well if you don't line the ones that come with it or like me you have 2 installed next to each other. Once installed and set up it can be operated either manually by pressing the switch, opening the TP Link app with your phone, or by using the Amazon Echo. If the internet is down it works fine as a regular light switch. Overall, I would recommend these as a cheaper alternative to other smart switches.

This product performs exactly as described.  Instructions were easy to follow although they are written only for replacing a single 1 gang switch.  In my install I had a 3 gang switch with each switch controller different lights.  We wanted all of the lights controlled by a single switch. We had to buy a 3 gang decorator style wall plate and a couple of filler panels from our local hardware store (about $10.00)  The only issue we had was that the screw holes for the wall plate that we purchased stuck out too far on the plate to allow the switch to fit correctly.  We easily trimmed the numbs off of the wall plate to make it flush and then the switch fit in perfectly.  After wiring, setup took only about 15 minutes which included doing a firmware update.  Integration with google home was also easy.  Two features it seems to be lacking are the ability to turn off the LED indicator when the switch is off which Not a problem for us but could be for some bedoroms, and there is no ability to have it automatically turn off after running for so many minutes.  The kasa app however does allow you to set a schedule.  so i have mine set to turn off every night at 10pm.  There is also a function in the app to turn it on or off after a specified amount of time, but you have to manually trigger the timer.

Like others have said the HS200 switch by TP-Link is easy to set up and install. The KASA app guides you through installation. I like these switches so much that when we were packing for a recent move I removed all of these switches from the old home and installed them in the new one. I then bought some additional switches. The only issue is installing these switch in a 2. 3 or 4 gang box. They do take up a lot of room in the box so you really have to make sure you move the wire connections around to maximize space in the switch box. Other than that minor issue these are great switches.I recommend.

I had some trouble getting this installed correctly due to my lacking knowledge in electrical wiring. I wired the ground and neutral wires from the switch to the corresponding wires coming from the power source, so the switch turned on, but the lights it was intended to control didn't turn on when the switch was on. The fix was to wire all the neutrals in the box together (source, load, other loads) and all the grounds together. Maybe this was a dumb mistake, but the directions in the app could've called it out as a possibility.Other than my slight trouble with the wiring, the install was easy and everything is working perfectly. I use the switch to automatically turn my outside lights on at sunset and off at sunrise, which took all of 15 seconds to set up in the app.

I have purchased, installed and programmed 13, yes 13 of these switches and four TP-Link HS-210 three-way switches.  I did NOT have an electrician do it because for me it was easy enough to do.  BE SURE you know/understand 120 VAC, how your house is wired, and local electrical code(s) before you start.  Having the the right tools for the job is just as important.  Watch enough a YouTube videos to where you feel confident in what you’re doing.  I also replaced all of the 30+ outlets, 6 GFCI outlets, and five plus regular switches.  This has been a an expensive project costing well in excess of $1000.00 not including tools and spent 6 months in my spare time doing it.  I would do it again if given the chance.

This is awesome!!! Connects right to Alexa! Smoothly operated. The regular light switch use is flawless.Installation was kinda fun because I had to watch several YouTube videos on how to install a light switch but if I can do it than anyone can. With no prior electrical knowledge, it took less than 10 min per switch including WiFi connection.

We have a house built in the 1940's and the electrical boxes are smaller than your modern plastic ones. This wouldn't even fit some boxes and when we finally found one in our home that would, we had to "feed" the supply wires back out of the box into the wall to accommodate the bulk behind this item. I don't understand why the relays have to be so big on a standard 15A switch. The microcontrollers for IoT of this degree can be crammed into the size of two nickels stacked on top of one another...

I love this thing, really easy to install. Download the app first and it'll give you step by step instructions on how to get it installed and set up. Honestly, not sure it could be any easier. You don't need to be a trained electrician but read the instructions carefully. I recommend turning on the lights before turning off the fuse to make sure you turn off the right fuse. Then test the existing light switch to make sure the lights don't come on or flicker. If they are out and no power is running through them, follow the instructions to install your switch. Also, when it is completed, it will need to connect to your wifi, make SURE you know your password. check and make sure before you install the switch. after that, scheduling times for lights to come on and turn off is easy. You can even turn them on from your phone from down the street! I am very satisfied with this purchase. Glad I waited and did my research before buying.

Got this as an intro to home automation.  We wanted to have outside lights turn on at night, off during the day.  With the Kasa app it was easy.  You can choose sunrise/sunset ( I guess it checks the net for this information) or you can specify the time.  Alexa interface is a bonus, as is smartphone control from anywhere.  Now we’re hooked and have started expanding.

I purchased the wi-fi switch to control several LED lights on a single switch in my kitchen. I have been using this product daily, controlled by Alexa, for months without any issues at all.I did have to modify the switch cover a bit as this switch is in the middle of a three switch bank. I had to trim the plastic "stand off" tab off the cover to accommodate the ever so slightly bigger switch. It took 14 second with a box cutter.I love the Alexa application and Echo / Dots in my home. Especially when I forget to turn out the lights when I leave the room. I have everything in a "House" group so at night I can simply say, "Alexa shut off the house" and everything goes off for the night.

I now have these in every room of my house. I love it. My son first told me when he started installing one of them that it was frivolous. Two years later he has now started implementing them in his house. All I do is laugh and smile. Maybe I should tell him I told you so. I highly recommend this brand in particular. The customer service is out of this world fantastic. I only had to call them once after buying 18 of their products. And it turned out to be user error.

No complaints here. Started with one (bedroom) and loved it so much i got 2 more (hallway and living room). I’ve got one of those living rooms that doesn’t have lights at all. So, i set up an array of strategically placed lamps connected to tp smart plugs and hooked up one of my smart switches to the nearest electrical box. I then use the app smart actions to use the switch to turn on the connected lamps. Love it.The first thing that comes to mind for additional features is maybe smart actions that allow double pressing or holding for different functions.

All in all this smart switch meet my needs. I had purchased another brand but its wifi signal could not penatrate  the metal electrical box. No problems with this.Negative the directions are missing from the box and if you do not have access  to the internet when installing you may have problems. their web site does not idenity which  black wire goes to hot and which to load. and it is not marked on the switch. It is indentified in the product pictures which I used

I purchased and just installed this product to have Alexa voice and remote control of my office lights. Overall, this product operates EXACTLY as advertised, almost TOO well! (As it turns out, ANY Alexa device in the house can be used to turn on / off my lights, which means that my family can now mess with me on occasion. (sigh!))As far as installation, I'd recommend that you check and verify that your existing switch's wiring configuration includes a <NEUTRAL> wire to the box. If none is present, this install will be a "no-go." Luckily, mine does, so onward! Now, if you aren't familiar or comfy with working around 120v AC, you should leave this to someone who IS. Luckily, both my son and I ARE, so onward!

This Smart Wi-Fi switch works great.  I have three of them, one for front porch light, back porch light and outdoor Christmas lights. I use the Kasa app to set the on/off schedules (on at sunset, off at sunrise), and while I don't use that often, the integration with Alexa works without a hitch. The switch connects via wi-fi, and I have never had a problem with the unit reconnecting if there is ever an Wi-Fi Internet outage, and the unit has never failed to turn on/off via the schedule.  Very happy with this switch.Note that you should be comfortable working with electricity and electrical outlets to install, but if you have ever put in a dimmer before you will be fine installing this switch.

Dislike:Unit construction.  It is designed with 4 pigtails to connect to the existing wiring.  All this extra wiring and wire nuts makes stuffing it into the electrical box a bit challenging; especially if there are other wires in there.  It would be easier to install if there were 3 screws for wiring connections as is typically found on standard switches and one pigtail to tie into the neutral wire.

First of all, the setup ABSOLUTELY requires the use of a smartphone. If you go to the TP-Link website and search for "Kasa" (the app for this device) you will find NOTHING at all about it. Zilch, zero, nada, nicht, nyenta, etc. I don't understand why a cell phone is required since I also have a laptop/desktop etc. It says it is compatible with Windows 10, but I could find (again) NO app for it (while using Windows 10).I will say however, that at least it only *requires* access to wifi, pix and NOT to all the other stuff some apps *require* such as: Phone number, Contacts, etc, etc. I just want to connect to a light, or a switch, WHY DO I NEED TO GIVE ACCESS TO MY CONTACTS??

The main thing I like about these switches is that someone on the internet hacked the protocol so you can control them without using the cheesy tplink app.  What I mean is, you can write a program or script to turn the switch on or off however you like.  Search for tplink-smartplug.py.I've set mine up to control my whole house fan.  When the outside temperature gets cool enough at night, my computer tells the switch to turn the fan on, pulling in the cool night air.  I know of no way to have Alexa or Kasa operate the switch based on an external temperature sensor.  I do know how to write a simple program to do it myself.

I had a challenge installing them by myself as I was not familiar with what to do with the neutral wires. The directions show you how to hook up a single switch, but they do not show the differences involved if you are installing more then one in the same box. In my case I was installing two side by side. I called support and they were not very helpful. I ended up watching videos on YouTube from other customers and eventually found someone who had the same situation and that helped me out. Otherwise they work good. The app was kind of basic in the beginning but has recently been updated and is getting better. These seem to go on sale about once a month so check the price history and make sure you are getting a good deal

Just bought the switch, then 5 more. I knew going in that these require a neutral wire, but it sucks that it does. I installed two of these with very little issues and started using them with the Amazon Echo immediately. I am waiting for an electrician (my dad) to come help me install the rest of these in a few months when he comes to visit. I wish the price was less, but I bought them when they were on sale, and had a friend buy more for me since there was a limit of 3. I would buy more again if I needed for other switches, but I think 6 will be all I need for my house.I also bought 4 of the outlet mini's and my review is the same. Little on the pricey side, but will be worth it in the long run.

For any room we want a smart light switch I have switched to these as our standard switch. They are great for a location with only one light switch (can't link them for Two or more way setups.) You also have to have power in the switch box.If you only have 2 wires from the light fixture coming down from the fixture box then this (or most any smartswitch) won't work for you.
I like the product, but take a look at the reset button.It is placed so close to the opening of the wall plate that it gets pressed accidentally by the wall plate all the time.

I’ve had two of these switches for around 6 months and the have worked flawlessly.  Easy wireless setup via the Kasa app, then easy integration into the Alexa app.  Straight forward wiring.  Note, you must have a neutral wire; some older houses do not have this wire and the switch won’t work without it. Control by schedule (Kasa app), voice (Amazon Echo), or the wall switch.  I’ve had no issues with it dropping the WiFi connection.  I would buy this switch again.

Once this was set up, it worked fine, but I had trouble with a couple of things.  First, it's large so you want to put this in a deep box.  It's also wide enough to be a tight fit.  There are other devices like this too, so you should expect it.  If you want to put it in a ganged box, the cover plate may not fit so well so use a flexible plate.  My first attempt to configure it failed, I think because of the way the wifi setup was described.  I'm not sure.  I reset it and started again doing it the way I thought it should work and it did.  Connecting it to Alexa requires reading directions while performing actions so use two devices, one to configure Alexa and one to read what to do next.

First, these work fine with TP-Link's own app.  However, there are problems with Alexa.  I purchased two of these switches.  Both installed without problems and worked great for a few weeks.  Then, out of the blue, one switch quit working.  Alexa shows this switch as "offline."  I have deleted it and re "discovered" the switch several times and Alexa still says it is "Offline" and will not control it.  Of course, the reason I bought the switches was to be able to control them through Alexa.  So, the switch is pretty much useless to me now.Update: Nothing made by TP-Link is recognized by Alexa now.  They work great with TP-LINK's own app (Kasa), but the Echos simply will not see the TP-Link devices.  I have tried resetting ALL devices and Echos, but to know avail.  At this point, if you buy any TP-Link product, it might not work at all with Alexa.

I was frustrated by this packaging at first -- very sparse, limited instructions.  However, I searched you tube for a video on this exact product, and found a "how to" made by someone not related to the company, just a user.  With that video's help (go ahead and search for it now), setting up this product with its own app as well as to use with my Echo device was a breeze.  I can control the switch (used for my outdoor entry light) with an app on my phone (click on and off while I'm in bed), or very easily with Alexa/Echo.  "Alexa, turn on outdoor entry."  She says "OK," click.  I'm getting more....

A good way to start with smart switches.  I have no experience in electrical work but it was easy to install and integrate with Alexa/Google home. Step by step instructions were clear. Basic tools are enough for installation.The 2 things I think it needs improvement:

I tried a couple different brands of wifi light controllers and Kasa was by far the easiest to use and integrate. I had no issues getting the switches on my wifi, no issues setting up schedules in my Google Home or in the Kasa app, and have had zero issues after more than 6 months now with switches disconnecting from the wifi or needing to be reset. These just work and I've told many friends and family to buy Kasa switches!

Unit does what it is designed to do. took alittle time to get it to work with ALEXA but works well once connected.Did find that there is a line wire and a load wire (the black wires) . First wire it and lights would not turn on or off via wiifi or manually. had to swap black wires then it worked great.

I bought this shortly after we moved into our house so I could automate some of the lights for the house and it works perfectly! Install was nice and easy (as long as you know the basics of how light switches are wired) and once I had it setup, I haven't had to do much with it! Only annoyance is when I accidentally bump that switch and toggle the light, as opposed to having a traditional switch. But that's not the switch's fault.

This is definitely the best smart switch choice for most people. The product came well packed. Installation was straight forward, I did not use the wire nuts instead I used I-Sure push-in wire connectors. Using the push-in wire connectors, made for a much cleaner and compact installation. I used my android device to pair the switch wirelessly to my router, this operation went flawlessly. Once connected I was able to easily set the switch up in the Google home app and my Alexa app, (Yes I have both!!). The switch works flawlessly, is easy to program and looks great!! I will update this post with reliability in a few months.

I replaced a Wemo Belkin light switch with a TP-Link Wi-Fi Light Switch and could not be happier.  So far the I have not had to reset the link, like had to a lot with the Wemo.  Second, I can connect from anywhere as long as I accessed my router when not in my house through my VPN connection on my phone.  Remote access never worked on the Wemo.  I will be purchasing a second TP-Link Wi-Fi Light Switch for our second home.  Hopefully I will be able to see both switches on my phone based upon my VPN access to both local routers.  That make this switch really fit my needs.

Old Outdoor light timer died and in looking to replace it found this smart switch was comparably priced with much more functionality. Easy to install with a bit of electrical knowledge and fits in with the other decora type switches in my home. Dawn to Dusk feature is perfect for outdoor porch lights. no more adjusting the time for the changing sunrise and sunset. Alexa integration a plus. If it lasts as long as my old light timer, which at the time cost more, I will be very happy.

After reading reviews I fully expected the joy of installing this wasn't in fact going to be a joy. It wasn't difficult, it just takes up so much room in the gang box it takes a bit of planning and work to get it to sit flush and straight. I was able to use my existing double gang switch plate without added effort.This one was my first WiFi switch but it wont be the last, already have planned and budgeted (smart home gets pricey) for a few more here and there. I use the hell out of it but less and less with Alexa voice control (which was a simple integration) and more on the routine/schedule ability through the Alexa app or even the Kasa app as it is quicker to access than Alexa app.

Quick review - this switch is great. It integrates with my Alexa fine and I have been happy with TP link plugs and smart light bulbs.It was pretty straightforward to install, you need some basic electrical skills and PLEASE double check the power is off to the circuit before you begin. I recommend you have a testing tool to make sure the wires are not hot when you start - these tools are only a few bucks.

I like this switch a lot. This is my first WiFi switch and it was pretty simple to install. It controls the light socket that my entertainment center is plugged into. Now, if the kids aren’t listening and doing their homework, I can shit the TV off while I’m at work, lol. It’s AWESOME!  Kids hate it, but that’s ok. The only reason I would give this a 4star instead of 5 is the switch itself. It’s not a toggle up and down, it’s just down and there is a tiny poorly lit circle that tells you it’s off. In the day in a bright room, it’s hard to see. I would have preferred it to be like a normal switch of this style. If they were cheaper I’d buy more and do most of my house with them. Until then, this is the most important one.

These units are so balky you'd nearly need a dual gang box worth of room to install a single gang pole. I only have 2 single gangs in my home where this would be worthy of install and it would not fit in either. The unit is nearly 2" deep alone, then you have to utilize wire nuts to connect it, so you need another 1" of space there. If the design was changed to connect wires directly to the unit, it would be much better off. I had to return, sadly, due to space requirements.

I bought this because of the name brand TP-Link. I had used a few TP-Link products and they never turned me down. However, this switch did not come with instruction in the packaging. I had to look it up on the amazon site.  I had a hard time connect it to my home wifi.  After chatting with a technician online and resetting it three times, it finally worked.  If you are not an electrician with some computer or network background, I don't recommend doing this project yourself.

These are great smart switches that also provide simple manual use controls. I've supplemented them with my Alexa connected home and primarily installed them for exterior lighting I operate with a timer. I am very happy with the traditional look, as these are simple to use as manual switches as well. A guest may not even realize they are smart-switches. I used to have a set with the analog clock and control buttons...but wanted a cleaner appearance. Setup with WiFi and Alexa integration using the App was a breeze.

Where there is sufficient room for four wire nuts, the switches work well.  If you are replacing a switch in a single gang box or a 2-gang box where the other switch takes more than half of the room, you will not be able to fit the large body of this switch in with the four wire nuts supplied with the switch.  If tp-link had provided a way for wires to be inserted or screwed down on this switch, there would have been room but the bulky wire nuts prevent the switch from fitting into the box.

Switches constantly drop from the WiFi and are unavailable to be turned on. This is not an issue with WiFi strength-I have many other IoT devices and none of them have this issue. But all of the TP-Link switches have this issue.For the Kasa app, often it will show devices unavailable and unable to communicate with them. When you try and turn one on or off it will take up to 20 seconds to do so. Meanwhile, if you do it from Google Home, it is much, much faster.

I use these to interface with Alexa to turn on and off lights since I am too lazy to get up and do it.  They are easy to install and with the app, easy to get on the wifi.  I have had no issues with them falling off the network or working as expected.  I do have one that controls the coach lights on my garage and with the app, I was able to put them on a schedule to come on at sunset and go off at sunrise.  I recommend these highly.  No issues.

I love using this light switch, and it's better for non-techy users when they come to my house to have a physical switch on the wall where they expect. I used this to control a fixture with 5 light bulbs, so I save money not buying smart lights but still get all the benefits. Took just a few minutes to install.Minus one star because many times a physical press only registers halfway, so the lights flicker on and right back off. A second press fixes this and the lights stay on, but it's an annoyance. Perhaps it's some issue with the programming, since I normally use voice control for the light. If the physical switched worked the first time every time, this would earn five stars.

I decided to go for switches instead of smart bulbs because the switches were more flexible. If the WIFI or internet goes out, you still have the manual switch to control the lights. These switches interface seamlessly with my Google home setup, which is a big plus. I started with a couple of these switches and I was so happy with them that I have now replaced a little more than half of the switches in my home. Even my wife, who rolled her eyes when I suggested installing these, really likes using them. I will be replacing the rest of the switches in my home moving forward.

Would highly recommend these smart switches to anyone. Easy to follow installation instructions on the Kasa App. Once they are installed on the wall, the smart setup is very easy and the integration with Alexa is seamless. Clean look once they are installed and also fit standard faceplates if you don't want to (or can't) use the provided ones. They also feature a small, dim light on the front when they are powered off to make finding the switch in the dark very easy, if you want to use it manually. Will definitely return to this brand to upgrade additional switches in our home down the line.

I bought the smart switch to try out and hoping it would work out for my home. I bought it in August and installed it myself knowing it was easy to do.Everything was working perfectly for a while up until this past December when my switch started to lock up and it wouldn’t turn off/on manually or on the app.

These Wi-Fi switches are awesome. It allows you to set schedules or toggle the light via the app, but you also get to keep the wall switch functionality. I like this much better than using a Wi-Fi light bulb, as you lose wall switch functionality with those.The downside is install takes some effort. I’m not handy at all so I had my dad do it. It took him some time to figure out, but he did get it done. The other downside is that this one-pole version doesn’t work if you have a 3-way switch.

Works great!  When syncing/setting up device, it picked a neighbor's wi-fi network, and I kept entering my network password to connect.  Of course it did not work. It took me a long time to realize that the network the Kasa device picked was not my network.  It finally picked my network in the setting up process so I could complete the installation.  It  initially indicated a network's name of my neigbors, so I wish the program gives a warning to check the name on the smartphone's screen being displated to make sure it is indeed the purchaser's network before proceeding with entering the password.  This was confusing.  I thought the initial name being displayed was the code name for the Kasa device. Perhaps screen should say “Found Yoir Network:”

Easy to install and set up in Kasa app. This does require a hot, neutral, and ground wire to work. At first I panicked when I opened the wall plate and found only two black wires going into my existing light switch, but looking into the back of the box, there were white and bare copper ground wires twisted up for me to cap into. House was built in '92. Absolutely love these switches. They have a faint circle on the switch that makes it easy to find and press it in the dark (but too dim to actually cast light in the room so it won't bother you if you're trying to sleep). After adding the switch in the Kasa app, it's easy to tell Alexa to "discover" new devices. I did this repeatedly as I installed each one and marveled at the fact I could tell Alexa to turn all the lights off in the house. What a time to be alive!

This thing worked great. My reading skills on the other hand... Long and short of it is that none of the places I'd want this have a neutral wire, so I couldn't use. BUT! It did work admirably, and provided me a bounty of components when i took it apart!5 stars, would misread the listing and spend several hours trying to fix my mistake before giving up and using the thing for parts again ❄️🖤☄️

I own 2 of these, though 1 has yet to be installed.  The one I have controls my bedroom ceiling fan.  Now I can turn my fan on and off with my phone without getting out of bed - and once I get an Echo device for my bedroom, I will be telling Alexa to do it.  It would be nice if TP-link would make a dimmer version, but for a strictly on-off switch, this works great, was easy to install, and looks good, too.I also have several TP-Link Smart plugs (some regular and some mini) - and I like the app used to control them as well as this switch.  I've recently acquired an Echo Show, and setup with the Alexa app was a breeze.
The TP-Link Wi-Fi light switch was so easy to install and easy to connect to our Wi-Fi.I wasn't sure it would work for me, but it connected quickly and the app works perfectly.
Overall, I like it, and recommend it. Love the no-hub approach.Caveats:

Installation was okay. But I had to check on Youtube just to be sure that I was connecting the right cables because the product comes with no instructions whatsoever. But this didn’t bother me since everything is on the internet anyway.The main problem is that I couldn’t go beyond the setup because the switch wouldn’t connect to my wifi. I tried for about 40 min. Sometimes it would find my wifi signal but it said that connection could not be made and try again. Then it wouldn’t even find the signal again.

The app is very easy and the switch works.  We use it for our porch light to set a schedule so it can be on and off based on the time of day.  I can also use the app to turn the porch light on from elsewhere, which for me means my car.  I park in the driveway (no pass through from the garage into the house anyway), and if I want the porch light on so I can see what I'm doing navigating the porch steps and fumbling for the house key, I can turn it on from the car.  My only complaint with this switch is that the entire setup including the switch plate doesn't seem to match up to the regular switch plate that was on the wall.  So it looks strange.

We love TP Link products. We have their routers cameras, switches outlets you name it. We originally bought these because the front flood lights are activated by a switch in the back of the house... I know right.  With Alexa integration it's super easy now. "Alexa turn on the front floodlights", "Alexa turn on the living room fan" etc  for get a few lights downstairs after you have gone to bed "Alexa shut off the downstairs" done, simple, the best thing since those old clapper commercial.

If you were thinking of getting a 'smart switch', GET THIS ONE. The price is reasonable, the directions are extremely clear, and I can't imagine the setup being much easier. I also like that the back of the unit is 'small' -- so it's not difficult to fit everything back into the electrical box (I've suffered devices that are huge which make it challenging to cram back into the box).It seems to me they have really thought through a number of small details that made setting several devices up at one shot easy. Their App is simple, and the Alexa integration is a great plus.

Are you tired of having to walk upstairs to start your attic fan?  Want to schedule it to run in the middle of the night when it's cool outside?  This switch was an easy solution for me.  I had the switch installed and connected to my WiFi in 10 minutes.  Integration into Google Home and the app on my iPhone was super easy.  Now all I have to do is say, "Ok google, turn on the attic fan" and BOOM!  It fires right up.  I love being able to schedule when it turns on and off with the mobile app.

In general, I really like these switches and they do the job as described.  I have a few detailed comments that some might find useful.1.) I really don't like the connections being 'wires' that come out of the switch that you have to connect to with wire nuts.  This takes up much more space than if they had screw terminals just like standard electrical switches have.  Since the switch itself is larger than a standard electrical switch, the extra space taken up by the wires and wire nuts can really be a problem if the box you are installing it in is short on space.

Mine quit working within the warranty period, but they make you pay to return their broken product, which costs about the same as just buying a new one.  What is the point of the warranty then?  They obviously know their products are cheap, and make customers pay for return shipping to deter customers from making warranty claims. I wouldn't buy from this company. You'll waste too much time dealing with support when your products quit working.

Customer support!!  I installed a complete house system 3 1/2 years ago and everything worked fine, for the first 3  1/2 years.  Then with no changes in my home network, one at a time, each device STOPPED WORKING!!  I contacted their customer service (now THAT is an oxymoron!!)  and could not get through to a PERSON TO HELP ME FIX IT!!  AND THAT WAS WITH A SUPPORT CONTRACT!!  I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS COMPANY TO ANYONE!!

I am using this product with an Amazon Echo and Dot. It works great! Setup was easy, once I found out that the product had to be registered via the TP-Link app before "Alexa" would recognize it.A side note, that even though this is listed as a single pole device, I have mine working in a three way situation.  I bypassed "switch one" by removing the switch and connecting the power to one of the load leads with a wire nut.  The other (red) wire I just taped up.  In the "switch 2" position I removed the existing switch and replaced with the TP-Link smart switch. Since the smart switch responds to my voice via Alexa anywhere in the house, I no longer need two point control over the light.

So I was looking for a way to turn off a light automatically a few minutes after it was turned on manually.  It seems that there is a little confusion over this so i hope I can clear this up.YES, you can use this as a timer.  You need to install the app and have access to the "Smart Actions" tab.  For some reason the tab would only say coming soon for a few days and then one day I opened it and it was available.  I set up the action and it has worked perfectly ever since!

I used it to replace a timer system that sort of kept track of local sunset to control my outside lights.  It was a beast to program.  It had a fixed date for daylight savings time which changed and eventually the battery that ran the timer through power outage failed requiring frequent reprogramming Installed the Kasa switch and a very simple Alexa routing and it all works great.  Not effected by political changes in time or momentary power outages.

I found this item to be easy for me to install and the switch works as described. However, for some reason after the initial installation whenever I manually used the switch it would lose its WiFi connection and I would have to go through the setup process again which I find to be easily done. I solved the issue by manually resetting the switch by depressing the small button bellow the rocker lever and this seems to have solved the issue as I have not had anymore issues with the switch, it works great.

Worked well right out of the box. When it says it requires a neutral, that doesn't necessarily mean a "real" neutral.  What it basically means is that this is not just a simple switch that connects 2 contacts, but requires a neutral because it, itself, RUNS on 120V.  In my application I have a 240V transformer splitting into 2x120V pairs.  It works fine connected to those, even though neither is technically a neutral.  As long as you feed it 120V, it will switch the hot side between "hot" and "hot when switched on", basically.  I used it in my water heater controller.

The switch was easy to install.  It is much larger than a normal switch so you need to take care to be sure there is enough room in the electric box for the wires and the switch.  Once installed it was easy to add the switch.  I already had two Kasa plugs for other rooms so it was only a matter of adding the kitchen switch.  It works well with both my Alexa and Google devices.  The Kasa app works well from anywhere I have internet access.  It is good to be able to the lights on and off when away from home with and without timers.

And on came my ceiling fan. It was amazing. And now I will get more things Kasa/echo related. I will have my entire home echo controlled, damn the FBI and anyone else listening to me cry like a lonely girl...(i'm a guy). Seriously I have TP-Link Plugs, switches, bulbs, WiFi Extender. TP-Link is and always will be a favorite company. Their items require no hub, Easy to use and set up app, BEAUTIFUL warranties! Can't go wrong. Now, I need a 3 way switch, but the wiring in this house is a  nightmare. Wish me luck.VERY easy to install, use, etc.

Added three to remodeled kitchen.  So LOVE these switches.  So easy to switch on manually or VIA app. We have the main kitchen overhead light set to go on and off on a varying schedule, along with our Kasa wall plugs for lamps elsewhere in house, to give house a lived in look when we are away for the day or gone on vacation.  I'll update if any negative issues (always do) but so far flawless.  We've had them installed since summer 2019, Today is New Year’s Day 2020.

Be sure to assign the switch a permanent IP in your router, and try to locate it away from other smart switches if you can. If it's in the same box as another switch, you may experience occasional wifi disconnects.Beyond that, this product works well. The Kasa control app is well-done, and the switch integrates well with Google Home.

This is the third one I purchased.  Price is much better now, I paid way to much for the first two.  Either way, they work great, are easy to install (if you understand how a light switch works) and everything you need is provided.Connecting to your wireless is also easily done using the app.

Now that the switch is working, I'm satified, but tp-link gets an F- on customer consideration. There much vaunted KASA app fails to consider that maybe your installation will be on the same electrical circuit as your router. An easy fix would be a file download of the instructions, but customer convenience, they let you figure out on your own how to install without instructions. That's because their app simply stalls when it can't find wifi. Really, are pdfs sooo hard to make? Or might the KASA app be able to walk you through the setup without a wifi connection?

I loved the fact that the switch easily connects to my network via wifi and a simple app downloaded to my iPhone.  The operation is very intuitive and works flawlessly.  You need to know a bit about electricity to safely install.  For example, the instructions state that you need a common wire, so you need to know that this is not the same as a ground, even though it will (unsafely) function using ground for common (no different than any other switch needing a common wire).  With that said, it works like it should.  I could not give 5 stars for two hardware/physical reasons.  First, the size is large and takes up every bit of room in the half of my old wall switch junction box.  If only it were just 10% smaller it would easily fit.  So I had to push and shove and could barely NOT get it all the way in because of the clamps internal to the box.  But, it is close enough, I suppose.Secondly, the switch comes with a nice screwless single switch cover plate, and my box has two switches.  Although that is my problem and not the switch's, a standard two or three switch cover plate (which I bought separately) does not fit completely flatly onto the switch due to its design.  I had to grind down the nubs to help it lay flatter.  The screw threads to fasten the cover to the switch are slightly different also.  So when all is said and done, the cover plate is about 1/16th inch off of the wall.  Lastly, you cannot use the screws that come with the switch to secure the switch to the box... they are almost like wood screws and totally pointless.  So you will need to use the screws from your old switch.

I have 12 Kasa smarthome. Plugs, switches, cameras, strip & they all work good except for the switch & a plug. It works perfect with the Kasa App but having problem most of the time on Alexa voice command. Most of the time they work but at times they do. I replaced the mini plug without solving the problem. I also replace a plug with a switch with same problem. I just don't know what to do. Signal are good, in fact 1 of the mesh router is sitting 3 feet away from the plug. I've gone with tech support many times to no avail. I'm going to replace those 2 with other brand& see if it solves my problem.

the App walks you through the wiring types and the install of the physical switch.  once power was back on, the app connected to the switch and it was configured to my WiFi.  i was able to set some schedules (this is for my outdoor coach lights without a daylight sensor), and also setup Alexa on it so i can play around and see how it works.  going to install a few more in the house next week

I have every type of light switch kesa has and they work great but there is a problem if you get a lot of them.At first it was great that you didn't need a hub! But now that I have so many my wifi crashed because of all the plugs connecting to my router. I fixed the problem by turning my guest Wi-Fi into a smart home wifi. I know that there have a router/ hub but I like my router because it's good for gaming. They need to make a normal hub like Samsungs smart things or even better make it compatible with smart things hub but I don't think that its possible to make it compatible with smart things

Love the ways this switch makes my life safer and easier. I can remotely turn on my porch light if I stay away longer than intended. I never come home to a dark house. I also have one hooked up to my ceiling fan so at night if it gets too hot I no longer have to get up to turn on or off the ceiling fan. I don’t have to search for the remote control. Just tell Alexa to turn on the ceiling fan!

I have now installed these in 5 locations around my home. Most importantly in my carport, flood lights, basement, and deck. All places where I was too lazy to install three ways or wanted remote access. Now, when coming home I can flip on the lights in my dark carport from my phone, or tell Alexa to turn on my flood lights if I hear something outside instead of walking through my house to hit the switch. I have not had any trouble installing any so far and wifi reception is great. This is the future.

I can't say how much I love these light switches. My alarm company wanted over $100 to install a similar product which would also definitively tie their usefulness to me staying with the alarm company indefinitely. It's so handy to be able to set timers and create "scenes". For instance I have outside lights on a timer for when my wife gets home from work. I have the garage lights set to be on about 5 minutes prior to when I normally arrive home and turn off about 10 minutes after. Or I have a "scene" for when I arrive home at night so that I hit that scene and my front outdoor lights, garage lights, and entryway/kitchen lights all come on at one touch of the screen on my phone. Very handy and useful item. Also, it was very easy to set up. The app walks you through wirelessly connecting the switch to your network once u have it physically installed. No fuss and worked great right out of the box. I'm Impressed and I'll buy more in time.

I don't know jack about electric. I see the same color wire and I connect them and bam it works. Thankfully I have a white wire that was in the back of the wall. I am surprised I haven't burnt down the house but it works so I'm cool with it. I use this on my ceiling fan. Wife doesn't like the fan on all night but cool with it for 3 hrs or so. I set a timer on the app to turn off every 1230am. Now I fall asleep to fan and it's off so she doesn't get a stuffy head. Win-Win. Plus Alexa will turn on when we are lazy in bed and don't want to walk 12 feet to the switch. Life is good man!

I have several of these throughout my house for various switches including lights and fans. The install and set up is very easy to figure out for someone without previous experience with electrical work. The app is very easy to use, and the fact it works with Google Home allows me to create a lot of automation and schedules for my lights within my home. I plan to replace more switches over time with these.

Don't know why I didn't think of doing this sooner but finally put an Alexa-integrated light switch in my laundry room so I could turn the light on and off when my hands were full. There were several to choose from but very pleased I chose this one. Was very easy to install, and I have had no issues whatsoever with it so far. Now thinking of installing one where I have ceiling fans without remotes!

I really like the Kasa ecosystem and only buy these products. I like the dimmer version and bought this switch for another use. I am disappointed that this switch doesn't have a removable wallplate mount like the dimmer does. If you don't use their wallplate which I don't, it causes yours to stick out a tiny bit. Why wasn't this switch like the dimmee I bought earlier?

Love these!  Got one to control my porch light, and the other that controls the two lights on either side of my garage outside.  Easy to install, fit in the standard box.  One of them I used the faceplate that comes with it, the other did not as it is in a group of three switches where I have a cover with three openings.  Fits in perfectly!  I have both integrated with Alexa to turn on and off based on a schedule.

Installation was pretty damn simple. Just be aware that it's larger than standard light switches and with the additional wires, it can take some work to get more than one (or sometimes even one) of these to fit.Works with my Google Home just fine. Wife is loving it. For anyone who cares, I replaced the switch for the bathroom vent and it works there just fine, too. It knows when it should be on or off, unlike the first generation of smart light switches.

if you dont have the DiY experience to install this you can try you tube tutorial but dont recommend "winging it"i have some electrical experience and it took me a minute to figure it out with confidence

I’m usually extremely picky and over critical about smart home stuff, as I’m sort of a technology snob.These light switches are gold. Decently priced, mobile apps are surprisingly well designed and work very well, easy-ish to setup, very reliable, and just overall amazing. I’ve purchased about 16 of these, yes, sixteen.

I'm a big fan of the TP-Link Kasa Line. I bought some of these because it makes it so you can turn lights on and off both by and or by voice (As opposed to the smart bulbs that always need to have power going to them by the switch to control them.) App is easy to use and installation instructions were very clear. I had to watch an additional youtube video because  my apartment was wires a little weird, but all in all it took about 20 minutes to get it all set up. Highly recommend if you're considering buying it.

Literally, the switch did everything after it was connected to the wall. All I had to do was name the switch and type in the wifi password when asked. It even connected with the Echo dot by itself and almost immediately responded to Alexa. The app is easy to use but you wont have to do much. I had another brand that blew out. It was very difficult compared to the ease of setting up the TP-Kasa Switch. Highly recommend.

I installed this switch to control a built-in LED ceiling lamp. The circuitry of this switch and the ceiling lamp appear to be incompatible. The ceiling lamp flares with a surge when the switch is turned on, and the settles into about half energy level.The switch might work with an incandescent light, but who uses incandescent lights?

I bought 5 of these and love them.  Easy to install and every single one works the first time. I had WEMO but was frustrated by the price and some challenges from time to time. I still have 2 WEMO but I will probably replace them over time.I use this with Alexa as well as the KASA app that comes with it.  This is exactly what I was looking for. No hubs, no challenges. It just works right out of the box with very little setup.

This switch was very easy to install and connect to the network. The box I was working in was very tight but I was pleased to find neutral wires in the switch box that were joined together with a wire nut. I added a pig wire from the neutral bundle to the switch. Based on this purchase I ordered a 3-way switch from TP Link. I'm very pleased with the tp-link Line Products and I think they represent some of the best smart home technology on the market.

Nice easy to install product. I like the interchangeable functionality with different face plates. It worked with a smaller faceplate I had because the opening was very small and recessed. The plate it came with was too large but it interchanged easily with a standard faceplate. It hooked up and worked the first try. Easy peasy.

This switch is a quality product. I bought one to try it out. It did not disappoint me at all. The packaging is clean, it even includes wire nuts. It was very easy to install. Not only is the switch itself clearly labeled, the app has directions as well. It comes with a  very nice switch plate, although I didn't use it for my installation. I installed it in my pool equipment control box on the side of my house to control my pool light. The main reason I got this switch is be able to turn my pool light on and off remotely. The app for controlling it is super easy. I can turn the light on from my phone anywhere I have a signal. I also set it up with my Alexa so I can say "Alexa, turn on the pool light". It is really cool. I bought two more switches and have put one of them on the pump for the waterfall in my pool. Note: This was installed to control the relay for the pump. I think the pump draws more current than this, or any, switch should be expected to. You won't be disappointed.

I’m half way through outfitting my whole house in TP Link switches, 12 so far, very happy with my decision to go with TP Link products. Very simple to install, even a novice can hook up 4 wires and a new wall plate. The Kasa app is straight forward and your switch is operational in less than 10 minutes.Very reliable WIFI connection and have no issue with signal drops. Even when/if the switch loses power/signal connection, it re-connects on its own automatically. I know this because when I turn off the power to install more switches, once power is back on all previously installed units work perfect- every time.

It works. Seems like a lot of the negative reviews here are for the power plugs and other similar devices, but this is a simple device that does its job well. This switch went to my bedroom where it controls the overhead lights, and it's so convenient to sit in bed and kill the lights when I'm ready to sleep. Or set a timer. Or have it on when I'm downstairs and ready to go upstairs. Since then, I've added a switch to control the porch lights which is now set to automatically track sunsets, and for the office and the dining room to provide a one-button solution to turning on all the lights when I get home.Installation was a breeze. I have a house that was recently remodeled and rewired so I had no issues with grounds and neutrals. The fixtures I have are simple single-pole lights so it was as straightforward as it could be. I think I had more difficulty in getting it to see my wifi if only because I don't broadcast the SSID, so that had to be done all manually. For whatever reason the Kasa app took a few minutes to fully recognize any new switches I added but since then I haven't had any issues with it disappearing or needing to reconnect them to the home network.

If you have one black, one white and one ground (copper or green) wire, connect the black to black, other black from the switch to the white wire, then the copper/green wire to the white AND green wires. It works perfectly.Also, if you're having trouble connecting the echo, go to the Kasa app, select on the switch, go to settings (on the upper right) and enable "Remote Control". Then go back to the Alexa app and connect it to the switch.

I have tried 4 differnet companies that produce products like smart bulbs and switches for Alexa.  Kasa is the only one that has been 100% reliable and easy to install.  I have had no issues installing and using the Kasa products or apps with my Alexa Show or echo dots.  I will only buy the Kasa products from now on.  The switch was not to difficult to install.  I'm not an electrician; i just watched a Youtube video and did it myself.  Buy this one.

This is the third one I installed. The instructions are not good and just to let everyone know, the two black wires are the switch leg wires. Tech support did not understand me when I called them regarding this question. You will need a white neutral to make the switch work. I had red and black switch leg wires which threw me off,  until I  figured out that the red was part of the switch leg.Follow up to my review. Today 3/2 17 they are decided to stop working with Alexa and can only operate locally. No remote operation. It seems that looking at the reviews this is a very common problem. I tied everything, and I am computer literate, but with no luck. Amazon needs to look into this.

I bought these to replace cheaper LYASI switches that did not want to pair after changing routers. After spending almost a week wanting to pull my hair out I finally decided to buy what I knew. I have had a TP-Link smart outlet for my son's tv for over a year and I have never had issues with it. I live in an area that I have to change routers at least twice a year and the outlet has always been so easy to repair it. So I bought these switches and I love them. It took me no time at all to pair them to my Kasa app and it was easy to install. It might cost more than the Lyasi switches but it will save you in headaches!

Easy installation (neutral wire required) and set-up.  The app has only very basic programming so to get more out of these, you'll want something like Stringify (free app).  I'm far north, so sunset and sunrise times change a lot over the year and it is great to have times adjusting automatically.  With Stringify, my front lights turn on 15 minutes after sunset  and then turn off at midnight.  I plan to buy additional smart devices and add more smart things to my home.  The Kasa switches have worked perfectly in the 6 months I've had them.

Great light switch. Picked it up for scheduling when we're away so the lights continue to go on. The set up was easy with some very basic electrical know-how. Same went for the WiFi setup. took me about 5 minutes to get the whole thing in and going.Extremely impressed by just how fast the on/off switching works from the phone - practically instant.

I just installed this today and it was a breeze. I was worried it wouldn’t pair easily with Alexa but it was flawless. I live that it can be set with timers or by sunset. Looks great with other decors switches. I used to be an electrician for four years wiring houses to get through college so I do have an electrical background, but anybody could do this themselves very easily. Great product!

Works like a champ. I removed the existing light switch (which was not using a neutral wire, nor a ground) and installed the new TP-Link switch. It would not work until I wired-up the neutral (my fault, per the item's title here on Amazon), but once ground, neutral, and hot were scotch locked correctly it started working great. Kasa app also works well. Updated the switch firmware and set a schedule for sunset to sunrise. Has worked every night. Highly-recommended.

I sometimes leave for work during the day but don't get home till after dark. with this switch I dont have to leave a light on during the day when I'm at work burning electricity. when It starts getting dark I turn a light on so It looks like Im there. also nice to walk in and be able to see Instead of trying to find a light switch

These devices work great until they don't work. In my experience, they are not as good as the HS100 because they do not automatically reconnect to your wifi if you ever lose the wifi connection, which can happen often in my house because I reboot my router nightly so as to maintain the best signal. I have a bunch of wall plates (HS200) and a HS100 plug which always recover their connection. Not so the HS105.TP-Link customer service tells me I need a firmware update but there is no way to get it to me since I use a MacBook. So, they sent me a replacement unit with the same old firmware on it. Guess what---the replacement unit is just as defective as the original!!!!

Oh man this thing is awesome.  After receiving my amazon echo for Christmas, I purchased two of these to replace the living room light and fan switches.  I was a bit concerned as it is hard to see if anyone was able to replace a 2 gang switch with 2 of these, and have them both fit in the original 2 gang outlet box.  Well, they both fit great!!  Once wired, setup was easy.  The only complaint I have isn't with this product, but just the fact that the 2 gang wall plate that I purchased separately, while it fits, doesn't necessarily fit flush with the wall.  Not noticeable to anyone but me though.  I think I just need to find a bit thicker and better quality plate and it will be perfect.

Switches were easy to install and configure. I purchased four to control the fans and lights in the master bedroom and living room. They connected to Wi-Fi easily and were easily discovered by Alexa on my echo dot (have two echo dots as well). They have worked flawlessly for the month that I have had them. I love being able to lie in bed and tell Alex to turn on/off the fan, turn off/on the lights.
