My TP-Link WiFi switch is working great. However, I have one issue. The switch turns my rear lights on at sunset and off at sunrise. My two TP-Link smart bulbs, in the front of my house, are also set for sunset and sunrise, but they operate at a slightly different time (5 or 10 minutes) compared to the lights on the switch. Shouldn't sunrise and sunset times, based on my location, be the same for the switch and the bulbs?

I love this switch.  I'm just getting started with the smart home thing, and this product arrived quickly, was easy to install myself, and works perfectly.  It was simple to locate and set up with the Kasa app and I love that I don't need a hub with TPlink products.
Piece of cake to install and got online just as easy. I have two of these in a group in my Alexa profile set to go on at sunset and off at sunrise. Great solution.
Easy to install, if you do not have a neutral wire you can't connect the white wire to ground and it works perfectly.
This was very easy to switch with the original switch.  Easy to add to the wifi and works beatifully with all the alexa units,in the,house.

Not truly accurate, if you want this device to control other TP-Link devices you will need a hub. These things can be controlled by smart phone, but cannot control other devices. I wanted to use it to control a remote TP-Link plug, but it cannot.
I have been very satisfied with this product and how well it works.  Alex's interaction is great and the app is very user friendly.

Great WiFi controlled light switch (with Amazon Echo, Echo Dot - Alexa!). Really slick for SINGLE switch controlled circuits. Can be used for fan control too. Be sure to realize, NO 3-WAY SWITCHED CIRCUITS (2 switches for same light or cluster of lights). I called TP-LINK Tech Support to help me with an issue I'm about to describe. The rep indicated TP-LINK is working on a 3-Way switch released sometime this year. Introducing a 3-way will eliminate the need for Smart Light Bulbs. More cost effective for clusters of bulbs. At today's costs, 2 WiFi bulbs @ ~$17/each = 1 HS200 (considering Amazon's cost of $34.99). Approximately. More bulbs to control makes HS200 more cost effective.Issue: HS200 instructions suggests connecting BOTH black wires to "HOT". Hot would be Line - the Black or Red wire from the electrical panel. (NOTE: Romex 2-wire will have 1 black wire, Romex 3-wire will have 1 black wire AND 1 red wire along with 1 white wire and one copper wire in sheath). Typically, a switch connects the LINE (hot) wire to one contact and LOAD (light-side) to the other contact.

I purchased 2 of these and they do work as described.  However, the initial setup takes a while.  I had to power cycle the units each about 5-6 times for them to find the WI-FI link.  One of the good things about these, is that you do not have to use a hub.After it was all said and done, the product pretty awesome.  I only with they weren't $30 each or I would make sure I had one for every room in the house!!

If this product had a dusk/dawn on/off option in the schedule program, I'd have give it five stars.  The installation, both physical and wifi, were a breeze with no problems.  Each one took less than ten minutes to complete.  I like the useage and power monitors as well.

We have a detached garage with outdoor coach lights. Installed this very quickly. I now have the lights set to turn on and off at set times. No more having to walk out back to turn the lights on and off each day.

I installed this switch in our master bedroom over my wife's objection and now she loves the convenience of the voice control feature.  The Alexa app makes it easy to operate remotely when I am away to control my lights.  I would recommend this product and I would purchase it again.
I just love it. I sit in bed and get too lazy to get up and close the light. All I need to do is askAlexa to close the light!!!
Will only work on four wire, neutral houses. I was disappointed there is no other way to use it. Now it sits in a box while all my other smart items work.

This switch is is a great easy 25 minute project to turn your switch in to a smart switch. For me, the set up was very easy to complete and works very well. It was also very easy to pair with the Amazon Alexa which is what I primarily use to control it. the only concern is that you need to make sure the you have a neutral wire before you purchase it. I ended up using a smaller set of twist wire connectors to fit everything in the box. Other than that it's great.

No more plug-in timers.  Set a schedule on the app and forget about worrying if the lights were turned on or off.
This switch is an easy install and works great. I have one setup on a daily schedule for my outside lights and no problems at all.

These don't work with any 3-way light switches - i.e. two switches that control the same light. You wouldn't think that would make a difference, but these would require a bit of soldering to make those work.

I like Kasa app and it is easily link to Google Home.
Easy to install and use. Had to be reset once, but that was easy to do too.

Working well so far. I had to change the switch from a three port to a single which I had to YouTube and Google how to do and the wall plate was also difficult to get on and I had to buy a different one from Home Depot so it would fit better. But other than that it works great with Alexa
I great switch. One of the best I have owed.
I really like TP-Link products.  They are reasonably easy to install and work as advertised.  The products are particularly well suited to Alexa and to the Alexa App.
Totally easy to install and very easy setup process.  I almost have my house converted to these switches.

It works. I like the design.But it does not have the auto-off timer at the firmware level. You cannot press the switch and expect it to be off after xx time. Instead you have to use the mobile app to manually set the timer every time.

These things are awesome. I replaced the old switches for the driveway lights and the front porch light with these tp-link smart switches. They allowed me to set a program for them to turn on and off at dusk and dawn automatically. Also with Alexa I can command her to turn them on and off and it works every time. The best part was installation was easy and no smart hub is required. Time will tell to see how it holds up.

Got it so my wife could turn the light off without getting up because of a broken leg. Works well with app and Alexa. Two caveats: 1. It only works with a 2.4 wireless network. 2. My light switch only had a black, white, and ground wire. I had to attach both the green and white from the switch to the ground from the box. Then connected the black wire to one of the black wires on the switch. Then the white wire to the remaining black wire of the switch. Works great now.
A great, and affordable way to add remote devices to your Homeseer network where Z-wave doesn't reach, like an out building.
High quality and easy install. Also has a good connection for being 100' away from my AP.

very easy to setup and the connection is very reliable.

My father is using it to control a single switch that connects to a fan/light combo.  Now his basement "man cave" is totally smart!

By far the best purchase for a smart home that I made. The switches are easy to install and set up. I have 7 switches and one plug from TP-Link. They work instantaneously and never lose WIFI connection. The scenes set up an easy way to turn multiple lights and fans on or off. This is another addition to my "smart home" and Alexa controlled devices. Simple installation if you've installed a switch before. Connectivity to my WIFI and was a breeze. It does not appear to be cheaply made. I would recommend it and buy it again for other rooms.

We love this wi-fi light switch! We had looked at getting Wink hub and bulbs awhile ago but ended up not because the only way to turn the on or off was with our phones, and we didn't want that. We wanted the option to either use our phone or a switch. So after we had gotten an Amazon Echo Dot and stumbled across this Alexa-compatible switch, we took a chance on it. Installation was pretty straight-forward, pretty much the same as a regular light switch. Once I got in installed I set up an account and added this switch and it worked right off. I then got it set up to work with Alexa and since then we haven't used our phones with this once, we always just tell Alexa to turn it on or off or we physically hit the switch if we're over near it. We like how the switch is a physical switch that clicks and springs back and not just a touch pad. Maybe others feel different but we like the feel of a switch. We haven't yet tried it out when the wi-fi has been down so I'm curious to if the physical switch will still control the lights without wi-fi. If you've tried this please leave a comment about what happened.
Purchased 2/ one to control garage coach lights and the other for porch light.Alexa compatibly makes programming simple.

These are fantastic switches if you just need a basic on/off switch. The switch will not work if you have 2 or more switches controlling the same light (3-way switching).I've installed tons of switches, lights, electrical boxes and plugs and I found these to be exactly as easy as any other switch to install. A nice touch is that the pre-attached wires on the back of the box are already exposed and the ends are soldered so there's a nice surface to attach to the existing home wires. You need to verify that the box you're planning to install the switch in is of standard depth and now shallow before ordering because these switches are very deep. You also need to make sure there's a common wire in the switch box you're updating. This is usually a white wire that is capped to another white wire in the box and not connected to the current switch. Regular light switches don't use this wire, it just by-passes in the box. You will usually have this wire if there are two sets of wire coming into the box at the switch. Some switches are at the end of the line on a circuit and they will have both the white and black wire already connected to the switch. In that case, when the white wire is connected to the switch, the white wire is NOT A COMMON WIRE. It's only a common wire if it's NOT CONNECTED to a traditional switch. I hope that helps with some of the confusion I've seen in other comments. As for the other important things about electrical work like turning off the breaker, please make sure you have some type of voltage meter or power line detector. Just because the light goes out doesn't always mean that there are not live wires in the box. Some boxes have more than one circuit running thru them.

I bought this switch to go along with my TP-Link smart plugs. I had high hopes that I would be able to control most of my electric world with Alexa. To my disappointment this switch could not be installed in my house. When I opened the box I found it had two black wires. At first I thought it was a 3 way switch so I contacted TP-Link. This is a single pole switch and the second black wire is a load wire that MUST be hooked up. Well my house does not have a load wire in any of my current switches. TP-Link sent me the installation diagram, which does not come with the switch BTW and it confirms that the second wire is needed. The answer in their doc is to hire an electrician to install the switch. Sorry I am not going to pay for an electrician so unfortunatly the switch went back. I think they should make this clear in the sales info. Hopefully some of y'all will read this and save yourself grief.

Finally! A smart home solution that actually works and is very simple to install and use. I've gone through a significant number of other devices like this (Wemo, Insteon with HomeSeer and others) and had difficulties with reliability. The Insteon devices sometimes worked, but not reliably. Plus, using these devices with one of the many hub hardware/software options  expensive and has usability and maintenance troubles of its own. If you're a techie with deep pockets and lots of free time, and a very patient spouse, these might be OK.The TPLink Smart family of devices are so reliable and easy to use it is almost unbelievable. I have the wall switches, bulbs and smart plugs and all work perfectly.  The remote functionality works fine over my Verizon Home Wireless router (no issues with needing incoming connections, port forwarding or other ugliness of this sort). I'm using the Android Kasa app, and have not encountered any issues at all with it. The scene support is fairly basic (allows you to group a number of commands/devices into one user action, e.g. "arriving at my home" turn on lights"), but sufficient for my needs. works well with alexa. very helpful. We used it instead of adding a 2nd switch in a new location - the wiring would have been difficult because of through wall distance.
The switch works immediately regardless if it's set up to your network I'm hooked now I wana replace every switch in the house

Easy setup. Pay attention. Neutral wire is needed or these won’t work. There were white neutral wires all rolled together in my switch box from prior install. I ignored them first. When this didn’t work I pulled them out and added the neutral part it now works.
Installation and setup was a breeze! Will buy more.

Good solution. Toggles only one direction, allowing an always on state. This is ideal. Other switches can be toggled off, forcing you to manually turn on the switch before you can manipulate the switch via your devices. I recommend this style of switch.

I did the wiring and verified the electrical works. I got the switch connected to my phone on its wifi. At this point Kasa says "Unable to Connect". I reset the switch and Kasa a few times but still get the same result. The TP-Link web site claims to have 24 x 7 phone support. I called on Sunday afternoon and after wading through their broken phone tree I got a message saying there was no support today. Been waiting on the chat queue for a while but there is no indication anyone is there  I sense this product is more Chinese electronic garbage. Later I was able to talk to someone at TP-Link. However the phone agents have very little knowledge of the product and severe language issues with English. I was promised a connection to a supervisor but then promptly disconnected.

Great product to use with Alexa.  Very easy to install.  I used it to operate my kitchen ceiling light which is a real helpful way to operate the light when your hands are busy cooking.  I only wish they worked with a double switch set up.

I bought this to repair a switch for a friend.  This arrived on time and worked as expected.  Exactly what I wanted.

These switches were easy to install, had excellent instructions and once set up (and firmware updated) can easily function on their own private unconnected network and/or a custom home automation solution. I'd actually call these switches a little over-engineered and that's a good thing.

automated my porch light so it will come on at dark and go off at midnight..

Top quality. Easy to install and overall awesome product. Makes everyday convenient and you'll impress a lot of people.

I am gradually replacing all my single-pole switches with the HS200 and operating them with Alexa.  This project will eventually grind to a halt until 3-way/Alexa switches are available (I do not want a hub-based solution to the 3-way problem).

These switches work great both through the Kasa app and by manual operation.  They also look elegant with a circle design that lights up when the switch is powered off.  The light on the circle design is bright enough that you can see it in the dark, but not bright enough that it lights up the room and won't let you sleep.  I have had them for only a few days, so I can't speak to their longevity-- but so far, we really like them...
Simple install. The Kasa app is simple and the Alexa connectivity was also simple to enable. Turning on the lights couldn't be any easier now. I look forward to adding more of these in my home.
Worked great and good price
Love it! No need to run additional wiring and switch.

I recently purchased 3 of the HS200 Smart Light Switch, and 3 of the HS110 Smart Plugs. They all arrived yesterday, and I finished the install a few hours ago. The setup and install went very well, with one small caveat. The light switches needed to be installed side-by-side in a single, 3-gang box, so I could not use the included oversized single covers and gaskets that came with each unit. And the 3 gang plastic cover that was installed over the old switches was slightly too small for the new smart switches--it kept depressing the 'restart' and 'reset' small push buttons beneath the lever switch. I had to file the short sides of the cover in all 3 positions to give a little more clearance, and after that all went as planned.The Kasa app found each of the devices, and in a short time they were all set up and functional through the app. I also created some 'scenes', and set a schedule for some of the lights to come on at sunset. The smart wall switches control an outlet in my bedroom, the ceiling fan, and fan light.

Works as advertised.  While the ability to turn on/off using an app is cool, the in-built sun-rise/sun-set scheduling is the real winner here.  Awesome for porch lights - you can now do away with the ugly light sensor box fixtures.
Works great with google home and as a manual switch. Setup is no more difficult than any other "smart" device. Also, there's a small light on the switch that's helpful when the room is dark.
I love this product
Love this works great with alexa
I am loving this switch! I have this setup with my porch and outside lights. I have them setup on a schedule to turn on at dusk and turn off at dawn. Everything works perfect!!!
Works perfect, is the best solution when you want to control more then one fixture (led lights in my case) at once!
Works great with Alexa and easy to install.
Love it! It’s nice being able to use my light as an alarm clock and turn them off from bed.

Kasa makes solid products. This is no exception

I own 3 different brands of smart switches because I've been playing with automating my house. I don't have a hub yet because that seems like a commitment I don't want to make in experiment mode, so I went the WiFi connected route along with my Google Home.First, the TP Link switches are the least expensive of the ones I've tried. Second, they're directly integrated with IFTTT, Stringify, and Google Home. The real secret sauce is being integrated with Stringify - this adds loads of power. I can get the same results with the other switches except that I need to have Stringify trigger an IFTTT applet which then does what I want to the switch.

Easy to install and set up with the Kasa application. This is my 4th TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi device. All are working perfectly with Alexa and the Kasa app. Now I need switches to control multi-pole and ceiling fans.

Super easy to install, works perfectly. I had this installed and operating from my smart phone in less than 15 minutes - and that includes the time it took for me to figure out which circuit breaker to turn off! I'm pleased and impressed!

I installed a couple of these switches to control my hallway and living room lights, I got 2 switches installed, setup with Kasa, then setup with Google Home and Alexa, it took me about an hour to set it all up including wiring in the switches and that was after having a few beers. I can now turn on and off everything with my voice I have had no issues with these switches at all, honestly was expecting some issues but it all worked fantastically.  I also have a couple of the mini wifi plugs from Tp-link and those work very well also.I intend to buy about 8 more of these switches to control all the main lights in my apartment.  One thing I really like is I created a group that has all my smart lights in it and I can say "Alexa turn on/off all lights"  and all my lights will come on or go off at once, this is great for those nights you think you may hear something in the house, if you turn on all lights anyone in there is likely to run, also nice at bedtime you can just go to your room get in bed then ask Alexa to turn all lights off.  Look forward to when I have all my lights setup with smart switches (or plugs if it is a lamp).

Utter failure.  I wired up the unit to replace my outdoor light switch.  I wired the wires correctly.  I could see that the unit powered on.  Pressing the switch, it would like up a ring, but my lights wouldn't turn on.  I figured I'd try linking it to Kasa in case they required it.. and Kasa failed the connection at the end where I enter in a name for the device.  I followed the instructions to retry by holding the reset 5 seconds.. but it auto connected to my network, and wouldn't let me re-establish a link.  I then tried to do the "manual" method, where you need to connect to the unit directly via WiFi.  There was no WiFi network matching the name given by Kasa.Now I went into debugging mode..  I could hear a relay click, but no voltage power was travelling down the Neutral line from the Live wire.  I confirmed with my Fluke Volt Detect that no power was coming out.  From here I figure it's a problem with the relay.
So convenient! This switch can be controlled manually, by my Echo Dot (voice), and my phone.I installed it in an area that was always easy to forget and inconvenient to turn off! Love it!!

I chose this over Wemo because of price, especially when it was on sale.  Whether it's TP-Link switch or bulb, they all work with Alexa without a hub.  One down side to their product is the lack of IFTTT integration.  It doesn't work directly with Nest either.  If you are looking for smart switch and bulb to work with Alexa, this will do the work.  You might really want to think about the IFTTT integration and if you need that or not.  For example, I have this switch in garage.  Using SpotCam and IFTTT, when the Spotcam in the garage detects motion, like garage door being opened, IFTTT can be triggered to turn on the Wemo switch.  Can't do that with TP-Link switch.  Yes, depending on the server issues and etc, IFTTT sometime takes way too long, but it hasn't been much issue for me.This switch looks and installs same as Wemo switch.  You will have to make sure you find the right wires, but it should be straight forward once you open up the switch on the wall.  The app will also walk you through the installation process.  I have several of TP-Link switch at home now and they all work really well.  Switch has little white halo, so it's really easy to see the switch at night.  I replaced couple of my dim switch with this as well.  No, this switch does not have dimming function, but I really didn't need that.
Directions were easy to follow for a DIY install and I had several up and running in no time!  Defiantly more in my future!

Using this in my garage which is an outbuilding so wifi control of the entry lights is great.  I ask Alexa to turn the lights on then can walk out with ease.  This beats other solutions i've tried.  Install and setup were easy.

It's unfortunately not mentioned anywhere, that this switch requires a neutral wire in your current switch - or you need to be able to pull one in from somewhere else. Without that, it doesn't work. Trust me, I've tried.

I gave this product a 4 star review not because it is an inherently bad product but because the install was not as easy as was stated and the customer support listened to my issue and told me the switch would probably not work where I was trying to use it... But in the time it took them to come up with the answer I had figured out how to fix the issue myself and now its working great.  This would be a 5 star product had the customer service behind the product been a little better.  My issue with installing it came with the fact that you need a neutral wire.  I knew this was the case and my home is new construction as of 2010 so I knew I had neutrals in all of my boxes so I wasn't really concerned with that.  Once I went to install it though I had multiple neutral wires in the back of the box and from most things I read it wouldn't matter which neutral wire I used and this seems like it is true as I got the switch installed and my power back on everything looked good!  Even got it connected to wifi... But then when I went to click it on for the first time the light flicked on then the switch rebooted and the light shut right back off... I couldn't figure out what was wrong as I wired up everything just the way it stated to so I tried giving customer support a call..  I got through to someone pretty quickly but it was pretty apparent within a few minutes of talking with them that they had no idea what was wrong and the conversation wasn't the easiest to have as the English was pretty broken...  Eventually the lady on the other end of the line told me to take a picture of my wire setup and she would forward it up to her higher level department and call me back within an hour.  So I did this and continued to trouble shoot the problem myself... So I tried tying the neutral wire from the unit into the big bundle of neutral wires in the housing instead of just one and then it started to work perfect... Wasn't to long after I got it solved that customer service called me back and told me the higher level came back and said that it wont work with my setup.  So when I told her that I got it figured out she asked how I got it working so after telling her she said thank you and told me to have a good day.  Once I got the units installed they work great and its really nice to be able to control the lights through the app or through my echo with my voice.  There is not currently Smart Hub support for this product but there is a work around for that if you dig enough online and the price point for these switches is about 10 bucks cheaper than the other options out there which when you talking about 20 light switches in a home adds up quick!

I'd give this  five stars if software installation was not so difficult. Wiring was easy and I am no electrician. The five minute tutorial video is excellent. However,  the app only works after you confirm your account ID and not all email servers send the email.The company help pages do not mention that the Kasa app account verification email will not be sent by Office 365's Exchange email service. Only after repeated attempts and an hour of research did I find a reference on the Web saying that if the Android app that set up by the Kasa app to control the smart switch does not get sent by many email servers. Armed with that information, I used a Gmail address and the verification email worked right away.

Edit: They added Google Home support yesterday. It works well enough for voice control but without SmartThings or IFTTT support I cannot include TP-Link in my automation yet. Until then they are being used in rooms I hardly ever use. No change in rating yet.The switch itself is a decent product and works well most of the time. The Kasa software can be a little funky and sometimes the app will not correctly show the status of my devices (also have TP-link smart bulbs hooked up). As far as Alexa is concerned, voice activation has worked nearly flawlessly since I hooked the units up. The only issue I am having now is that TP-link stuff ONLY works with Kasa and Alexa, no Smartthings hub, no google home (yet), no IFTTT (also yet). Once these are supported I could see myself controlling my whole house with these bad boys but I have grown impatient and I am now switching to the GE Z-wave switches, which work well with Smartthings, comes in a few different styles and works with any bulb type.

At first I was having so much trouble with this device and my Echo Dot. The installation and setup was mostly painless (see below) but every day it was losing the WiFi connection and I could no longer control it with Alexa yet it worked with the Kasa App, and I could not figure out why. I finally realized that it was because of how I have my network setup. My router only issues 1 DNS setting that I could customize for DHCP devices. The other DNS setting was always the router's IP address but my router is not was managing the internet connection (its a unique setup). This was causing the switch to constantly lose its connection to the internet. Why it required the internet to function with Alexa on a local network I have no idea, but the biggest flaw is that there is now way to set static network settings so I could force specific DNS settings. I was forced to change how my network was setup so the router controlled the internet, and the DHCP settings issued a DNS setting that would work. I have several other smart home devices and none of them ever had this issue.My only other complaint is with the cover plate, it is incredibly hard to get it onto the switch. It has to be snapped on in 4 different places and it only snaps on if it is flush against the switch. Because the switch in screwed into a flexible wall box, it is impossible for me to snap the plate on. For now I have it taped on until I can find a way to make it snap on. I will probably need a bracket or some kind of hard plastic plate to hold the switch in place so I can put enough pressure on the switch plate to snap it on.

Do your research before purchasing.  The switch will only work for a single configuration of light switches.  If your existing switch is "downstream" of the light socket, then the TPI-Link smart switch will not work.  I was able to get the switch connected to the our house wi-fi rather easily, with good signal reception on the part of the switch.  Instructions were much more detailed for hooking the device up to the app controller than they were for actually installing the switch in the circuit.  Online resources were only marginally better.  My biggest disappointment was customer service.  Very long wait time and the English language skills of the tech were just about non-existent.  Thanks to Amazon for their excellent return policies.

After installing seven of these switches my router crashes at least once a day causing me to constantly unplug and re-plug the router to reset it. I believe these switches are overloading my wifi router which also has many other smart devices connected. I just had the cable company put in a new router, wires, switches, etc., but the problem still plagues me. I did not have any overloading problems until I installed these switches. I was hoping a software update from TP-Link would fix it, but when they finally did update the software the problem persisted! My only recourse seems to be ; buy a different (hopefully better) router or rip out all these smart switches!I also had an initial problem when I first installed the first switch. I could not get it to work with the Amazon Alexa system. After calling for help from Amazon and the switch company along with many resets of my apps, and wifi connections I gave up with their suggested fixes. Then after hours of talking with tech-people as I probed their Kasa app I realized they have a remote switch on default "off"! How dumb could this be, nobody knew! When I turned the default to "on" Alexa immediately started to control the switch.

Very easy to install and easy to setup. The packaging has pretty much everything you need to install the switch. .The switches picked up on the WiFi and were a breeze to get configured. The TP-Link's Kasa app makes it really easy to set them up. After installing three of these I got a notification that the firmware could be updated. The app updated them all at once without any hiccups. The app also makes it trivial to set a schedule per switch. This way I could turn our outside lights on every night at a specific time and then turn them all off at a different time. Moving the switch from one WiFi network to another was also really easy. It just involves resetting the switch. Don't be worried, the settings will be carried over

This is a review of a free product received from TP-LINK as part of the review program.I was excited to install this switch, as I wanted to test out the Sunset/Sunrise feature and see if it really turns on at the appropriate time as the sunset time changes.  Up here in Seattle, the sunset ranges from 4pm to 10pm throughout the year, so I've got specialty sunset/sunrise timer switches on my porch lights that adjust with the shifting sunsets.  These standalone switches cost about the same as this wi-fi switch, but the TP-Link switch is controllable via smartphone app and Amazon Alexa, which makes it a way better deal.

I would give the switch 5 stars except for two cons. The first is that I was unable to get the switch to work if the power was wired to the light. This is when you only have one cable(two wires) to the light switch box. As we have in the older pre 1950's section of our house. It switch would light up but would not manually operate the light. When I had power to the box, i.e. two cables, one from power the other to the light, it worked great. It even connected and no drops in an area where our wifi signal is weak. App could be a little more intuitive, but the help section answered all my questions about setting up schedules and getting it to work with our echo. Which is way cool by the way. The second con is that there inside is big and leaves little room the the switch box for the wires. This was a problem for me because I had one with three cables one power and two to lights. As I tried to stuff it all back in the box, I disconnected on and had to go through the whole install again. BTW I have kids who for the life of them can't turn off lights. I got these so that I could do it with voice commands. Now I can except in the older parts. The pic is the box it would not work in.

There may be nothing wrong with this product -- honestly, I don't know.  The important question is  "Why don't I know?".  I don't know because I never installed the switch.  So, the bigger question is "Why not?"  This is why.  Proper installation requires a neutral wire in your wall box.  The existing switch was wired with a "switch leg", thus no neutral wire, and no safe installation.  One would think that this kind of information might have been on the box.  It wasn't  Or, maybe on the installation instructions?  Nope!  I only became aware of the problem after I opened the box, examined the product, and saw too many wires on the switch!  Thinking that there must be a solution I went to the support page of TP-Link's web site. Only after drilling down quite a bit did I discover that this product wasn't going to work for me!There may be nothing wrong with this product, but be cautious before you buy it.  Make sure it will work in your environment.

During installation, the switch went into an endless reboot loop. This was caused by a slight overtightening of the bottom screw. If you run into that problem, back out the bottom screw a bit to see if it fixes the problem. The reason this occurs is the placement of the reset buttons below the main switch. When installing this all-plastic fixture, the housing tends to bend, actuating the buttons. I hope that TP-Link can come up with a better mechanical design that prevents this from happening.That being said, the switch works well when controlled via an Amazon Echo Dot. Does anybody need a voice-controlled switch? Hardly, but it does add a nice futuristic touch to the house;-) If they could come up with switches for three-way configurations, that would be even sweeter since most of our light fixtures are wired that way.
Perfect way to control your lights, especially when your kids like to leave things on

Switch works ok but the app & approach has flaws. Firstly, no instructions with the switch, you have to download the app and then go step by step. This isn’t really practical when working in a construction environment plus the only reason we needed them was because the load & line cables are indifferent but you don’t know that until you get the app. 2nd issue, the app only works on local Wi-Fi until you registered your account which may be fine but for me the registeration process kept failing due to their server so we can’t get remote access. I think they need to rethink the practicalities of their approach.After less than 24 hrs, revised to one star. Now I can’t access the switch. Get a message that I need to be on MY Wi-Fi network even when I am connected and stood right next to the device. Looks like a one and done app.....buyer beware.

Once I realized what was happening, I was able to adjust the plate until it stopped resetting the switch.

This unit works well once installed, and installation was easy except for one problem.  The flanges that actually attach the unit to the box in the wall are plastic, fairly thick plastic at that.  On most conventional switches/outlets that flange is metal and therefore thinner and stronger.  Sometimes you have to push on a newly installed switch to press it back into the box due to the other wires in there.  Plus the inside "box" of this switch itself is relatively bulky, meaning you need to make even more room for it inside the wall box.  These plastic flanges will not tolerate as much pushing that way.  Finally once installed in a 3-gang box like I did, the thicker plastic flanges holds the cover plate away from the wall slightly.  Otherwise it works well, but I wish the mounting flanges were metal.  If you are installing this unit in a box by itself then this objection would likely not matter.

NO LONGER WORKS WITH ALEXA OR GOOGLE HOME.  And it doesn't seem TP-Link cares to fix it.  I bought this smart switch and a bunch of smart plugs.  Initially, they all work fine and I had no issues.  Starting about a week and a half ago, all TP-Link smart products stopped working cold.  Alexa or Google Home would say the devices are not available right now.  There are reports all over the Internet that this is widespread and happens to many users.  I've removed the skill and re-added it to no avail.So far, nothing has seemed to fix it and I hear nothing from TP-Link on the issue.  My other smart devices like Nest thermostat, Nest cam, smart LED bulbs (from a different company), etc. all still work just fine.  With a huge, major issue like this, I would recommend that everyone stays as far away from TP-Link products as possible.

I thought I could easily just leave one of the switches' black wire not connected with anything, but it didn't work that way although my switch could still connect with wifi and stuff.. Searching for the answer on threads, I found an easy workaround that worked perfectly. I'm not an electrician so i'm not sure if this is bad, but it seems to be working fine for me. This switch is awesome! Installation out of the box took less than 10 minutes! The hardest part for me was getting the wires back into my light switch box after installing this, but that is of no fault of this switch. The wires running from this won't hinder anyone's switch box as they aren't too long at all. The first thing you have to do when you get this switch is install TP Link's Kasa app onto your smartphone. From there you select which smart home hardware you are installing, and the instructions are very straightforward and even include useful illustrations for anyone that is having difficulties. Once everything is setup, the lights wired to the switch work like a charm! I have my switch hooked up in the kitchen and I simply say "Alexa turn on the kitchen" and the lights turn on and off. The only issue I ran into is the wall plate. It is meant for a single plate, but my kitchen wall plate uses a double plate, but I found a third party plate that works just fine. I would highly recommend this switch for kitchen and outdoor lights, because they are so easy to use!

This thing works. I had a pesky problem of turning on/off my patio lights based on actual sunlight. I tried the photosensitive switch but the sensor placement is key and therefore not a very flexible option.  Also, there are issues related to flickering etc.  A switch based on timer works well but is not sensitive to seasonal changes and hence need constant adjustments.  This switch solved all those issues in one shot. Installation was dead easy: Turn off the mains, remove old switch and put the new one.  The software configuration would not have been easier too with the help of the phone app.  Now, I set my switch to turn ON at sunset (this gets pulled based on geo location data) and trun OFF in the morning.  Awesome stuff 5*.

I love these things. You don't need a separate hub like many other products out there to control them. I have the original Amazon Echo and got the 6 pack of $50 dots so Alexa can hear me in any room of my house. The integration works flawlessly.For those of you that are hooking these up yourself, it's not that hard. The main trick, if you haven't dealt with a white "common" wire in the past, is to add the white wire from this switch to all the white wires in the wire nut in your outlet (if you have more than one bundled in a nut). You just need to untwist your common bundle nut (all white wires in this bundle), add the white wire from the switch to that bundle, and re-twist the nut. At first, I thought I needed to untwist the common wires in the outlet and attach to a single common wire, but the switch would not work. When I attached to all the common wires in the outlet, it worked. I had never dealt with wiring a switch to common wires, so this was new to me. The other wires are wired up just like a normal light switch.

Well, most of the bad reviews I read were not getting the switch to work for one reason or another.  I never made it that far, because I can't install it.  The electrical code did not require a neutral in the switch box until 2011, so I guess most of you are living in new homes?  Unfortunately, I guess,  I built and wired my house in 1978, and as it turns out there is not a single switch in my house with a neutral wire!  I think the REQUIRES A NEUTRAL WIRE should be in bold and underlined!

I made the mistake of replacing all the switches in my home thinking Amazon Alexa could control them all; purchased three Alexas and everything worked well for a month.  Then on 28 FEB Amazon's S3 servier went down for 12 hours and nothing worked; once Amazon's cloud servers were back up, TP-Link cloud servers went down and have been down for two more days.  "Put your stuff in the cloud..." they said; "Your data is safe and always acessible in the cloud," they said.  Boy, do I feel foolish.  I manage a data center for the Federal Government, so I was amazed to learn that Amazon and TP-Link operate with insufficient redundancy to ensure cloud service is maintained.  In brief, if you're looking for a working light switch with very unreliable cloud connectivity, then this product is for you.  However, if you want a reliable so-called "wireless, automated" home, my advice is that these companies are simply not capable of providing it.  I wish I'd stuck with my flip-on switches. It would have saved me hours of installation time; hours of time on the phone with Amazon and TP-Link to only be told, "we're working on restoring service;" over a grand to purchase all the TP-Link and Amazon products that were supposed to work; and the 5 minutes it's taking right now to warn you all about these services.

I like it, but be prepared for some modest tech hurdles.  This is my second TP-Link device (first was plug in switch) that I've set up to control lights in my home with my Amazon Echo.  First, be aware that if your switch circuit does not have a neutral wire this will not work.  It is not uncommon for the neutral to be run straight to the light fixture and only the hot (black) wire run back to a switch in a loop that is closed by the switch.  If that's your setup, you're out of luck with this unit.  Setup is pretty straight forward, but problems can crop up.  For this install, the Kasa app kept trying to link with my wireless network printer instead of the switch.  Disconnecting the power to the printer solved the problem.  Also, just as with my first install (the plug in outlet switch) performance is spotty at first.  That is, Alexa will say OK to the command, but nothing happens at the light.  Must be a system learning curve, because on the first unit after two days this was no longer experienced.  Just installed this switch today, and it's not yet working at 100%, but I'm optimistic that it will.Finally, I'm moved to say that I like my Echo better every day.  Can't wait to issue the command "Open the pod bay door Alexa."

I was very excited about automating my home and using Alexa, so I bought several smart outlets and one smart switch to test out. While the outlets work great in my home, the switch is another story.For potential buyers: Make sure you know about your home's wiring before buying the HS200 or any other smart light switch. My home was built in 1996 and I was certain that it was modern enough to have the required wiring. I misunderstood what a neutral wire actually does and thought that the white wire in the walls was neutral, but it's not! I've read that my local code did not start requiring a neutral wire to light switches until 2011, so most people's homes will not be able to work with this switch. Basically, don't make my mistake. Check to make sure that you have three wires AND a ground before buying.

Until TP-Link creates a Wi-Fi switch that does NOT require a neutral wire - (and if we can put a man on the moon in 1969, the technology should be available) - I recommend holding off buying this IF you live in a home that was built before 1990.

I hate it when they group reviews together. I bought the Smart Light Switch and the Smart Plug. Both devices were easy to connect to my network and get working. They can both be used as regular on off devices if WiFi is out or your phone is dead. I was also able to enable the KASA skill and use it with Alexa. I did have problems at first because my device names were too similar.The only con I have is with the app. It's not really a problem, I just wish it had more features. You can set a schedule for each device with as many on and off times as you like, but these are set times. You can set the devices to come on and off by sunset. There is an away mode,  but you can only set two times in the away schedule, an on or off. I bought these thinking that they would have a randomize setting to make it seem like you were actually away when you turned on the away setting. I wish they would add a feature to invite someone else to your account without giving them your password. Right now there is no such feature.

After struggling with getting this to see my wifi network for hours, I was wrist deep in cords and I had four routers running trying to figure out why Kasa could only see two of the networks. All were 2.4ghz so in theory they should all work fine. I eventually realized that it was only seeing the routers that were password protected. The fact that this will only work on password protected routers isn't mentioned anywhere, not even online, so it was extremely frustrating until I figured it out.I'm unable to password protect my main wireless router (it's from the ISP and they changed the default router login information) so I ended up taking an old router and configuring it to work as a wireless bridge. There's directions online on how to do this for your specific second router, it's not too difficult if you're technologically literate. I then WPA2 password protected my wireless bridge and connected the switch to it without any issues. Then I altered my Echo Dots to connect through the bridge so everything is on the same wireless network, and now the lightswitch is working with Alexa. Setup was easy before and after the wifi issue. I live out in the country a half mile from my nearest neighbor so an unsecured network is preferred in order to allow guests to easily connect to wifi.

I was a bit hesitant to order as I tried last year with a smart switch from a local shop Andrea the backing of the smart switch was too big and I couldn’t fit it in because I had many wires tangled up from the way the house was wired.But with this switch it was smooth as silk and install was pretty smooth as long as you follow the directions on the app and have some handyman skills but probably anyone can do this as long as they know where the fuse box is and they have a current indicator.

I like the light switch itself. It allows me to program my outdoor lights surrounding exterior of the house. We really like that feature.  But, a few months after we installed it and after changing out the batteries in our garage door opener remotes - several times. We realized that this switch interferes with our garage door opener‘s reception.  Before the installation of this switch, we could push the button and our garage door would open as we approach the house. Now, after getting the interference from this switch, you have to get right up to the garage door before it will finally open.  We are researching someway to change the frequency on the light switch or blockage interference in some other manner.  But, we have found no solution yet.We are certain that it is the switch. We killed power to the switch and the garage door certainly works like it used to. But, when we power up the switch again, the interference issue returns.

So I had an electrician come out to install this just because I didn’t want to do it wrong or mess it up. Turns out not all switches are wired the same! And it can’t even be hooked up to our kitchen light. I don’t know if it’s because our kitchen is wired for those long fluorescent bulbs or what but this switch has two black wires and we only have one (something about needing a leg lead?). We waited almost 2 months to have it installed because the electrician was backed up from COVID and now we’re stuck with it. I’m so bummed!

I want to LOVE these light switches. Simple to install and easy to wire up if you know what your doing. They do not support IFTTT (which would add several other automated options, like when coming home your lights turn on.) They do not have any motion sensors yet, again preventing any kind of automation much like a way to sense room activity, or lack there of. These switches do not work if you have a duel light switch to a single light option (Like a switch at your garage door and a separate switch at the other end of room to turn on kitchen lights) To get around this you would have to remove the 3 wire option to the slave switch. Overall happy. Would like to see IFTTT, Motion Sensors, and Remote switches to turn on lights or automate functions (like the Insteon remote keypad). Further the "newly branded" TP-Link isnt really dealing with the customer service issues they have always had. Support via social media is almost non-existant, and Forum support the same, which is my reason for a 3 star rating. This is an un-bias review, they didnt pay me or give me any product. I purchased these from Frys Electronics as they are cheaper than Amazon. I own 4 of these switches and 7 Smart plugs.

Just so we are all on the same page, this is a review of a free product received from TP-LINK as part of the review program. So far I have enjoyed the hs200 switch even more so than the smart plugs I have purchased. The main reason I like this switch is it’s not an add-on and blends in with normal decor.  After, I finally found a single pole switch in my house the install was fairly straight forward, with the exception that I had to go online to view the install documents. I first installed the switch in my kitchen but my wife missed the simple toggle of a normal switch. I then moved it to the living room and it was great. The little built in night light is really nice but doesn’t provide enough light to walk by just enough so you can see the switch and you aren’t fumbling for the switch in the dark. The best features for me is the away mode, where the lights turn on and off at random times. I travel and between this and my smart plugs my home looks occupied at all times.If you have put in normal light switches and/or outlets you should be able to install this, just make sure you turn off the power before you do. I actually plan on moving the switch again into a 2 gang box for a fan/light. I’m curious on how it will look as the plate the hs200 comes with seems thicker than most switch plates.

This was an easy install, took about 15 minutes. Fits normal gang plates even the my picture looks crooked. The Kasa app was simple to use and once an account was setup, it took about 5 minutes to find and setup the switch. Integrating with Alexa was a breeze, just login into your Kasa account and it will search and find the switch.As a bonus, this is in my bathroom because the kids leave the light on all the time. Now, when they last expect it, the light will go off when it's most inconvenient. :)

Purchased as a Father’s Day gift. I installed it myself in the kitchen along with an Echo Flex.I’ll let you in on a little trick in case you don’t have a neutral wire. If you try connecting it without a neutral, it will start up but it’ll fail to turn on the light or device. In most cases, the neutral and ground wires are tied together at the electrical panel. If you have no neutral wire, just use the ground wire. Hook the switch’s neutral and ground wire right into the ground from the panel. Did the trick just fine for me and never had an issue with it.

I just installed one of these switches to control the outside front lights at my home. There was plenty of room in the box for the switch, wires & wire nuts. I used my existing switch cover plate and saved the one that came with the wifi switch. There are no installation instructions in the package with the switch, but there is a label on the switch with easy to read wiring instructions. Take note that you must connect this wifi switch to a white/neutral wire. Traditional manual 'dumb' switches do not need a white/neutral connection.Once I turned the power back on at the breaker box, the switch turned my lights on and off manually like any normal switch. No problem there. Installation of the wifi switch was simple assuming you know how to install and connect home electrical switches.
I have had these installed for about a month now and they have been working great.Pros:

These are the 2 way switches, and they are GREAT.  I've copied the information for review from the 3 Way and the Plugs, I use all of them with the Kasa App from TP Link and also Alexa devices throughout the home.  The App is Flawless for me, and they all just work, flawlessly with the Amazon Echo throughout the home.  You can also pull up the App and they work.....amazingly its instantaneous, I'm loving these.These 3 Way work.  Now, I learned you don't "have" to put each one on the same circuit, so if you are okay going against the TP Link recommendation, since they come in pairs, you can put 1 on a plug and have it work, and put the other one on a different plug and name it separately, and BAM you have two 3 way circuits that are on your Alexa control (and Kasa App control etc).  I do have some "4 way" switches.....and they area  PAIN.  I thought they were 3 way, and one of them I got to work (don't ask me how, ha) but the other I cannot.  They have an extra wire, and it's a huge pain in the rump.  In general, it's awesome though.  I copied the review from the "smart plugs" as well, because all of the information is essentially the same, except for the install which for the switch you have to put in the wall switch (TURN OFF BREAKER< HA) and the plugs are just plug in and then the lamp or whatever goes in the plug.  The switches you have to know how to wire in a replacement switch in the wall.

This switch functions well and is straightforward. It is attractive and seems solidly built. It was easy enough to program. However, I ran into two important problems.First, it has a "locator" light to help you find it in the dark, which is terrific unless the switch faces your bed. The manufacturer ought to write the two lines (or so) of code that would permit the owner to turn off the locator light.

Works as described. This is my third Kasa TP-Link product (the other two are switched outlets), so I already had the app installed, and adding this was quick and easy, although the directions could have been a bit clearer that your phone has to first wi-fi connect DIRECTLY to the switch so the app can talk to it during the installation, THEN the switch will connect to your wi-fi. The app tries to do this for you, but it failed to do so on my Samsung S9+ phone, and I had to go into the wi-fi settings on the phone, find the switch, and connect to it. Once I did that and returned to the app, things moved along nicely. If you have other TP-Link wi-fi stuff installed, it will automagically pick up the wi-fi name and password, and those fields will already be filled in when you get to that screen. As soon as it connected to the Internet, it found a firmware update, and I let it install that - took about three minutes, with the app notifying me it was done. And once you establish wi-fi connectivity, the little green wi-fi light turns off, which was a bit disappointing - I liked seeing that. It turns on again in orange if it loses connectivity, then goes green and turns off once it reestablished its connection.The physical installation was somewhat difficult because the switch is wide, deep, and bulky. I had to move wires around inside the three position gang box and even then, it wasn't as clean an installation as I like, although nothing like the pictures one reviewer posted.

In the 12 months I have put approximately 20 different TP-Link products (HS100, HS200, HS210, HS220 and WiFi extender)All worked fine until one day all were no longer reachable I tried all known methods to get them reconnected but NO Avail.
The Good News: The switch and supporting app work great and it is all fairly intuitive.The Bad News: TP-Link's support; I happened to receive a bad switch within the 3-pack though.

The switch works great and looks beautiful but it requires a little more skill than just "plug and play" to install and to get it to work on your internet and with the app.  The wiring is confusing:  there are two black wires and a neutral (white) because the box needs power when the light is off to sense the internet.  Depending on whether the switch you are replacing is the last on that particular electrical run or is located in the middle somewhere with power continuing on to the next switch or plug means different wiring requirements.  They probably need better wiring diagrams:  I have three of these switches, love them, but I really didn't know what I was doing and just tried different things (pigtail a white wire for sure and pigtail a black wire on one).  The switch does pick up your internet but it's a little squirrely if you are working with internet extenders in your house.  Don't give up, it's worth it.  Last thing:  it is difficult to rename or regroup this item once you've set it in the app or in your home assistant (Google or Alexa) - I'm still working that issue because my lighting setup changed when I bought the second one.  I think I will have to remove the appearance of my 3 switches and reconfigure them in the software with the new names.  The price has come down so these are now a much better value.
I would not waste your money on this item poorly designed and gave me a lot of problems.

I love this light switch. Makes it really easy to turn on the lights to check on my 3D printer's webcam while I'm remote, such as in bed.The switch isn't a normal on or  off switch that flips. It is a momentary press style on the bottom side. There is a little light that illuminates under the toggle when the light is off so you can see it in the dark. The momentary press feels so satisfying as well (that sounds weird). But if you get one and press it, you'll know what I'm talking about.

This switch was easy to install with step by step instructions, as mentioned previously, 1. install, 2. Get App, 3. Add device to app, 4. Enjoy! It syncs accounts with Google Home and works flawlessly with Google Home and Assistant with voice commands.Beware of other products that require specific bulbs to work with their switch (one of the reasons I went with this product), I believe Hue is that way...just tons more $$$.
Terrible product. Does not work with Alexa.Disconnects from WiFi consatly.

If you do not have a smartphone don't even consider this switch.  It claims that it works through Alexa but that is only after you create a proprietary account on their website and set it up through their custom app.  Unfortunately, I do not own a smartphone and now where in the marketing materials does it say one is needed.They are crooks and do not support their 100% satisfaction guarantee - no return if you do not have a smart phone! They are simply defrauding people trying to get devices for use with Alexa. Amazon should drop them like a rock or they will be sucked down into the criminal fraud this company is representing.
It broke, DID not work after a few uses.
Switch has aluminum wire coming out the back. Unless your home wire is already aluminum this is bad.

The HS-200 wall switch requires a 4-wire setup with a neutral (not just ground) wire to work. Neutral wires were not officially required in light switches until 2011 which means MOST existing light switches contain regular 3-wire configurations. This means they have a black/white/green (or bare) wire but no neutral 4-wire configuration. The switch will not work with 3-wire setups. The description does not plainly state this. The description says it requires a single light switch and a neutral wire but often the white wire in a 3-wire black/white/green is considered a neutral. The product may be fantastic but it is useless with a 3-wire setup and this should be plainly stated BEFORE you purchase it. Although the neutral wire requirement is listed it is buried deep in the description and many will think that the neutral wire is one of the wires in a 3-wire setup. Since MOST light switches are NOT compatible, this should be clearly indicated at the top of the listing, not way down, small and in language that will be misunderstood by many.
Wasnt what I wanted, I'm sure it's a great product just not something I could use.

Easy to install, easy to add to the Kasa smartphone app, and easy to control via the physical light switch, via the app, or even via voice assistant.I love the fact that you can "group" multiple smart switches together in the app, and have them behave a certain way. For example, when I get home, I turn on the light switch at my entrance, and my living room, kitchen, and hallway lights all turn on. Very convenient and much easier + cheaper than getting an electrician to rewire my condo.

This is my third / fourth Kasa - TP Link product.  My main reason for choosing this brand was the fact that it works with "Alexa".  Secondly, these are "no hub required" products.I recently bought two switches to replace my bedroom light and fan switches.  I'm not an electrician and yet I was able to install these switches in less than a half hour without issue.  Be advised; this product does not come with installation instructions so you may need to search on-line videos for assistance.

We have every type of TP link device that they have to offer except the outdoor extension plug. What I love most is that We can control EVERYTHING ( except the WIFI extender that uses the Tether app).Each of us has the Kasa app on their phone (Android and IOS), and they can control everything, just as I can, including all upstairs and downstairs lamps in every room, big lights in each room, ceiling fans, and the hot water kettle in the kitchen.  We use the mini plugs for the lamps and the kettle, the bulbs and /or the light switches for the big room lights and ceiling fans.
This unit has its highs and lows. Smart devices are becoming more normal everyday for your home, and allow easy access and convenience for your life.

Very easy to install and set up. I've got several TP-Link light bulbs and switches, and all work nicely. In this case, I got the light switch specifically to control my porch light. It does require a neutral wire, but that wasn't a problem. The light can be controlled either by pressing the switch for on or off, by my smartphone with the Kasa app, or by Alexa voice commands or the Alexa app. I've got it set up, via the Alexa app to turn on at sunset and off at sunrise. Using the Alexa app gives me an advantage over the Kasa app, in that I can add a time offet to sunrise/sunset, if desired.

I'm using this switch with Alexa to control 4 fluorescent tube lights which are on top of a soffit in my kitchen. I just say, "Alexa, turn on the soffit lights" and the lights come on. I can also have her turn them off. One big advantage with this switch is that it doesn't require a hub like most other lights. All of the connectivity is built right into the switch. It can control whatever lights or devices you have running off of that switch, but all together, of course. It will only turn them on and off. There is no dimmer function.This wall switch replaces a regular wall switch. It is connected much the same as the old switch except that it needs a neutral wire which is usually white.I'm not an electrician by any means, but I've replaced several light switches with dimmer switches over the years. I checked the short instructions and diagram which came with the switch. It looked simple enough, 4 wires coming out of the switch which matched 4 wires coming out of the wall switch box, once the old switch was removed. Except that wasn't the case. There were 3 separate white or neutral wires coming out of the switch box, all twisted together. I have a healthy respect for electricity and figured I better check and find out if it was safe to connect the bundled 3 wires to the single white wire from the TP-Link switch. So I checked their website. This wasn't addressed there. But no problem, they say they have tech support 24/7. So I called. I waited 15 minutes on hold after going through several voice prompt options. Then I briefly spoke with someone with a heavy accent who said she'd connect me to someone who could help. After several minutes I was disconnected. I called back. This time I ended up on hold for 20 minutes before being disconnected. I also tried emailing. After more than a week I still haven't received a reply. So I consider Tech Support for this product non-existent. I finally found an answer to my question on one of their competitors websites, with videos. The solution was to connect to the 3 white wires with the one on the switch. Just twist them all together and secure with a twist on wire connector which was provided with the switch.

I like the fact that you can use this switch to turn your light on and off if you need to.  This can be iffy with some of the "smart" bulb systems out there which screw up your settings if you use the manual switch.  Installation is simple (as long as your box is deep enough).  You do need to make sure you have the proper wiring available with your old switch as some older homes may be problematical in this area.I also like the program-ability of the switch...setting hours for on and off..or random hours if you are away, etc.  And it's nice to be able to check from your phone while you are away from your house whether or not you left a light on.  It's also nifty that there is a small light (not too bright) in the switch which shows you where it is in the dark.

The TP-Link Smart WiFi light switch is a great addition to most people's home automation systems.The actual switch is really nice. It has a nice touch to it. I like how it feel more like a momentary switch vs a toggle switch.  Setup for the switch is simple. It comes with the wire nuts and just a matter of bringing the wires together. Pressing the switch works nice, quickly and swiftly.  I also enjoy that the switch brings a nice screwless wallplate.

The HS200 light switch is a fantastic device that gives remote control to lights or ceiling fans. Instead of having to get up and walk over to a switch and hit it you can do it all from your cell phone or tablet or any other wireless device that is compatible with the app (apple and android devices).  This is especially convenient in the morning and at night when rest is of the utmost importance and interrupting or delaying it to turn off a glaring light or shut off a chilling fan can be very cumbersome.The device is can also use timers which can be set up to match a schedule. I set mine up so my light turns on in my room right as it gets dark outside. I've also set my fan to cut off around the time I fall asleep. In my room the light and fan are on the same switch. These features could also be used to deter theft by giving the impression that the room and home is occupied.

I was able to install the light switch in my family's home and it's fantastic. We own an Amazon Echo and we can pair the two devices together. This gives the user voice control on the device that is connected to the light switch. This is an amazing feature which I truly enjoy; I can turn things on without even using the phone App. In addition phone app is very easy to use for set up, but once a device is set-up, I think the UI can be a bit more friendly/informative to allow the user to know what is capable of the device.PRO:

First off, these are not traditional rocker switches. They are push button style, with only the bottom half being the button. Keep that in mind if you're trying to match styles. Also, they have a light on the bottom of the switch. It's quite dim, but if you've got them next to non-Kasa switches, they could stick out.The switches are quite deep, so if you don't have a lot of room in your gang box, you might not be able to fit them, or might require a deeper box.

Installed in under 10 minutes.  The only issues are this is bigger than a traditional switch (so one needs to make room in the box) and one must have a common (white) wire in the box (which almost all newer homes have anyway).  After installing, simply follow the app instructions and then add to your Alexa devices like you would any other switch.  I installed it in my garage to turn on the outside lights at dusk and off at dawn.  It has been installed for about 2 months and works flawlessly.  I also only paid around $10 for this device because of an ad on facebook.

One quick warning: the instructions for installation are provided by an app, so be ready to have your phone or tablet handy. The step by step instructions are, however, easy to follow and offer well defined questions to determine how to properly install the switch based on your home's wiring.I was able to install this switch in the oldest portion of my house, where the wiring was from many decades ago. Once installed, the switch was controllable via the app, and after following additional directions in the app, I was also able to integrate it with my Amazon Alexa devices, letting me toggle the switch very easily.

I don't know the first thing about installing electrical items.  And I was not about to pay an electrician to come out to my house and install the TP-LINK Smart wi-Fi Light Switch.  So it took me a while to get the item installed.  I had to wait for my son (who must have inherited the electrical genes from his mother) to come out to my place for a visit in order to get the light switch installed.  So I have had the light switch sitting around waiting for nearly a month.But the results are impressive.  I was really only concerned with one light in the house...a reading lamp in my bedroom, which is really difficult for me to turn off by hand.  The switch on this lamp is a round metal ball which must be rotated, but it sticks; and I often have to get out of bed when I'm finished reading, and get a napkin or something to turn the switch to "off."

I've installing this switch and it works very well.  I also have the Wemo wall switch in another location in my home.  Comparing the two I would offer the following:- Setup was very easy and completely trouble free on the TP-Link; joined my network without any issues.  The setup was easier and faster than the comparable Wemo switch.  The Wemo switch was more finicky with regards to the network connection and I had to try a couple of times.  Point for TP-Link.

This is a review of a free product received from TP-LINK as part of the review program.If you are considering improving your home, upgrading too a smart home, building a new home or just want to make life easier on yourself, you have to give serious consideration to the HS200.

Once installed, these work great. They do make an audible click when turning on and off which I didn't expect but also don't mind. Installation became a real issue when trying to fit all the wires for four of these into a four gang box. The switches are very deep and take up a lot of space in the box. I just spent an hour packing and repacking the wires behind this set of four switches until I finally got them all to fit.

Very happy and satisfied so far. This is my 6th smart switch and the first TP-Link smart switch. Most of the others are either Wemo switches or Leviton. Wiring installation was straightforward, instructions were clear and all my home is wired with neutral (white wire). Build quality is also good, size is almost comparable to other peers. Initial setup: compared to Wemo smart switch and Wemo Dimmer, setup was a breeze. I could connect to my wifi in less than 2 minutes where-as with Wemo switches, it took close to 1 hour with several attempts to connect to my wifi network. Once connected both Wemo as well as TP-Link switches worked fine, had a stable Wifi connection, iPhone App worked fine as well as with Alexa. The operation using the iPhone App was bit sluggish (3-4 seconds wait time) compared to Wemo / Leviton Apps. When I rebooted my router (for firmware upgrade) or my main switch-box during installation of other devices, all the smart devices re-gained the wifi connection on its own once the router was back online. Only the Leviton smart dimmer switch went offline and never regained connection. I had to start the initial setup again after which it came back online. Both Wemo and TP-Link provide the matching face/wall plate but Leviton didn't provide one. I didn't mind a visit to the Home-Depot to get one but it's still better to have everything ready. Overall, TP-Link switches are highly recommended as they seem to be more reliable and worth every penny as Wemo switches are little more pricey. I hope the sluggish response when using iPhone App will be fixed/resolved in upcoming firmware upgrades. Finally, I wish TP-Link also had the dimmer switch as well. Hope to see the TP-link smart dimmer switches in the market soon.

I am not much of a technician, but I installed two of these switches rather easily, one to control my living room fans and one for my kitchen lights.  I may end up replacing most switches in the house for this thing!  I had a little bit of a surprise when I took off the old switch and there were only 2 black wires connected to it, but the tp link smart switch has 4: two black, one white and one green.  The 2 black wires connect to the old switch 2 black ones in any order.  The neutral inside the wall is not connected directly to the old switch.  You can easily identify it because it has two or more wires bundled up and intertwined and hanging loose inside the box with an electrical cap or electrical tape.  Just add the tp link white wire to the bundle.  I left the green ground wire floating unconnected because my light switch did not have one nor did I see anywhere inside the box to connect it to.  If your old switch has a ground connection, then attach the green wire to it.  You can find videos on YouTube if you are not sure.  The app picked up my wifi with no problem and then Alexa (downstairs) and my Google assistant (upstairs) picked the switch immediately (you have to add the switch to both, of course).  I did not encounter any of the issues others have reported, like having to press the top and the bottom or the switch or losing the wifi signal.  A light touch and the lights come on, and, of course, the commands to Alexa or Google are flawless.  Love it!
I purchased four of these switches to use with my Echo Dot and have them installed and working as expected with a few caveats.PROS

Every aspect of the Kasa light switch is awesome. My only problem was getting it installed, which the seller had advised might need to have an electrician install, which I did.  Once installed it is perfect.  I have several Kasa products, ( light switch, plug ins and light bulbs) and so far they all work perfectly.  Each one connected with Alexa without any issues almost immediately.  I can either voice command (with Alexa) or open the Kasa app on my phone and control from anywhere I happen to be, even in another state. Love it.

The only complaint I have is that this doesn't work with Apple Homekit - other than that, it is great.  To be honest, I primarily use Google Home for smart devices at home, so the Apple thing is a minor issue.It was easy to set up, even with 3 light cables hooked up to the switch - it wasn't an ordeal to get everything into the switch box.  Don't get me wrong, it was tight, but if you take the time to tuck everything in the box, it fits without issue.

It wanted to schedule the lighting in some areas at my home. It was hard to replace them with smart bulbs and I didnt want to use a hub. If you are comfortable replacing the existing switch, this is a great alternative. I am not an expert, but I was able to follow the instructions in the Kasa app and was able to set it up easily. I am now able to create schedule and it is working perfectly so far. Alexa integration is great too. My concern before buying it was that if i will be able to replace just one switch in a 3 gang/2 gang plates. It fits in perfectly with other switches.

I purchased this based upon the reliability of other TP-Link products in my home. The online instructions were easy to follow. If you don't feel comfortable about installing any electrical switch you probably want to hire a professional. The only problem I experienced was trying to locate my network and getting it to sync. After a second try it connected and has stayed that way even with a recent power interruption. The Kasa app is easy to work with my Echo. Nice being able to turn on a light before I enter the house (or turning it off if I forget). I will purchase a couple more for other switches. Note: The only problem that you might want to avoid is checking how many wires are bundled into your current switch box. The back side of the switch does take up a bit more room that a standard switch so check before you install.

I bought this as a cheaper alternative to replace a WeMo switch that was damaged.  THE APP DOES NOT ALLOW YOU TO SET UP SCHEDULES.  I wanted to use this to auto turn on my pool light at sunset and off at 2 AM -- just like I did with the old WeMo.  The Kasa App you are prompted to download does not have this feature.
